Today's foot soldier defends his particular trench under the idealized rank of "account representative", "data input specialist", or simply, "marketing representative". His/her trench is also outfitted with the modern conveniences of a fax machine, a speed-dial telephone, and part interest in a secretary. Today's wars are fought on the battlefield of office politics.

name: Rotundo
description:
The board contains 6 straight grooves running towards the centre and one going round the outer edge. (This outer edge groove is used only for the 12 balls at the start of the game). The game is played in the straight grooves in which the balls run down and are stacked.

The object of the game is to have 3 balls of your own colour stacked one on top of the other in a groove.

Two players each have 6 balls in their own colour. Each in turn places one ball in one of the six grooves. You can stack on top of your opponent's as well as your own balls. But no more than 3 balls are allowed in any one groove at this point. When all 12 balls have been placed, the players take it turns to move one ball from one groove to another: now there can be up to four balls in a groove.

You can only move one ball in your own colour and only if it is lying alone in a groove or uppermost in the groove, i.e. nearest the centre of the board. It is NOT counted as a move, however, if by moving a ball to another groove it happens that the balls in this groove are of the same number and in the same colour sequence as in the old groove before the ball left it.

A player has lost the game if he or she has no possibility of moving.

name: Pike: City Arena
description:
It is over 200 years since the first of the terran colonists landed on the uninhabited and unsuspecting planet of Neo-earth. Humans have begun to establish a new history of wanton destruction and unbridled creativity. The Singularity rift that eventually will lead to the establishment of a utopia is centuries away in the future. The fledgling nation of U.S.N.A. originally set up by the North Americans of old earth is fast becoming one of the most powerful of the industrial states.

As nations formed and the population began to be settled the media was there to cover it. Whenever a settler put a spade in the ground, wiped out a species or did something horrible to another human being a camera was there. The media became the chronicler of the pioneering years, and more. To forget the hardships of day-to-day living the Neo-earthlings immersed themselves in all forms of entertainment sims, V.R. and finally real combat TV. Beginning as fighting matches between professional athletes it quickly evolved to include audience participation. Teams of home viewers roamed across elaborate battlegrounds beating the snot out of each other for the sake of entertainment. These "teams" eventually became fighting orders with their own particular combat styles. As long as TV audiences could see a New Texan housewife savagely mauling an accountant from Maine with a pain-wand each week real combat TV continued to be a success.

Nobody knows exactly when FENRIR (Fusion Engine Non-Robotic Intercept Raider) was invented. Originally developed as support for conventional army forces, they began to be used in the frontier areas and in civilian "control" situations. The executives of the NABC (Neo-American Broadcasting Corporation) weren't slow to adopt this new technology and use FENRIR in their real combat events. Unable to construct artificial battlegrounds of a sufficient size the media networks purchased the ruins of Harmony, the former capital of the USNA state of Piermont that had been destroyed during the conflict with the Ontarians. In this city-sized arena the combatants now range across the landscape in giant FENRIR machines dealing devastation to the opposing team(s). The ultimate televised combat sport is born!

In PIKE: City arena each person controls one of the four major real combat "teams". The object is to crush the opposition while putting on the most entertaining show for the cameras.
categories: Fighting, Miniatures, Print & Play, Science Fiction, Sports, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Line of Sight, Measurement Movement, Paper-and-Pencil, Variable Player Powers

name: Axis Threat
description:
Axis Threat is a DTP wargame on the German counterattack at Gela in Sicily, 1943.

The second edition (titled Counterattack at Gela) included hypothetical scenarios allowing the Germans to use units that were available but did not participate historically. (The first edition may have these as well.)

name: First Down!
description: Before Tudor Games made its foray into a playbook-driven football game simulation, a Washington D.C. company known as TGD Games made its own version of a football game driven by play selection, "First Down!". In it, two players call offensive plays and set offensive formations in order to drive down the field and score, or set defensive formations to prevent the offense from gaining ground.

name: Traffic Patrol
description: One player controls an red "outlaw" car. The other player(s) control four gray "police" cars. The outlaw can move in any direction, while the police may not move backwards. The outlaw's goal is to escape the board; the goal for the police is to trap the outlaw or force him back to his starting space. No dice are involved. Instructions are provided in both English and French.

name: 18 Wheel'n
description: 18 Wheel'n is a promotional piece published by Roof Enterprises and presented by George Transfer Inc. of Parkton, Maryland. The object of the game is to be the first to get one's rig from their home city terminal to their destination terminal and back. Yellow spaces on the board require players to draw a card that can either help or hinder them.

name: Battlefield Command
description: Two players use tanks, helicopters, paratroopers, engineers, bridges, and infantry to achieve either full victory (elimination of an opponent's forces or Operations Command Center), or at least a tactical victory based on points should either of the main victory conditions no longer be achievable. Special advanced/tournament rules are also included.

name: Escape From Pirate Island
description: One player leads a Pirate fleet of 6 ships, while his opponent leads the King's fleet of 3 war ships, 2 life boats, and 9 merchant ships. Both sides have reserve forces that may come into play as well. Sea monsters (a giant squid and giant octopus) may be added to increase game complexity. The Pirate player wins by eliminating the King's fleet; the King's player can win via straight force elimination against the prates, successful transit of a merchant ship, or by capturing the Pirate's Treasure.

name: Pacific Fleet Command
description: Each player has 2 aircraft carriers, 5 dive bomber squadrons, a battleship, 5 heavy cruisers, 2 light cruisers, 2 submarines, 4 destroyers, 2 mine sweepers, 2 mine layers, and 2 construction battalion game pieces. A player achieves victory by destroying his opponent's 3 ship yards or eliminating his opponent's aircraft carriers, heavy cruiser, and battleship.

name: Convoy Defender
description: One player takes on the role of a submarine force commander, leading a fleet of six submarines. The other takes charge of a convoy of nine destroyers and three convoy ships. A hurricane and two tropical storms may also be added to increase game complexity. Victory conditions vary for each player: the convoy commander must eliminate the submarine fleet, while the sub commander need only reduce the convoy to a single ship.

name: Adventures of Sir Lancelot
description: This game is based on the NBC TV series of the same name. Two to four players compete in a "spin and move" venture to avoid pits, traps, a dragon, and the Black Knight as they head along the road to capture Camelot or Westbury Castle.

name: Coloption
description:
"Coloption" is also known as "Col*ption".

From the rules:

"COLOPTION is a fast paced adult game with some gaming elements familiar to generations of games players and new devices [...]. The object of the game, which is played on a geometrically designed game board, is to move your men from their home base to a goal. To do this, you must roll combinations of dice and color cubes and move your men through an exit triangle, hazard hexagon, safety zones, alien colors and goal paths. If that's not enough, there's also the danger of being 'bumped' by other players!

"COLOPTION can be played by two to six players which immediately makes it more sociable than backgammon which is played as a twosome. A round is over when all of one player's men have either reached the goal or been bumped. A round usually lasts from fifteen to thirty minutes. Play can be for several rounds as in backgammon or for point totals as in bridge."
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Conservation
description: In "Conservation", players move their cars along the board's outer track, then the inner track, and then to their service station in the middle. Along the way, they face state fines and maintenance issues for their car. The game ends when a player reaches their service station, but the winner is the player with the most money at the end.

name: Corvette
description:
"Corvette" bills itself as "the automobile maintenance and trading game." However, it somehow feels more like a Chevy advertising piece, as each player progresses from owning a Cavalier through a Celebrity, Caprice, and Camaro in their quest to be the first to own a Corvette and be free of debt.

2-6 players compete in an admittedly simplistic game: collect money by passing "payday", then hope to avoid spending it all on car maintenance in order to buy a better car. Judicious selection of which "pick up" cards (coupons and special board advance cards) to keep in one's hand add a little strategy to an otherwise "roll and move" style game.
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: FutureStories
description:
From the game description:

"Storytelling often revolves around the past. But there's another type of storytelling that we call FutureStories. Imagine playing a game where you talk about your hopes and dreams for the future. What do you want to be doing five years from now? What will the world look like in 100 years? [...]

"FutureStories is easy to play and fun for all ages. There are no right or wrong answers. This game is based on your imagination, not intelligence, knowledge of trivia, or chance. And... it can be played anywhere."

name: Game of Love
description:
In this game, two to eight players compete by trying to out-romance each other. For the winner, the game notes, "Your reward is collecting a KISS, a BEAR HUG, or a HEARTY HANDSHAKE from the lover of your choice. (We suggest the winning lover and the chosen one leave the room for this.)"

While luck plays a factor in moving from the start space to the LOVE NEST goal, life experiences, memory, quick wit, and other factors can also help you advance. Some spaces call upon you to quote a line from a love poem (or complete a line for a provided rhyme) without repeating another player's answer. Others call on a player to correctly identify the eye color of the other players in the game. Still others feature bits along the line, "If you think your legs are pretty, go forward one. If anyone doubts you, prove it or go back two."

name: Pol-A-Tics
description: In "Pol-A-Tics", each player is assigned a platform of seven different issues that shows which position their candidate has taken on each issue. As with many election games, players choose a game duration prior to the start of game play. When that time has expired, players determine the popular vote winner in each state to allocate the electoral votes. Unlike actual elections, however, a tie in the popular vote for a state results in a split of that state's electoral votes, and the player with the most electoral votes is declared the winner.
mechanics: Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Pure Greed
description:
In 1971, CreaTek release a title called "Pure Greed" and subtitled it as, "A Nasty Game for Nasty People." In truth, the game could have been subtitled, "A Nasty Game *from* Nasty People," as it is essentially the same game that CreaTek marketed a few years earlier under the name "Speculation".

"Pure Greed" is for two to six players. The object of the game is to amass the greatest wealth through property ownership. Players first compete at auction for the properties, then collect rents from each other or the bank as they land on owned properties. The game ends when the last purchase OPTION card has been purchased, at which point the player with the most money is the winner.
mechanics: Commodity Speculation, Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Running For President
description: "Running For President" is a game that provides an odd mix of Primary, Convention, and General Election campaigns. Each player must obtain the necessary vote total in the Primary area in order to proceed to the Convention, then a higher vote total to proceed to the General Election, then a still higher vote total to break free and try to end the game. The player with the highest vote total wins, regardless of where they are on the board.
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Slick Willie
description:
Long before Monica Lewinsky and cigars came to the fore on Clinton-based games, "Slick Willie" was a common theme in the Clinton-based game fare. As the designer goes on to note in his introduction, "This game is based solely on my opinion. It's designed to make you laugh at all the hard times we've had over taxation and for all the aggravation, desperation and suffering we're all going to share in the months and years ahead."

In light of the game having come out before Clinton finished his first year in office, the prior 12 years of Republican presidencies, and the subsequent U.S. economic boom, it comes across in hindsight as one of the more mean-spirited Clinton games to hit the market.

The game is nominally for two to four players, though the designer notes that, "you may play up to 6 players, for extra pawns use lose [sic] change." The object of the game is to amass and retain 270 electoral votes while trying to enter the White House.
mechanics: Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: The Big Board
description:
From the game description:

"THE BIG BOARD is a game of stock investments, combining chance and skill. Two to six players move colored tokens around the board, and play the market. The object of the game is to make money, as much money as possible, before the game ends. To do this, players SPECULATE, buying low priced stocks that may rise in value, PROFIT-TAKE, selling stocks for more than they cost, and EARN DIVIDENDS on the stock they own. [...]

"Investors must watch the market's movement and make the right choice at the right time to get the most return on their investments. Test your skill against the ups and downs of the stock market on THE BIG BOARD."
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Stock Holding

name: The Big Campaign
description: "The Big Campaign" is a game for either two or four players. In a fashion reminiscent of Monopoly, players gain the electoral votes of a given state by landing on it and buying it. Opponents who land on one of your states must pay a penalty for campaigning in that state. However, there are Campaign issue cards that can allow you to gain a state for free, or have a state wrested from your control and placed back up for grabs.
mechanics: Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Starcross
description:
Starcross is a relatively simple strategic science fiction game.

The board is made up of a number of hexagonal sections, the number in use depending on the number of players and the desired length of the game. Each section has a number of star systems which produce varying amounts of credit, and have no other characteristics. Players use their controlled credit each turn to build or upgrade their ships.
Ships have two characteristics, movement speed and combat strength - players choose the values of these by how much they spend.

Interest is added by the technological advances which can be purchased. Some of these are permanent, such as Hyperdrive, which lets one ship per turn move an unlimited distance, or Capture, which lets you capture enemy ships if you have a 3:1 advantage, while some are temporary, such as Force Field, which protects a system for one turn. (Capture will sound familiar to players of Flying Buffalo's Starweb play-by-mail game - most of the Starweb abilities are in fact reproduced here.) Each advance can only be purchased a given number of times per game (depending on the number of players), so players will be forced to use different mixes of abilities.

The object of the game is to control a given quantity of credit production.

name: Captain Kidd's Treasure
description:
The object of the game is to move your ship from one Treasure corner of the board to any other Treasure corner. Instead of using a die to dictate movement, the game uses a shuttered Light House "spinner". Players rotate the light house wheel in either direction until a dot appears. Opening the shutter at this point reveals a "light" that tells how many spaces the ship may move.

Some strategy comes into play, as circle spaces at the board's pathway intersections confer both advantages and disadvantages. A ship on a circle space *must* turn left or right on its next turn, but a player whose ship on a circle may move another player's ship if that move will put his opponent on a circle space.

name: The Highest Ground
description:
The Highest ground is a game that imagines a world that has a very long period variable climate. Where an alien species has, approximately every 800 Earth years, collected a band of warriors from the most advanced warrior state on Earth at the time, and transported them to this planet. There they are to achieve dominance over the local population, grow a crop for the aliens and, in the ensuing climactic holocaust, be almost wiped out and, therefore, not become a threat to the aliens.

At the time depicted by the game the [aliens] have just bagged a new group of Earthlings and taken them to the planet. This group is from 1979 and is a bunch of mercenaries on the losing side of an African civil war. They have been grabbed from a soon to be terminally untenable position. They have been taken to a planet where the society that has grown up around the survivors of previous recruiting drives consists of several warring states peopled by Medieval feudal kingdoms and knights, Roman legions, pony riding barbarians and Egyptian pharaohs. The game finds the few mercenaries, having allied themselves with the European kingdoms, at war with the local Roman empire.
categories: Ancient, Modern Warfare, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: The Original Intersection
description:
"The Original Intersection TM" is the humorously intended title of a game that owes almost all of its creative inspiration to Parcheesi, the Westernized version itself of Pachisi. The designers are simply experimenting to see how little they have to change to come up with their own game that will make them a million dollars in royalties, (or at least a tidy income so they can design MORE games without otherwise having to work) and thus, avoiding copyright infringement lawsuits. As such, it IS a useful and instructive game, as it is almost certain that they would have made more money had they simply reproduced the original public domain version and sold it.

The game differs from Parcheesi in that it has a jazzier layout, where the players move in a more complicated journey around a mazelike path of concentric circles. An additional option is the ability to play as a "partner" with other players, moving your partner's pieces once yours are all safely "home".

Though the board itself IS reasonably attractive, this is purely a "novelty" game, purchased for no other reason than that probably nobody else had ever seen it. It is one step away from a total "home production", in that the parts are made nearly as cheaply as possible. Indeed, though it looks totally unplayed, the box is so flimsily designed, that it is bent in several places. The tokens are push pins with the pins removed to save production costs.

name: Golferholics
description:
From the website:

The idea of the game is to imagine yourselves out on the golf course playing a relaxing game of golf - but - it is a board game and is meant to be light-hearted and entertaining, so there are a few hiccups along the way - and - you must bear in mind you will be very much at the mercy of the dice.
Played as near to real golf as possible with 2 dice, 1 black and 1 white. The black for the fairways bar the four short holes. The white for the four short holes and all eighteen greens.

The black and white dice cards are used when each dice rolls a 'c'

All the various games can be played e.g Stroke play, Foursomes, Fourball, Match play, Stableford etc. Up to 4 players at a time. Serious golfers can deduct their handicaps.

Joy for all the family and friends. Fun to try and beat 'Dad'

Ages 8 and up

name: Spell-a-Word
description:
From the rule book: "Spell-a-Word is a crossword dice game The object of the game is to build words and run up the highest point total before time runs out. The Winner is the player with the highest score after 6 rounds of play."

The letter-dice are rolled, and arranged so all players can see the letters and their scores clearly. The egg timer is started, and each player tries to spell words using only the exposed letters. These words must be recorded on a crossword-style scoresheet, which contains several spaces with word-value multipliers. After time runs out, both vertical and horizontal scores are taken, a penalty is applied for each letter left unused, and scores are compared.

Contents:
13 letter dice
1 dice cup
rule book
"Spell-a-word" blank crossword score sheets
egg timer
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Paper-and-Pencil, Pattern Building, Pattern Recognition

name: Attrition
description:
Alternative Armies' second attempt at a game in their Ion Age universe, this transports the action to the world of Golgotha, the "last battlefield" of the Great War. It also modifies the background found in the Firefight game which ostensibly takes place in the same setting. It uses the Ion Age miniatures produced by their company.

There are 3 factions - the Confederacy, the Khanate and the Trators (a mixture of mercenaries and scavengers). Players can play in either 15mm or 28mm scale - the army lists differ, with the smaller scale featuring larger vehicles like tanks. A points buy system is provided - players will control a squad or two in a typical game.

The basic game system is fairly straightforward, using a 10-sided die and centimeters. All players move (using jumpacs for extra speed), then all units fire, with the latter normally being simultaneous. Roll to hit - on a successful hit, you inflict damage, generally by chipping away at the opponent's armor and wound totals. Heavy weapons will generally vaporize a target in one hit and have enormous ranges - consequently they dominate the game. Finally, there is melee, which, as is typical for a science-fiction game, is generally more lethal than ranged combat.

The game itself could either be purchased as a PDF file or as a bound rulebook of about 94 pages (11 of them rules with another 17 pages of optional rules, most of which are geared towards providing a campaign system).

name: OMASHI
description:
From the game package:

Omashi is the fun new game of sticks and stones that can be played many ways almost anywhere. It's easy to learn and will provide many hours of enjoyment for your family and friends

Omashi is also a game that allows you to use your own imagination to create whole new ways to play it! So if you think about it, when you have the game Omashi, you don't have just one game - you have many games in one.

Omashi, the addictive low-tech game for the 21st Century and beyond.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Action / Dexterity, Dice, Fantasy
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Pattern Building, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Clash of the War Galleys
description:
Ancient naval conflicts during the Age of Antiquity (Sparta, Athenians, Persians, Phoenicians, Romans).

This is a tactical naval battle game with flat models - Bimarines and Trimarines with arbalists, catapults, Greek Fire, and corvuses.

The game appears to come with only one scenario.

Instructions are provided on how to construct the paper ships (coloring and mounting).

The map area (not provided) would be set to a grid 36" x 36" with 3" squares in which to place terrain (not provided) and your ships.

Game duration is between 5 and 10 turns. With a turn the following events take place;
1) Check Wind & Weather changes.
2) Determine which player conducts an Action (roll a die or flip a coin).
3) Ship or Fleet Action is conducted only after rolling dice and comparing the results to Ship Efficiency.
4) Combat occurs during an Action. It is usually simultaneous.
5) Actions are continued until every ship has had an opportunity to take an Action.
6) Adjudicate loss of ships from fire, ship capturing, etc.

name: Nick Game
description:
Every agent chooses a secret nickname made up of equal number in words. In order to win players must guess the nickname of one of their opponents agents or kill everybody. In turn each agent must choose a movement (by foot, by car or by motorbike) an if they want to, an action (to catch, to shoot, to place a bomb, to be hidden, to try steal files). The actions allow you to get one letter of the nickname out of the victim and in some cases cause wounds.
The 16 parts of modular board allow you to make countless combinations for the city.
The game is set in an ideal city of 400 spaces.

name: Hack & Sack New Jersey
description:
The Krylons invaded New Jersey one day. They had nothing personal against the Garden State, but they wanted to conquer New York City so they’d have a place to park, and they needed a base of operations. The Jerseyites were annoyed enough at being invaded. But being told that their state was just a stepping stone to New York was the last straw. As one, they rose up to fight for their homeland.

They didn’t have much to fight with. The federal government refused to intervene, because the Krylons’ green cards were all in order. The National Guard could help, if they could mobilize in time. Some of the state’s more militant citizens needed no encouragement to take up arms against the alien invaders. And a mad scientist in Newark (every cheesy sci-fi story needs a mad scientist) figured out how to turn pleasure boats and junk cars into impromptu spacecraft. But the aliens had big advantages in firepower and mobility.

On the plus side, the Krylons didn’t bring much of their advanced technology to bear. Their code of honor forced them to fight at the level of their intended victims, and they turned to the New Jersey media to determine what that level should be. Luckily, the Krylons’ cable TV had been cut off due to a billing error; they could only get one channel on their TV sets, and that channel was running a barbarian-movie festival that day. So the alien spaceships began disgorging their equivalents of Cossacks and Roman legions, thinking them adequate for the task of subduing the Garden State.

Boy, were they in for a shock.
categories: Humor, Modern Warfare, Print & Play, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Dead Slug
description:
In Dead Slug, players roll five six-sided dice and, if they can build certain shapes, continue to roll and accumulate points. It plays very much like many bar room dice games.

You need two+ players, five six-sided dice, and a way to keep score.

On your turn, roll all five dice. Pull aside only the highest dice rolled (including doubles), AND any ‘attached’ dice. An attached die is one that is sequenced one number lower than the high die (or dice). Ex: rolling two 6’s, a 5, and three 2’s, only the 6’s and the 5 are pulled aside. Rolling a 4 and four 1’s, only the 4 is pulled. Note that 1 has no lower attached dice (just as you can’t roll higher than a 6).

These ‘pulled’ dice occupy imaginary tiers in a ‘shape matrix’ (see completed shapes in the image section). Whatever your highest die is (or dice are), place it (or them) into the topmost tier of what will become your shape (if completed), and place any attached dice in the next tiers down. Ex: rolling a 6, two 5’s, a 2, and a 1, the 6 and the 5’s are pulled into the top two tiers (the roller is on her way to several possible shapes—Praying Mantis, Snowman, etc.).

Pick up any dice that aren’t pulled into the shape matrix and roll them again. The tier system continues, as long as the roller has thrown any ‘attached’ dice that would occupy the next lowest tier. Only the lowest filled tier is considered ‘open’ for attached dice, in that you can match the number occupying that lowest tier (in addition to rolling the next lowest number). Ex: the first roll ‘pulled’ three 5’s, which all occupy the top tier (possible shapes include Little T, Beret, Dead Slug, etc.) – the other dice (we’ll say a 2 and a 1) are picked back up and re-rolled. Second roll: another 5 and a 6 (the 6 cannot be placed above the 5 and will be re-rolled); the 5 is pulled alongside the existing 5’s (roller is on his way to a Dead Slug or a Beret). Third roll gets a 1. The roller’s turn ends and the dice are passed to the next player. Had the roller gotten another 5 or a 4, a shape would have been created and the roller would receive the appropriate points and would be ‘still rolling’.

Keep rolling, as long as at least one die can be pulled (from each subsequent roll) and played legally. Only if a shape is completed: players may decide to stop and score the points for the shape, OR roll all five dice again, continuing to accumulate points. If a player ever decides to keep rolling and is unable to complete a shape in subsequent rolls, that player ‘bombs out’ and scores zero points. A player must accumulate at least 2,000 consecutive points before ‘being on the board’ for the first time only. Once players are on the board, they may choose to score anytime they complete a shape.

To win: score 10,000 points. Longer game? Score to 20,000, etc.

Variation: For a slightly longer (but more exciting) game, have the Black Widow and the Skull take away 800 points apiece, BUT only if they are rolled completely on the first roll (they can still be ‘built’ for positive points). Have fun!

name: Risky Mgax
description:
CCG published in Spain and designed for a popular kids TV show called "Club Megatrix".

This game consist in drawing cards from a deck. This cards represents different tests where you have to complete an embarrassing task (atrevimiento/dare to, yellow cards) or tell a secret about you (verdad/true , blue cards). Each card scores different points based on the difficulty of the test.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Card Game, Collectible Components, Humor, Party Game

name: Colledge
description: Colledge is a drinking/party board game for coed players, aged 21 and over (due to adult themes and alcohol). The object of the game is to reach the top of the board and graduate from college first. When players land on certain squares, they must draw cards, collect money, or make rules that must be followed by the other players. "Spell cards" require players to do such things as have phone sex, fake an orgasm, and spend time in a closet with another player. "Challenge cards" involve activities such as trivia questions, arithmetic, playing quarters, arm wrestling, and drinking. According to the Justintime website, Colledge gets players "laughing, drinking and hooking up."

name: Steam  and Steel: Expansion Set 1
description:
Expansion of the Steam and Steel system to allow up to 8 player or additional counter for 4 players. Also has a few new units, battle board and rules on elite units. Requires the original game

Contains
Rules sheet
Battle board
4 sheets of counters
Extra money

Expands:

Steam and Steel
categories: Economic, Expansion for Base-game, Nautical, Wargame

name: Gunfir(E)
description:
The Generically-Useful Naval Force Interaction Rules (Easy) is a naval war game for people who like their games simple, or for people who want to fight big naval battles without getting bogged down in details. The era is the first half of the 20th century.

GUNFIR(E) assumes you have some of my All the Ships counters, or a set of 1:6000 naval miniatures. You'll also need maps, as described under "Setting Up a Battle." All you provide is one 20-sided and two 6-sided dice.
categories: Modern Warfare, Nautical, Wargame, World War II

name: Tax Evasion
description: Players go around the board 12 times making investments, finding (and buying or selling) tax loopholes, shunting funds off to their Swiss Bank Accounts, and - of course - paying taxes. At the end of the game each player fills out a final Tax Form. The player with the greatest Net Worth is the winner.
mechanics: Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Weerwijzer
description: It is a quiz. Who Knows the Most of the weather and has the right answers to the difficult questions.

name: Battlegammon
description:
From the website:
"Your fleet has just deployed out of N-Space™ into enemy territory, only to find they are outmaneuvered! Dogfight back to your Home Quadrant, and then count off into your Mothership before they get 'Gammon you! You can play with the standard ships below, OR you can use any of the ships offered for my Trekkers:Genocide ™ game."

The set includes a 3/8" thick by 16" round board, 2 Fleets of 15 pewter cast ships, Rules, 2 dice, and a cloth bag.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Ancient, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction, Space Exploration

name: Sound Effects
description:
Sound Effects

The CD guessing game

What is the sound of one hand clapping? That's one sound you won't be asked to identify while playing Sound Effects, a fun new game that has the whole family listening! You will, however, be required to identify 80 other sounds, including the sound of someone brushing their teeth, a skill saw, a pinball machine, a tree falling or a mosquito...after listening for only a few seconds. Fun for anyone aged 4 to 104, Sound Effects can be played at any level. Players determine beforehand the level of difficulty (the tracks get progressively hard to identify) and how long they'll get to hear the sound before they must write their answer down. Mix it up by hitting random play on your CD player or take it with you in the car.

Includes a CD of more than 80 sound effects, pencils and score pads.
Ages 4 and up, 2+ players

name: Prof. Wacky's Wahoo Word Lab
description:
From the Publisher:

Phonics strategies for building words are presented with the fun and engaging Professor Wacky. Players practice making words using onsets (word beginnings) and rimes (word endings). Seven different games accommodate varying skill levels.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Educational, Word Game

name: Frog Pond Fractions Game
description:
From the Publisher:

Croak the frog teaches the beginning concepts of fractions, the relationship of parts to wholes. Game promotes quick play and offers hands-on learning with squeezable, solid foam fraction pieces. Multiple skill levels can play together and game adapts as skills progress.

name: Let's Go Shopping Game
description:
From the Publisher:

Kids learn smart consumerism at the shopping mall as they practice addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division. Fun-filled game builds money math skills and involves all players at every turn. Two versions to challenge multiple skill levels.

name: Prof. Wacky's Neon Number Flash Game
description:
From the Publisher:

Learn number sense through fun, strategic play. Versatile cards build math skills including reading and writing numbers, multiplication and division, finding prime and composite numbers, and more! Ten different games encourage collaboration and strategizing, and adapt to varying skill levels.

name: The Iguana Factor Multiplication Game
description:
From the Publisher:

Leaping Lizards! What a great way to master multiplication tables! Friendly iguanas watch every move as kids use multiplication facts to reach their goal. Bumping and capturing moves make this game even more fun.
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Educational, Math, Number

name: Connexxions
description:
Connexxions is a game where you must move your pieces to capture areas of the board. The game allows you to unsettle other captured areas by supplanting their pieces with your own.
The game encourages you to change to rules to increase difficulty and extend play time.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Enclosure, Point to Point Movement

name: The Wizard of Menlo Park
description:
From the publisher:
"The Wizard of Menlo Park turns you into one of Thomas Edison’s enthusiastic but overworked assistants. Help Edison develop, test, and assemble the incandescent light and the electrical system that would revolutionize the world. Can you help Edison to achieve the seemingly impossible before New Year’s Eve 1879?"

name: Trekkers: Genocide
description:
This is a "futuristic checkers" style of game, and you even get spaceships based upon very familiar themes, shows, or genres that are very easy to recognize. The acrylic gameboard is 3-sided with triangular areas depicted upon this allowing for a third player to be introduced if so desired. You also get to choose which two kinds of spaceships you'd like for this, from a selection of over a dozen available types.

In the box:
Acrylic gameboard
Rules
2-sets of metal-cast polished pewter spaceships
A cloth storage bag for those pieces

You have to order an additional set of the spaceships if you want to play a 3-Player game.

name: The Self-Esteem Game
description: Play the game that builds, boosts and bolsters Self-Esteem! You'll start your journey under a cloud in Mopesville and make your way toward feeling good good good about yourself! You'll get brainwashed with positive affirmations and learn to cope with problems along the way. Whether or not you're the first to finish, you'll get a lot of out of playing The Game Where Everybody's a Winner!

name: Math Around The Home
description:
From the Publishers:

Introduce problem solving challenges that occur in everyday life around the home. Math drill includes basic addition and subtraction of time, temperature, money, metrics, and liquid measurement. For example: Large eggs weigh about two ounces. How many ounces will one dozen eggs weigh?

name: Travel Math
description:
From the Publisher:

Players will have fun with this problem solving activity as they encounter real-life situations that happen on trips. For example: calculating miles per gallon, hours on the road, and costs incurred during a trip.

name: Primary Place Value Chase
description:
From the Publisher:

Here's a great, competitive, fun-filled game. Each player chooses a colored pawn and follows the track around the board by spinning and moving to a specific number in either the ones, tens, or hundreds place. The winner is decided by the first player who makes it once around the board and follows their colored alley to the center of the board.

name: Bank Account
description:
From the Publisher:

Can you balance your checking account? Players learn a variety of processes involved in having a checking account. As they play around the gameboard, they write checks, make deposits, and keep accurate records. Real-life transactions include buying groceries, paying taxes, making car payments and paying medical bills. Checks, deposit slips, and currency from $1 to $100 are included.

name: Championship Basketball
description:
From the Publisher:

Two teams or players use basic addition facts to play this basketball simulation game. Using basketball terms such as "steal the ball" and "shoot from the key" , 18 different plays make this a great game for sports enthusiasts of all ages.

name: Dino-Czars
description:
Back in the days when the great plains were ruled by dinosaurs, the local Tyrannosaurus came to you and your dinosaur friends with a proposition you couldn't refuse: help eliminate the neighboring Tyrannosaurus to open up a new food supply, and you and your friends won't get eaten. Your brain is the size of a walnut, so this 'not getting eaten' bit sounded like a pretty good idea. Little did you realize that the neighboring Tyrannosaurus had the same idea. Who will be the next Dino-Czar?

Dino-Czars is a shogi-like game where the object is to capture the opposing Tyrannosaurus. Up to two captured pieces can re-spawn by hatching eggs, but gestation takes time and causes a player to lose tempo. A computer version is available for the Zillions of Games engine.

name: Chu Han War BC 206-203
description: This is a Japanese DTP wargame on warfare in ancient China.

name: The Siege of Osaka, Summer campaign
description:
Tactical game on the final siege of Castle Osaka.
Title is taken from one of Japanese folk hero "Yukimura Sanada".
He led the small special selected warriors into the horde of Tokugawa army and tried to kill the Tokugawa Ieyasu himself!

Published by Bandai.

name: Decimeter Game
description:
Appropriate for Grades 6-10

This game teaches the commonly used units of the metric system with questions involving everyday shopping situations. It also gives practice in simple math.

Players move around a colorful board which presents and reinforces the concepts. There are separate decks of question cards which allow beginning and advanced players to participate together.

Game Includes: game board, dice, 60 centimeter cubes, question cards and chance cards for both beginning and advanced players, instructions, and an answer key.
categories: Children's Game, Economic, Educational, Math, Number

name: Princess's Court
description: A Japanese card game. The game consists of 110 regular playing card sized cards and a one-page rules sheet in Japanese. The game is similar in play to Uno. Each player plays one card in turn, matching against the last card played in color or value, or drawing a card if not able to do so. The first player to go out scores 0 points for the round, with the remaining players scoring points for the cards remaining in their hands. The game is played in a series of rounds until one player has scored 500 or more points. When that happens, the player with the lowest number of points wins. If a player happens to score exactly 500 points, his score is halved to 250.

name: Mestieri
description:
Mestieri (The Game of Trades) is an Italian card-game using a non-standard deck of 52 cards for 2 or 4 players. The cards are divided into 4 suits, each suit representing a trade: Mechanic, Bricklayer, Farmer or Carpenter. The cards within each suit do not have ranks and display tools or supplies that trade would use. For example, the Farmer cards include seed, a tractor and a scythe. Some cards belong to more than one suit (e.g. the bucket belongs to both the Bricklayer and Farmer suits). In addition, there is a fifth suit, labeled with a 'T'. These cards bear generic goodies like money, Industry, a first aid box and a 'Good Luck' card.

At the start of the game, each player receives a card specifying his trade for that hand. The object is to collect as many cards as you can that belong to your trade. At each turn, you pick one card from the previous player's unused cards. If it belongs to your suit, you add it to your sequence. Otherwise, it joins your unused cards which you then offer to the next player, who will pick a card, and so on. 'T' cards are wild cards that you can add to your sequence. There are three 'T' cards with a '?' on them and the words 'dillo tu' (name me). You can only add these cards to your sequence if you can name a tool/object that fits with your trade and is not already used in the game. The 'Good Luck' card has the power of negating an unused card in your hand - if you have the 'Good Luck' card and only one unused card, you can end the game immediately.

The game ends when any player runs out of unused cards. Unused cards count as penalties (I assume this means they subtract one from the length of your sequence). The winner of the game is the player with the longest sequence of cards bearing objects of their trade.

name: Napoleonic Period 5mm Wargames Rules
description:
A 42 page rulebook that covers the Napoleonic era in 5mm (1:300 scale). In particular the rules address aspects such as command structure and battlefield concentration that is impossible to cover in larger scale.

The rulebook is divided into three sections, namely (1) the definition of units and organization of armies; (2) the actual rules and (3) campaign rules.

A second booklet covering army lists have been released complementing the rules. The armies covered includes the French, British, Austrian, Prussian, Russian, Spanish and Swedes.

name: Black Belt: The Karate Game
description:
From the instruction manual:

"Become a master of the ancient Martial Art of Karate. Use wit, skill, and luck to battle your opponents as you progress from white-belted novice to Black Belt of the eighth degree!"

The game is actually played with the use of cards depicting different karate maneuvers (attack and defense) and generic kung-fu weapons (like sai and nuchukus). Players turn cards over, and a rock-paper-scissors effect determines the winner. The players advance around the board, challenging each other and winning belts until they can advance to the Master Sparring Circle, where they must defeat two opponents at the same time to become the true Black Belt Champion!

From the black-and-white cards that feature only the names of the moves they represent, to the 4-color gameboard covered in Yin-Yang symbols, to the box cover featuring two Karate Black Belt Masters fighting in silhouette against the backdrop of a setting sun, this apparently self-published item (Jim Co.?) is really not much fun as a game, but worth a few chuckles as a curiosity.
mechanics: Hand Management, Rock-Paper-Scissors, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Chem Trak
description:
Chem-Trak™ can be used by individual students or groups.

A student can play five different games to learn element names and symbols, ion names and symbols, formulas for compounds, and equations for reactions. The games range from timed races to error elimination.

The game board has a chart of 552 compounds on the back. Developed by Bob Gang. Grades 10–11.

name: Fire! Fire!
description:
FIRE! FIRE! - Learn to Survive Board Game.

From the box:
"Children are probably some of the most vulnerable members of society when confronted by fire. By playing this game they will learn how to prevent, avoid and survive a fire. It is an ideal family game to help parents teach their children about the dangers of fire."

Devised by a professional firefighter of 37 Years experience with the Leicestershire Fire and Rescue Service and with the help of Fire Prevention Officers part of the proceeds from the sale of this game goes to the Fire Service Benevolent Fund.

Players have two playing pieces each - one for movement on the board, the other to indicate progress up a "ladder".

It is a simple roll and move game with actions being dependent on where the playing piece lands on the board. Options are:
- Roll again
- Move the other firefighter one rung up the "ladder"
- Answer a question(from a pack of 132 cards on fire and fire safety). A correctly answered question will allow the 2nd firefighter to advance up the ladder.

The winner is the first player to get their first Firefighter to cross the board to his destination and return to the Fire Station (start) AND have their 2nd Firefighter climb the 12 rungs on his ladder.

name: The Evolution Game
description: From the designer's web site: The Evolution Game is a board game for two, three or four players, which was inspired by the concept of biological evolution. During the course of the game, your species will compete for territory with other species. As the environmental conditions change, it will face plagues, endemic disease, starvation, natural disasters and global catastrophes and may even succumb to total extinction. It will take advantage of mutation within its gene pool to establish itself in a series of ecological niches, thereby surviving through the successive stages of the geological sequence from the Precambrian (the dawn of life) to the Pleistocene (i.e. the present day).

name: Haggle
description:
Haggle is a simple trading game involving ideas (represented by light bulbs), girls (actually women, but this is from 1970, after all), connections (represented by printed circuits), time pieces, and rhinoceroses.

Each player gets five of each of these items, five value cards, and a rubber band. By arranging the cards with the rubber band passing through the appropriate notches each item is given a secret personal value from one to fifty cents. Then everyone trades - trading is completely free-form, with no turns and no restrictions on deals. When no one wants to trade any longer, the game ends and players add up the value of the items they have.

While there is no credit for a game designer, the graphic design is credited to Don Moyer, who since then appears to have become prominent in the world of graphic and industrial design.

name: Humps & Horns Rodeo Board Game
description: A simple roll and move game in which players travel around the board paying to enter in bull riding events in different cities. Dice are rolled to determine how long players were able to stay on the bull and money is awarded in increasing amounts depending on the length of their time. If anything lower than 7 is rolled a Hung and Dragged or Bucked Off card is drawn with various penalties against the victim. Play continues until only one player has money left.

name: Mr. Cadbury's Parrot Game
description:
From the box:

Balance Mr. Cadbury's Parrot in the tree, then take turns placing marbles in his nest. The nest will get heavier and heavier until ...it falls.

But watch out, not all marbles are the same size.

Lots of fun for all the family.

NB: this game does not contain confectionery.

(But it should - we use Cadbury's mini eggs!)

name: Buzzball
description: Buzzball is a two-person game, each person choosing a squad of four players from an actual baseball game. The last player on the squad is chosen for you by your opponent. This player is called the "Bum". Your opponent will try to pick the worst player for you. The players earn points during the baseball game based on their performances in seven scoring categories. Points are deducted for errors. The winner is the owner whose squad scores the most points. (description from the package)

name: Plaza
description: PLAZA is played with a five-suited pack of 60 cards, the suits being distinguished from each other by color (each color also has a little picture of an animal to help distinguish suits), the cards run from one to twelve in each color. A game turn consists of Draw, Play, Discard. Similar colored cards are placed in a row and similar numbered cards are placed in a column, eventually forming a card grid. The winner is the first player to run out of cards. This game was original enough at the time to get a US Patent (#952939)

name: Country Music Trivia
description:
Players take turns answering questions about Country Music. If the question is answered correctly, the player gets to circle a "band hat" on his scoresheet to indicate he has answered the question, and is asked another question. If player does not answer the question correctly, play passes to the left.

Scoring is done by constructing a "band". Different questions allow a player to recruit different band members. To win, a player must have a band worth 15 points or more, and this band must include one Lead Singer.

name: Tipped Tacs
description:
From the Crosstown Games website:

Tipped Tacs is a game of tic-tac-toe using die faces as the instrument of victory. The die are not placed individually on the grid as in normal tic-tac-toe, but 'tipped' based on strategy. A die has only one valid direction to tip each turn, so deciding which die to tip and when… that is the key to master.

Number of Players: 2
Playing Time: 5 - 15 minutes

Download here:
http://www.geocities.com/crosstowngames/tippedtacs.html

name: Turn-Tac-Toe
description: Turn-Tac-Toe has 4 moving TIC-TAC-TOE boards. The object is the same as TIC-TAC-TOE: to align 3 pins of the same color in a row - horizontally, diagonally, or vertically. It can be played by partners and when done so each partner set plays one color while the other plays the other color. play moves clockwise. As soon as the partnership lines up a row of three of their color before or after the board rotates, that team has won. The key aspect is the boards rotate; thus realigning the colored rows in a predictable way. Adds a slight more depth to this ho-hum classic...

name: Thinking in Circles
description:
From the Invisible City Productions website:

A game of intuition and second-guessing for two players.

Object: To set three adjacent circles to your color, or to get three adjacent circles to match your secret shape sequence. You do this by outguessing what your opponent will play.

Each player writes down a sequence of three shapes. The only valid shapes are circle, triangle, square, and pentagon. On each player's turn, the player picks a circle to adjust. The player secretly picks a number of beads and put them in his hand. His opponent does likewise. Every white bead counts for one point. Every black bead counts for one negative point.

Reveal your beads simultaneously and add them up. This will give you a number from -6 to +6. Move the token in your chosen circle that many steps clockwise (for positive numbers) or counterclockwise (for negative numbers). If your total balanced out to zero, the token does not move.

If tokens in three adjacent circles are resting on shapes that match the player's goal, then he wins. Note that the order must match also. If his goal is circle, square, pentagon then tokens resting on circle, pentagon, square don’t count. The sequence may be read forward or backward; square, square, circle is the same as circle, square, square. The current player also wins if tokens in three adjacent circles are resting on spaces that match his color.

Rules and the board can be downloaded here:
http://www.invisible-city.com/play/46/thinking-in-circles

name: Pitter Pattern
description:
From the Invisible City Productions website:

Pattern placement and deduction for two to four players.

Object: Place tokens on a board to match patterns on your card or (even better) on your opponent’s card.

Give each player one pattern card. You may look at your pattern card, but keep it secret. On your turn, you get to roll and fill. Roll: (This step is optional, except that you must roll if the previous player filled a blank space.) Roll the die. Fill: Put a piece in a vacant space that shows the same number as the die. If there are no available moves, you may put a piece in a vacant blank space. If there is no vacant blank space to fill, then roll again. Play passes to the left. The game ends when all spaces are filled. When the game ends, you must reveal your pattern card.

Winning: Starting with the last player, each player takes turns 'lifting' (removing) one sequence of his or her tokens that matches one of the following conditions:

* If you lift your pattern, you get 4 points.
* If you lift a straight line of 4, you get 5 points.
* If you lift the pattern of the player to your left or right, you get 6 points.

Once all available patterns have been lifted, the player with the most points wins.

Rules, cards, and an optional board (a set of double-six dominoes can be used instead) are available here:
http://www.invisible-city.com/play/51/pitter-pattern

name: Quadruple Agent
description:
From the Invisible City Productions website:

A game of espionage gone horribly awry for 4 players.

Object: To guide a hopelessly befuddled secret agent back to your territory.

There is no 'first player'; play is roughly simultaneous. A round of play has the following steps:

1. Allocate Resources.
2. Reveal Allocations.
3. Prepare Transmission.
4. Broadcast Order & Receive Orders.
5. Execute Orders.
6. Debriefing.

Using these steps, along with order and command chits, you try to lure the confused secret agent to your side of the board.

The first player with 5 points wins.

Rules and game-specific pieces are available here:
http://www.invisible-city.com/play/90/quadruple-agent

name: Snuffy Smith's Hootin Holler Bug Derby
description: Everyone's favorite childhood redneck is having a race. A bug race! Spin the dial and slide your bugs along the track. Watch out for the occasional hazard that will slow you up or send you back. Intended for children - many years ago.
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Racing

name: Davy Crockett Rescue Race
description:
The board consists of a grid depicting four forts in each corner of the board, trails, deserts, mountains, rivers, and a single color square for each of the four players.

Contents:

board
4 1.5" tall Davy Crockett
playing pieces
spinner
compass
24 game supply cards
Instructions on box lid

The spinner depicts cardinal directions and dictates the direction of movement. Players try to direct their figurines to the appropriate fort while using the correct supply cards for the terrain they must cross.
categories: American West, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Racing

name: Spe-Dem Auto Race Game
description:
The SPE-DEM AUTO RACE GAME was manufactured by All-Fair Games (Alderman, Fairchild Co., Rochester, NY) and dated on the board as patented in 1922. The game consists of two (2) folding game boards, each measuring 17" by 17 1/2" when open. One is the OROTECH AUTO RACE board, and the other is the SPE-DEM. Six cast metal cars, each measuring 1 3/4" long by 1/2" wide and standing 5/8" tall (Buick, Ford, Paige, Maxwell, Dodge and Saxon) are included, as well as a cardboard shaker and six wooden dice that have the six letters that stand for the cars (B, F, P, M, D, S) that along with the cars fit in a small utensils box. Directions are on inside of the box lid.

The game is basically a roll-and move horse-racing type game. There are several squares on the playing track marked "Accident" which, when landed upon, cause that car to have to restart the race. The "Blow-out" squares cause the cars to stall for one turn. First car across the finish line wins.
publishers: All-Fair Toys and Games (Alderman-Fairchild Co.), E. E. Fairchild Corporation

name: France Quiz
description: In France Quiz you have 400 cards with 2400 questions from six categories : Miscellaneous, History, Sport, Culture, Nature and Geography. Most questions concern Latvia. Collect a token from each category to win. The players roll a die to move and then they must answer a question from the category they land on. If they answer correctly they get a token and when they've gathered tokens in every colour, they can head to the capital (center). First they need to get to a corner of the board where they answer a question of their own choosing. Then there are two coloured spaces from the corner to the center. When the players get to the center they answer a question of the other player(s) choosing. A correct answer in the center means victory!

name: Goethe
description: A limited run card game based on the life of the German poet Goethe.

name: Xenocide
description:
From the website:

Xenocide is a sci-fi skirmish level miniature wargame. I will make it open to any miniatures. It is entirely d10 based, and you ought to get at least 10 of them.
publishers: (Web published), Micro Revelations, Inc, Thane's Games

name: Filmigame
description:
The FILMIGAME is a new and exciting form of Bollywood based
entertainment. It is an interactive DVD trivia game that
gives players a chance to test their knowledge on movies,
songs, stars, dances and dialogs from Bollywood movies.

There are Four categories of question:
LIGHTS - All about the stars of the movie, Heroes & Heroines, Villains & Vamps

CAMERA - Behind the scenes, Producers & Directors, Sets & Locations

ACTION - What it's all about, Scripts & Dialogues, Songs & Dances

IT'S A WRAP - Everything Else, from Production to Promotion
You must select the category that you rolled and simply answer the question that follows. A player can press THE FILMIGAME Buzzer to challenge their opponents answer and steal the turn. The first one to collect 3 points in all four categories and then successfully answer the box office speed round wins.
categories: Electronic, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game, Trivia

name: Flying Fortress
description:
Two of the "Test Series" games released by Poultron Press, the forerunner of SPI. Flying Fortress was Test Series Game 2 and Flying Fortress II was Test Series Game 10. The games covered the Allied strategic bombing in Europe during World War II.

The games covered both US and British bombing efforts. Planes include B-17s, B-24s, Lancasters, and Halifaxes. (B-29s are in the optional rules.)

The games were reportedly the first to use hidden victory conditions (the "nidden victory points" mechanism is the closest available equivalent). Flying Fortress II may have been the first game with double-sided counters (the back used for step reduction).

Each turn in the game was a separate "tactical mission" game representing a month of real time. These turns were linked together to make a campaign. The mission game rules were divided into basic, standard, and advanced levels.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Wargame, World War II

name: Arena: Gladiatorial Combat in Ancient Rome
description: "Re-stage the bloody Roman tournaments where Gladiators, condemned criminals, Christians, and wild animals fought to the death. Although the game is played on hex paper, no counters or figures are provided."
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Events, Grid Movement, Hexagon Grid, Movement Points, Paper-and-Pencil, Player Elimination, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Simulation, Variable Player Powers
publishers: Adversary Games, Adversary Products, Richard R. Sartore & Associates

name: Zig Zag
description:
The rules:
"How to play Zig Zag: a game of skill for 2 players

Object
To be first to capture all your opponent's pieces.

Preparations
Issue 4 light pegs to yourself and four dark to your opponent. Place the pegs on the board on the line nearest your recess or pocket.
Toss or draw for first turn. Alternate thereafter.

The Play
1. Move any one of your own pegs at each turn into one, two or three adjacent holes at your discretion provided that:
(a) each hole moved into is in the direction indicated by the arrow surrounding each hole moved out of
(b) intermediate holes, if any, are vacant
(c) the hole your turn ends in is either vacant or occupied by an opposing peg which is removed from the board.
2. Continue to move any one own peg in this way at each turn until only one player has a peg or pegs still in play and wins the game.

Copyright 1983 David Smith and Associates. Christchurch, New Zealand.

Other board games in the Quest series are: Mini Halma, Helter Skelter, Tac Tix, Draughts/Checkers, Nine Men's Morris, Mini Ludo."

From the box:

"Handcrafted in solid native hardwood (rimu) by the IQ Company of New Zealand.

Quest 14 Ryan Place, Manukau City, New Zealand"

This board game in the Quest series of the IQ Company of New Zealand is a simple abstract game made as a nice heavy wooden board with wooden pegs for pieces. The board shows a 4X4 grid of holes for the peg pieces. Each hole is surrounded by an outline of an arrow; two of the holes are surrounded by an outline showing arrows pointing in two directions. At each end of the board is a felt-lined depression to hold captured pieces.

It's not clear if the David Smith in the copyright line for the game is the same David Smith of other games in the BGG database.

This is not the same game as the Zig Zag published by Editrice Giochi, also included in the BGG database.

name: Playas & Haters
description:
The publishers call this collectible card game "da first and only game for the hip-hop generation." The unrated version of the game contains references to profanity, violence and drug use.

Each player builds a deck of fifty cards. No more than two of the same type of card in each deck. The decks are shuffled separately and each player (excuse me, playa) maintains a hand of five cards. Players alternate taking turns by drawing a card from one's own deck and playing cards on one's self or on the opponent where determined advantageous.

Victory points are gained and loss through card play. (Go to jail: gain six points, read a book: lose three points.) If your score drops below negative ten points you have automatically lost. If your score gets to twenty you have automatically won. The player with the most points when both players have gone through their decks is the winner.
categories: Card Game, Collectible Components, Humor, Music

name: Mini-Games: Football
description:
Mini-Games: Football is part of the Package Creators Mini-Games line. It includes a pocket sized box containing 54 cards, a magnetic football field and magnetic tokens for keeping the state of the game. The 54 cards are broken up into 27 Offensive and 27 Defensive cards.

The players each receive a hand of random cards with the offensive player playing a card and the defensive player either trying to counter it or discard a card. Whether the play is countered or not the winning card's instructions are followed. The players then move the tokens on the magnetic board to keep track of the down, line of scrimmage and distance to the next down.

An example offensive card is "DRAW PLAY - 10 Yard Gain" with it's counter defensive card "DRAW PLAY - 10 Yard Loss". If the offensive card is not countered then the ball moves 10 yards, otherwise it moves back 10 yards.
There are also cards for intercepting, fumbling, field goals, field goal block and punting.

Essentially it's a derivative of Snap with state and a few special cards thrown in.

name: Liaisons
description:
LIAISONS - A game of imagination, mime and detection.

Every player is dealt one "Boy" and one "Girl" Personality Card and imagines that, unknown to everyone else, the couple are involved in a secret liaison.

Each player is dealt one boy and one girl from the decks of cards and invents a situation as to how the liaison (between, for example, Captain Kirk and Madonna) began. This introductory story must contain some clue to one or the other (or both) of the liaising personalities, but not be so vague as to be meaningless. Successive questioning through the game must contain additional clues. Any information provided is recorded by all the other players on "Probe Sheets".

The "Probe Sheets" contain a list of permitted questions (e.g. "What did he first say to her") that may be asked during the course of the game. The questions that may be asked are determined by the movement of playing pieces on the board, which comprises three concentric rings.

Additional information may also be gained through the use of Chance cards or "Acting Up" - in which players are required to act as another celebrity, but in the style of either the boy or the girl of their liaising couple.

On certain squares it is permitted to attempt to guess the names of the liaising couple for one of your opponents - this is done in secret by writing on a scrap of paper. The challenged opponent will then award markers for correctly guessed personalities.

The first player to unmask all the liaisons of all of his or her opponents is the winner.

name: Dancing Mice
description:
A PDF print and play game inspired by daVinci's game Dancing Dice.

In this new game you play your dancing mice in the dance floor, trying to build the patterns shown on the choreography tiles.

The game materials are:

A dance floor (a 6x6 squared board)
36 dancing mice in four colors
32 choreography tiles
4 player boards
rules (Italian only)


You can download the game from www.arima.it

Home Page: http://www.arima.it/giochi/catalog/product_info.php?products...

name: The Piggeries
description:
The Piggeries game is played by each player gently pulling a string on the back of their respective pig to advance it toward the center of the game, which represents a well. Players can place bets using the enclosed game counters. There are four wooden pegged tracks, four hand painted wooden pigs, a "well" for bets, and a cardboard roof for the well.

The description of the game that appears on the inside of the box lid:

"As many persons can take part, as there are pigs in this extremely interesting and amusing game, which holds the players and onlookers spellbound with excitement, from beginning to end.

"The game is set up, as seen on the picture. The players then deposit money or counters in the pool."

"The pigs are placed, with their hind legs on the lowest step of the planks. At a given signal they proceed, step by step, up the plank, by the aid of the string, which the players must pull lightly. If the string is pulled too hard or violently the pig will tumble and fall from the plank, which necessitates going back to the starting point, thus rendering the game very exciting and making the fun fast and furious."

"At first many of these 'accidents' will happen, but with a little more practice, the player becomes adept and the pigs make splendid progress. The player, whose pig arrives at the trough first, is declared winner and accordingly takes the stakes. Throughout the game the pigs must not be touched by the hand."

No year or publisher is on the box...

name: Open Card Game
description:
Open Card Game is actually a collection of games (the exact number is unclear) which all use the common mechanic of placing playing cards on a board and moving them.

There are three different custom card decks used and three different boards as well. The mechanics for the various games involve standard card game mechanics such as higher ranks beating lower ranks, trumping, etc.

name: Open Dominoes Game
description: The Open Dominoes Game is actually a collection of games all played with dominoes on a board. There are at least three custom domino sets used in the games, which share the common feature of having arrows to control their orientation, and several different boards.

name: The 1 Game
description:
An abstract strategy game for two players involving a triangular (equilateral) board that has positions for 36 balls, or marbles. i.e., one row each of 1, 2, 3, ... and 8 balls. The game contains 42 silver balls, 8 blue balls and 1 red ball, but only 36 of these are used in each game. A cleverly designed box/board with sliding panel makes setup a breeze as well as randomizing the initial set up.

Players take turns removing any number of consecutive balls along a single horizontal line, as long is there is no gap or red ball between them. The removed balls are discarded into the large hole and underneath the slider, which stops them going astray and gets them ready for the next game. The red ball can only be taken on its own. Any row containing red can only be taken up to the red. A blue ball allows players to take up to, or part of, three entire rows radiating from that blue. Other blues in the path are treated as regular silver balls. The player with the last ball loses.

name: The Wizard of Oz
description:
Dorothy, The Cowardly Lion, Rusty, the Tin Man and Socrates, the Scarecrow travel by way of the yellow brick road to the Emerald City seeking Kansas, Courage, Heart and a Brain.

A simple race game that was published in the early 60's. The game is based on the story of The Wizard Of Oz.

The components include 1 board, 4 character cards, 4 goal cards, 4 colored pawns and 1 die.

Players start in different spots, but at the same distance from the goal. Movement is dictated by a single dice throw. The first player to reach the goal and collect the correct card wins.
mechanics: Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Boom 'n Bust
description:
From the rulebook: Boom 'n Bust is a Financial Markets Game that is not only challenging and competitive but educational to those not familiar with the various financial markets. A glossary is provided to define and explain terminology commonly used in those markets.

Beginning at the Start position, advances around the board are determined by a throw of the dice. The landing position determines the players action.

While "there's a lot going on" in the game, understanding the basics comes rapidly as play progresses. Skill in trading, and the selection, timing and amount of share purchases are major factors in playing Boom 'n Bust successfully.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Stock Holding

name: Cross Purposes
description:
From the rules: Cross Purposes is a game of strategy for two players.

You start a game of Cross Purposes with five trains at your House. Your goal is to get all five trains across the board to your Station, and then to get them all back Home. The train tracks might not run from your Home to your Station, but you can switch the tracks so that they will point where you want your trains to go. Sound simple? It is, except that your opponent has a Home and a Station too, and is trying to run trains on the same tracks. Your opponent will be turning the switches so that the paths run in a different direction. This is why you and your opponent are always at Cross Purposes!

name: Round Bout
description:
According to Sid Sacksons "A Gamut of Games":

On a circular board, an attacker with seven pieces attempts to reach the center against a defender with four pieces. Capture is by jumping.

name: Ready or Not
description:
4 delightful games, all packaged in box and played on a unique plastic platform with interchangeable playing pieces.

All the games are based on classic outdoor games like Hide and Seek, Tag, Hot Or Cold and Leap Frog. Each time you play "Ready or Not" you will experience the thrill of these outdoor games...right indoors!

(from the rules)

name: Reddy Clown 3-Ring Circus Game
description: A simple roll-and-move game with a circus theme. Try to reach the middle ring of the circus while collecting all of the appropriate pieces.

name: Treckers
description:
2 or 3 players play on a six-sided board, moving their twelve pieces from their Base Line toward their King Row. The object is the same as checkers: to eliminate the playing pieces of the opposing player(s) by jumping or cornering them.

Treckers comes with five levels of play:

Level 1 - Players move only away from their Base Lines (not sideways or backwards) until a piece is made a King, in which case it can then move any direction.

Level 2 - Level 1 rules plus single pieces can move sideways (in addition to forward).

Level 3 - Level 1 rules plus players may jump their own pieces, thus allowing quicker movement across the board.

Level 4 - Level 3 rules plus single pieces can move sideways.

Level 5 - Players take opponents' pieces by capture, not by jumping (like in chess). Also, pieces can move one or two spaces, but two spaces only if moving toward the King Row and not sideways.

name: Crossword Bingo
description:
According to Sid Sackson's "A Gamut of Games":

Each player takes a "Bingo" card showing twenty letters. Then, working with their own letter tiles, all players attempt to form words before a timer runs out. Matching letters are moved to the card. Continue until one card is filled.

name: Chain Reaction
description:
According to Sid Sacksons "A Gamut of Games", 2nd edition (not in first), page 218:

Tiles with numbers from 1 to 15 are played to a many-hexed board. New tiles are added in numerical order, or against two or more that add up to the tile played. Letters on the other face of the tiles are for a similar word game.

name: IACTA
description:
From the web site:

IACTA is a completely new dice game for 2 players Ages 8 and up.

Many games are build on historic games or complicated rules.

IACTA is not like these games.
IACTA is simple and yet advanced.
IACTA allows skilled players to play against lesser skilled players.


Try for yourself to throw the dice and experience a fascinating game, where a combination of luck and strategy will lead you to victory."

On a 10x10 colored board, players try to move their 6 dice from one corner to the opposite one according to the result of the thrown dice. One result for the movement length (only horizontal & vertical), the other for the pips that will be shown on the moved dice at the end of the movement.

name: Colorforms Dress Up Game
description:
From the box:

"The concept is simple: spin the spinner, pick a piece, and dress up your character. Choose pretty pants, stunning shoes, or a handsome hat. There are no wrong choices, and there are countless different ways that you and your child can dress up. The first player to completely dress a character wins the game."
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Ponies: The New Forest Pony Chase Game
description:
Ponies - The New Forest Pony Chase Game

From the Box:

"Ponies", as it is popularly called in our family, was invented heres (Sway) in the New Forest in about 1985 to keep our children quiet on wet days.

Firstly we wanted an interesting game for younger children that was not contentious and would not end in arguments and tears. "Ponies" was based upon a drive in the New Forest, taking the routes to our favorite walks. Players had to collect the Ponies found on the road, and get ten back to their Corral, avoiding the usual hazards of Forest roads.

Then, finding that we adults also wanted to play, we made it more interesting with scope for an element of low adult cunning. Enter the Verderer and Game Licenses; and "Ponies" was born in its current form.

The game is ruled by the throw of dice, but the Chase Cards introduce scope for planning and strategy and generate suspense and excitement. The lucky early leader rarely wins, and the ultimate winner has to run the gauntlet of determined Verderers so that often it is the last throw of the dice which decides the victor between three or four neck and neck contenders.

My family and all our friends have been playing it ever since, both adults and children have remained addicted over the years. Bowing eventually to everyone's enthusiasm we have at last decided to go public with "Ponies": we are certain you are going to become as ardent Verderers as the rest of us!"

name: Twiggy
description: A more complete title: TWIGGY -- A Game That Makes Every Girl, Like Twiggy, The Queen of Mod; this is basically a roll and move game based around the supermodel Twiggy and the London fashion scene of the late 1960's. Roll, move, and take the effects of the cards you land on...

name: Bread
description:
According to Sid Sackson's "A Gamut of Games":

Move around the board taking cards with a suit mark or with one of four pictures. Bid for the right to turn a "bonus card" showing a combination of a suit and a picture. You collect if you hold cards that match.

name: Be Sharp or Be Flat
description:
According to Sid Sackson's "A Gamut of Games":
