Europe once more finds war thrust upon it!

name: Joltz
description:
From the directions: A lightning fast game for 2 or 3 players.
The goal is to move all three of a player's marbles around the board from base position to "home safe". Each player rolls his dice once to determine who plays first. Player rolling the highest number is first and chooses his color, placing the three marbles in "base" position. Play will proceed to the left, each player choosing his color and placing his three marbles in his "base" position. With all marbles now in "base" position, first player rolls his die. Either a one or a six must be rolled to take a marble from base to "start" location marked by single hole of the player's color. Players roll their die in turn, moving marbles which have been started the exact number of places permitted by number rolled. When a one or a six is rolled, player has choice of moving a "started" marble that number of spaces or starting a new marble. Also, the rolling of a six entitles that player to an additional turn IF he was able to use the six he just rolled. As play proceeds, a player may not pass or land on a marble of his own color. However, when a player's move lands his marble on a space occupied by another's marble, he may JOLT by replacing that marble with his own. The JOLTED player must then re-start the marble from his "base" position. Marbles are ALWAYS subject to JOLTING until in "safe home". First player with all three marbles "safe home" is winner of the game.

With that being said (or rather written), sounds like Parchesi revisited...

name: The Clairol Beauty Game
description: This is a game which promotes learning about perms and hair styling. Typical roll and move structure.

name: Decisions! Decisions!
description: This is a game/puzzle where you move slides in order to make marbles drop. There are several games; which game you play determines exactly how you win. The primary game has the winner as the person who collects the most blue marbles.

name: Progress Summit
description:
This is a very simple game. The game board depicts a mountain, which the players have to climb.

Each turn you draw a card and play a card (you don't have ANY hand cards). You move your pawn according to the card drawn. There are green cards which allow you to climb up the mountain, red cards which make you fall down and blue cards (which depict mountain climbing gear) that can safeguard you against future red cards.

In addition there are red spaces where you automatically glide down and green space where you automatically go up.

What we have here is the innovative variation on 'roll and move' called 'draw a card and move.'

name: Redneck Christmas
description:
Yee-Ho-Ho-Ho! "It's Christmas time in the hills of Kentucky, and just like every other year before, you don't have a job. You decide to clean up your rifle and go hunting for a turkey so yer family won't go another holiday season eating Spam sandwiches for the main course."

I believe this was published in the December 2000 issue of Games Unplugged Magazine. The board is printed in the magazine; you provide a few D4's and 2 pawns of the same color for each player (must be able to tell what direction your pawn is facing). The board also has a "Buzz Meter" for each player (Betty-Jo, Jim-Bob, Tex, Cousin Luke, Uncle Robert and Ma) so you can keep track of how drunk each one is.

"Objective: Everyone's pawn on the board represents a drunken hillbilly stumbling through the woods trying to land on the center square of the game board (shooting a turkey). Once you have landed on the square, you then have to move your pawn off the board (bringing the turkey home). First one to do this wins."

There are two phases per turn:

Action phase - Move (you control only distance or direction), Drink a beer (allows you to change your direction) or Sober up (decrease your level of drunkenness on your Buzz Meter). Everyone performs their action before the Shootin' phase.

Shootin' phase - Anything in each player's line of sight (turkey or hillbilly) gets shot automatically. Of course, if you are shot, you guzzle a beer to ease the pain before continuing.

You are out of the game if you get so drunk that you wander off the board. You are the winner if you are the first to shoot a turkey and bring it home OR you are the last player on the board without anyone else having gotten a turkey.

name: Gigglepants
description:
Paraphrased from the publisher:

Take turns gathering colorful shapes as you move around the gameboard. If you land on a space with the Gigglepants character, you have to actually put on a pair of pants (Gigglepants) over your own clothes before the time runs out and you get to pick a shape. Collect all six shapes and you win the game.

The game includes a large gameboard, shape cards, colored shapes, kid-friendly pawns, spinner, sand timer, and Gigglepants play pants. For 2 to 4 players. Ages 3 - 5. Gigglepants teaches children about colors, shapes, numbers and counting. The game also helps to improve motor skills and encourages social interaction. Gigglepants play pants are designed to fit most 3- to 5-year-olds up to 45 lbs.

No reading required to play.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game, Humor, Number
mechanics: Pattern Recognition, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Polemos: War of the Spanish Succession
description:
From the publisher's website:

First of the great dynastic struggles of the eighteenth century, the War of Spanish Succession involved most of Europe. A state which did not back up its policies with troops in this period probably supplied them as mercenaries to those which did.

Central to the causes of conflict were the expansionist ambitions of Louis XIV, King of France, which were opposed by a series of shifting alliances. Towering over the period is the figure of John Churchill, Duke of Marlborough, and his close ally Prince Eugene of Savoy.

This is the classic campaigning period. Each year, the armies marched across Europe is a colossal chess game on a board constricted by river barriers and studded with fortresses. These manoeuvres culminated in great set-piece battles, including Marlborough’s ‘big four’: Blenheim, Ramillies, Oudenarde and Malplaquet.

The War of Spanish Succession has much to recommend it to wargamers; uniforms were colourful (but are simple to paint.) and manoeuvres were bold and forceful. Standing armies were in their relative infancy at this time, and the period saw the founding of traditions which were to last the centuries.

Polemos War of Spanish Succession is specifically aimed at enabling the wargamer to fight large scale actions; actual battles, rather than small scale skirmishes. Systems for firing, melee and morale are straightforward and easy to learn, but allow your troops to emulate the tactics used by their historical counterparts. For instance, troops using the platoon firing system have improved close range factors, while others using fire by ranks are allowed to be more aggressive.

The basic playing piece in Polemos is the Base. An army consists of a number of bases, organised into Brigades and Commands, either to an historical model or by the use of army lists. The size of armies in this period varied enormously; in Polemos WoSS, a general’s command can be from eight to 15 bases, but an army can comprise anything from two commands upwards.

Polemos War of Spanish Succession is designed to not only give the feel of command in the period, but also to give something of the look. The actual number or composition of figures on a base is unimportant, but it should mount enough figures to make it look like a real unit of troops. The sight of your lines of steady musketeers or massed cavalry advancing across the table should fill your opponent with awe and trepidation!

name: Malaka
description:
Malaka is a cross between Backgammon, Plakoto and Lines of Action. Players race to move their pieces around the board, delaying their opponent while trying to connect their pieces to the far end of the board marked with their symbol. Using a familiar (Backgammon type) roll-and-move mechanism, each player attempts to form an orthogonally connected group of their pieces (as in Lines of Action) at the opposite corner of the board from their starting location. The board is designed with two "walls" that force the players to navigate an "S" type path to reach their goal in the opposite corner. The board consists of nine subareas, each with a basic direction of forward movement (which is, of course, opposite for the two players).

On their turn, each player rolls two dice (4-sided dice for the 9x9 board, 6-sided dice for the 12x12 board) and uses the resulting numbers to move their pieces. Pieces may either step directly forwards, or jump over a wall. If a piece steps directly forwards, then it must step in a straight line a number of spaces equal to the number of pips shown on one of the dice. If the piece steps onto a single enemy piece, then that enemy piece is pinned (as in Plakoto) until the player moves off. Players may stack as many pieces as they like onto any point, but cannot move to any point at which the enemy controls a block (a pile of two or more pieces). Alternatively, a piece may jump over a wall (ignoring the movement restrictions of the moving piece's current sub-area) if that jump lands on a single enemy piece a number of spaces away equal to the number of pips shown on one of the dice. The enemy piece is captured and removed from the game. Players cannot jump backwards and cannot cross both walls with the same jump. Jumping over a wall to capture an enemy piece is a double-edged sword: it allows the piece to push forward quickly by taking a shortcut, but also makes the opponent's task easier as they have one less piece to connect.

After making any move, the same piece may take further steps or jumps, possibly changing direction if the first move resulted in a change in sub-area. If a double is rolled, then the player moves four times using the pip value shown (as in Backgammon). The player must make a move that uses the maximum possible number of pips.

A player wins by orthogonally connecting all of their remaining pieces to the far end of the board marked with their symbol (not necessarily in a single connected group, but all pieces orthogonally connected to a piece on the goal line). A player may also win by pinning an opponent's piece on his own starting line.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: O.J.Opoly
description:
"Guilty or Innocent? You decide!"

A variant on Monopoly that is themed from the popular O.J. Simpson murder trial in the 90s.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Air Combat Trainer
description:
"The up-to-the-minute game that gives you a chance to try your skill at combat flying, using 48 exact miniatures of war planes and combat maneuvers-helps you identify planes in the sky!"

The game was actually produced in conjunction with the War Department, and is part of the "Air Youth" series of games.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Educational, Wargame, World War II

name: Rendezvous in Space
description:
In this very large game (22.5" x 32.5"), players race to explore the eight other planets within the solar system.

One unusual gimmick to this game is its use of a stack of slide transparencies (vs. regular cards) in concert with a board randomizing mechanism. Pulling a lever rotates the obstacles to movement on the board as well as pushes a transparency off the bottom of a stack into position. Movement of the transparency into place causes a small light bulb to turn on, lighting the slide and revealing the instructional text.

name: Where's Willie?
description:
A plastic house with four doors stands between the two players. One player secretly places Willie, a little man in a swimsuit holding a flower, behind one of the doors. The other player has to guess behind which door Willie resides by opening the door. If Willie is there, a little bell goes ‘ding!’ and the player scores a point. There is no penalty for a wrong guess. Players alternate roles until someone scores four points to become winner.

Where’s Willie? was an activity on the television show Shenanigans.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Eddie Arcaro's Riders Up
description:
Ten races are run. Each race will have eight horses. Each race varies in length from three to ten furlongs. Two factors handicap each horse: the odds of each number being rolled on the special dice vary with the lesser numbers being favored (“One” appears on every die while “Eight” appears on only two dice) and horses carrying less weight have an advantage over more burdened beasts.

Players place their minimum $2 bets before each race. The starting gate is placed the appropriate distance from the finish line and the horses are placed in the starting gate according to the weight they are carrying. The dice are rolled and each horse is advanced one space each time its number is rolled. Bets are paid when three horses have finished.

Advanced rules lets players own the horses and get a payoff whenever the horse wins.

The game comes packaged in a massive box that measures 25” x 14” x 3”. The gameboard folds out to become sixty inches long! The game is named after the legendary jockey who rode two Triple Crown winners.

name: Hard Times: The Money Management Game
description:
From the publisher:

Can playing a board game stop your child from making grim financial mistakes as an adult? That’s the aim of Hard Times, the money management board game for kids (and their parents) that seeks to eliminate those future financial mistakes.

Players start out with a line of credit and loop through the path any young adult might take: dinner with friends, college, finding a job, shopping for house supplies. But Hard Times lives up to its name: get fined for parking in the handicapped space, max out your credit card, and turn down a job only to be faced with a hospital bill? Real life hurdles lurk.

Players compete to build personal wealth. The first player to be gainfully employed, purchase and furnish a home, buy a car, and – here’s the tricky part – end up debt free, wins the game.

name: Dragons & Danes
description:
A game (supposedly) reminiscent of Viking games of old, this game was first available in museums with the "Vikings: The North Atlantic Saga" traveling exhibit.

From the publisher's web site (edited):

Dragons & Danes is an exciting new "Combat" style game that uses our unique "Throwing Disks" that will either score you points or enter you into a "Battle" mode. You may find yourself in the middle of a "War," fighting a "Skirmish," "Ambushing" your enemy or find yourself saying "OH NO!" as your "Ambush" backfires in your FACE!
On each turn you either win or lose pieces of treasure from your treasure hoard. Of course everyone knows, "He who getteth the most treasure WINS!"

Dragons & Danes is hand-crafted in our studios. Each game set gets hand-assembled by our in-house game-crafters. The same pair of hands sees each game through from start to finish.

Each set of Dragons & Danes includes:
1 set of 5 hand-crafted "Throwing Disks"
1 custom made carry-anywhere pouch
1 booklet with complete game rules
30 jewel colored "Treasure Horde" pieces

name: Affection
description:
Affection is a set of cards with various images and words on them. Each of these represents a fuzzy concept related to feelings, life experiences, relationships, communication, sexuality, needs or problems.

For example: flirt, cosmic scream, fear, I want to make you happy, penetration, body memory, triggering, sharing things , massage, too much, submissive/dominant, feminine, intense/casual, control, family issues, etc.

A number of different games are possible with the deck, ranging to Apples and Apples type games to free association games, from Tarot-style divination to educational or storytelling games.

The deck is an amazing creative tool that inspires to share thoughts, experiences and communicate.
categories: Educational, Humor, Mature / Adult, Party Game

name: Verbosus
description:
From the game instructions;
"Verbosus is a game where you take the letter of the alphabet and make up words. It is an educational game with excitement and fun for ages 7 to 70. It refreshes our memory of spelling, reading and making words."

Game consists of a deck of 72 cards with letters in both upper and lower case. Each card also has a score. By drawing and playing sets of cards to spell words you score points. Can be played as partners. You continue to draw cards until you can use all your cards to spell words and "go out". Player that goes out scores bonus points.

name: Strobe
description:
An electronic game similar to SIMON, but with an even more futuristic look. The unit features three different games:
"Pass the Flash" in which you must press one of your three buttons when your dome lights up, thereby “passing” the light to one of the other players. The light accelerates the longer the game continues; "Xcelleration" in which you must pass the light in the direction indicated by the Strobe; and, "Electronic Tennis" in which one, 2 or 4 players “serve” the light back and forth across the board.
Each game also has three skill levels.

name: Tommy Guns Blazing
description:
Tommy Guns Blazing is a miniatures game (using the Matrix system) set in the 1920s (Prohibition in the USA). Players take on the role of rival gang members and try to gain control of the illegal speakeasies. Players must provide their own equipment (dice, map or miniature buildings, counters or miniature figures, etc.). The game consists of a single 8-page rulebook, including two pages of tables.

The game requires a referee to assess the difficulty of any proposed action. Success is stated in a number of "6s." An easy task may require only one 6 to be rolled, but a difficult one might require six 6s. Likewise, movement is 2" per 6 rolled, and combat is also resolved comparing 6s rolled.

As in most Matrix games, the player chooses how many dice to roll at any given time, which can vary at his whim. For an easy task, a player may opt to roll only one die, or two dice, or a dozen. The catch is that while 6s succeed, every "1" that is rolled causes something bad to happen to the character of the die roller! The more 1s you roll, the worse it gets.

name: HMS Rules: His Majesty George III's Sailing Rules
description:
HMS Rules is a naval combat miniatures game (using the Matrix system) set in the Napoleonic/American Revolutionary era. Players control either the British, French, Spanish or American fleets. Players must provide their own equipment (dice, map with squares, counters or miniature ships, etc.). The game consists of a single 16-page rulebook, including a few pages of tables.

The game requires a referee to assess the difficulty of any proposed action. Success is stated in a number of "6s." An easy task may require only one 6 to be rolled, but a difficult one might require six 6s. Likewise, movement is 1" as a base, but can be more depending on the number of 6s rolled, how the ship handles in general, and ship's angle to the wind. Combat is also resolved comparing 6s rolled.

Before the game, every ship has a record sheet and must be rated for Handling, Hull (ability to take damage), Crew Combat Quality, Crew Morale, and Crew Damage Control.

As in most Matrix games, the player chooses how many dice (d6s) to roll at any given time, which can vary at his whim. For an easy task, a player may opt to roll only one die, or two dice, or a dozen. The catch is that while 6s succeed, every "1" that is rolled causes something bad to happen to the ship of the die roller! The more 1s you roll, the worse it gets.
categories: American Revolutionary War, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Nautical, Wargame

name: The Game of Earth
description:
From the back of the box:

"A perfect formula: The Game of EARTH + family, friends, or classmates = fun and excitement! The toss of a die determines whether you'll be quizzed about Earth's Environment, Atmosphere, Rocks, Tectonics, or Hydrosphere. Four challenging levels permit players of like and different ages and abilities to join together in unraveling the fascinating mysteries of our planet. Be first to correctly answer one question in each of the five categories, and win!"

The game comes with a couple of dice and 150 cards asking educational questions about Earth and its environment; each card has four levels of questions to provide different challenges for different age/knowledge groups. The rules provide with a few different variants of play: "Regular Play", "EARTH Master" (a game show variant for large groups), "EARTH Face-Off" (spelling bee), and "EARTH Challenge" (team play).

name: Three Blind Mice
description:
Shuffle the pack of cards and place face down on the table. Starting with the youngest and going in a clockwise direction, each player takes a turn to pick up a card from the top of the pack. If this is a head card the player places this face up in front of him. If it is not the card is placed face up at the side of the pile. Play continues with each player taking a turn to pick up a card from the top of the pack. Once a player has a head card, he may add a body card and then a tail card. The player may collect up to three head cards before he starts adding body cards. should a farmer's wife card be picked up and some of the players mice have tails the player must return a tail card with the farmer's wife to the reject pack. If the players mice do not have any tails the farmer's wife is returned to the reject pack.

The game is finished when a player has in front of him three sets of Blind Mice.

name: Project A-KO Fighter
description:
Based upon the Japanese anime "Project A-Ko", the game tries to re-create the endless battles between A-Ko and B-Ko for the friendship of C-Ko.

Project A-KO fighter is a card game based upon the mechanics found in the card game "Heavy Gear fighter" and "Video fighter". The games are even compatible with one another.

This particular game is made of 36 different playing cards that were included in the "Project A-Ko: The Roleplaying game book". Included in the roleplaying book were two different character sheets (one for B-KO and one for A-KO), that needed to be photocopied in order to keep track of the progress of players during the game. Their number of action points left, their remaining health, etc. as well as being used as a reference sheet for the various special powers each character had.

The game was meant as a stand-alone card-game that could also be played within the boundaries of the role-playing game as a player's aid for the game. Players were encouraged to describe verbally how exactly their characters attacked the other using a particular card. It provided those players that described the action behind a card play with special bonuses to their character's statistics, such as increased delivered damage to their opponent.

Also included in the book were various other characters that could be used against B-Ko and A-Ko, such as "ordinary persons", tanks, mechas and spaceships, which could bring the game to more than 2 players (to an infinite number if needed), although no character-ready sheets was made available for them in the RPG book.
categories: Card Game, Fighting, Humor, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction
mechanics: Role Playing, Storytelling, Variable Player Powers

name: Glockner-Rennen
description: A very simple racing game about a car rally over the alpine "Glockner-Road" (Großglockner=Austria's highest mountain). Instead of a die, the game uses an 8-sided teetotum to indicate how many spaces a player may go. A few spaces means a temporary breakdown for your car, one space means immediate loss. The first player who reaches the town of "Heiligenblut" wins.

name: The Second Korean War: 2009
description:
From the website:

"Learning from their mistakes from the 1950's, the North Koreans are set to launch another invasion of the South all along the 38th parallel in order to bring about reunification under Kim Jong Il's rule. With the United States heavily committed across the globe, the North feels it cannot lose. Will the communists drive the Allies into the sea or will the American and South Koreans press on past the Yalu and bring total peace to the region?"

With this, you'll get the game's mapsheets, rules, charts, etc. While you'll need to provide the pieces from various sources - of which those will be clearly obvious. This involves the use of most "Axis & Allies" components with some extras as denoted.
mechanics: Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Team-Based Game, Variable Player Powers

name: Harvest 28: The Ultimate Bowhunting Board Game
description:
Harvest 28 was designed by bow hunters for bow hunters in an attempt to give hunters, families and friends the opportunity to learn more about the ultimate bow hunting achievement.

The game is based on the ultimate challenge for bow hunters worldwide, which is to harvest 28 of North America's big game species.

This fun and educational game can be enjoyed by people of all ages and is best played with two – six players.

The compact size of the game enables people to take the game away on hunting trips to help fill in those quiet times when unpredictable weather sets in.

The game comes complete with Board, Dice, Miniature Bow Hunter Figurines, Tally Sheets, Pencils, Money, Risky Shot and Park Ranger Cards, and instructions on how the game is played.

name: Dave Campbell's X-tra Bases Baseball Game
description:
From the box:

ESPN-TV's Dave Campbell has created what many are calling "the best baseball boardgame ever."

- Hours of fun for the entire family.

- Use your own baseball cards and the stats on the back in X-TRA BASES.

- Exciting Baseball trivia with two levels of questions (so any) baseball fan can play X-TRA BASES.

- Choose your own team of All-Stars or play your favorite team against their rivals.

name: Excuse Me!  A Game of Manners for Children
description: Contents include twelve white question cards, 36 small, numbered correct-answer slips and 76 small, unnumbered incorrect-answer slips. When you answer a question correctly, you move that many spaces. Play this game and learn to be polite!

name: Race to the Kabah
description:
An educational, high quality board game that's fun for the whole family!

Learn the 99 names of Allah

For ages 7 to Adult (but even very young children can play with an adult)

2-6 players. Each round is approx. 15 minutes. The more rounds you play, the faster you will learn!

Makes an excellent gift for families, students, schools, new converts-reverts, and more.

Great gift idea for all special occasions including Bismillahs, Ameens, Eids, etc.

Includes 105+ cards, 6 pawns, dice, and a deluxe size (quad-fold) board with a FREE gift booklet. Included with lots of helpful tips and information.

Families that play together stay together! Families that pray together stay together!

name: Swizz
description: Swizz players use card decks to move their playing pieces around the board. As in its sister game, PanGaea, players must collect eleven special cards - in this case, they're called Resort Cards. When a player has collected eleven Resort Cards and lands on the start/finish space, the game ends. The player with the most points wins the game.

name: YARI
description:
From the manual:
"Welcome to the world of YARI - one of the lost wonders of the earth!
From the cradle of civilization to the dawn of "civilized man," many collective societies have risen and fallen, leaving only mysterious traces of their cultures, struggles, and wisdom. Like all civilizations, they, too, had much to teach the generations that followed, but those secrets have remained lost in sand and stone, long forgotten... until YARI.
YARI is not just a game.
YARI is a way of thinking.
YARI is logic, strategy, and wisdom.
YARI is a secret that you, too, can share, an arcane pathway into the development of the mind.
YARI is a universal language without words, without sound.
YARI links your mind to your opponent's - a contest of wills."

YARI is... basically... Sorry! using shells for dice and a few fairly nice bits.

name: The Zany Zoo Adventures Of Tennessee Tuxedo
description:
Help Tennessee, a wise-cracking penguin, his dim-witted pal, Chumley and Mr. Whopee chase and capture the mice that have overrun Megalopolis Zoo.

A simple spin and move board game by Transogram based on the Tennessee Tuxedo animated TV series.

- 12 playing pieces
- 31 cards
- 1 spinner
- 1 gameboard
- Box with instructions
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Humor, Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanics: Pick-up and Deliver, Roll / Spin and Move

name: WTF (Where's The Fun?)
description:
From the publisher:

WTF is, on the surface, a game about cards and points. You play a card, you gain or lose some points, and the player with the most points when the GAME OVER card is played wins. But there's a catch or two: First, the GAME OVER card is double-sided, so everyone knows where it is at all times. Second, over half of the cards in WTF contain blanks and you get to fill them in and finish the rules! You might get a card that lets you determine how many points players gain or lose, or you might get a card that lets you require all players to perform some ridiculous task of your choosing. Each card simply must follow on the "suit" of the previous card -- but many of the suits are made up by the players as they play! The big catch is that you actually write on the cards each game, so your deck is always changing. The result is that the card that seemed funny when it made the player to your left eat his own earwax is a lot less funny when it comes back around to the player on your right! For even more excitement, you can mix up your deck with another friend's deck and see what happens. It’s up to everyone to decide how far you have to go to get points and keep the GAME OVER card out of the point leader’s hand.
categories: Card Game, Collectible Components, Humor, Party Game

name: Monsters of the Deep
description: The object of the game is to be the first player to collect three blue monster discs. At each turn, a player spins the spinner and moves his diver down the safety line the number of spaces which was spun. If he lands on an empty space he may move a disc on his safety line to any empty space on his line. Or he may move one of his opponents discs to any empty space along that player's safety line.

name: Cosmic Wow
description:
From the publisher:

A Fantastic War in Space. Take the Galaxy If You Use the Right Power!!

5 Powers at War! Who will be the victor? You have the powers but which of the powers will be right to take another world? Cosmic Wow! is a fast Micro Game of combat on the move as Humans and Alien Powers try to eliminate each other. Cosmic Wow! is a futuristic, multi-player, interactive space fantasy wargame, suitable for two or more gamers of any age.


A Complete Micro Game
Fast & Inexpensive
Hours of Fun
No Booster Packs
No Collectible Cards
Brains Not Included


http://members.aol.com/TRITACGAMES/index.html
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Hexagon Grid, Income, Player Elimination, Point to Point Movement, Rock-Paper-Scissors
publishers: Tri Tac Games LLC (Tri Tac Talents)

name: Pantomime
description:
Draw cards. Act out scenes. Gain points.

From the publisher:

THE GAME IN A NUTSHELL - You choose one of eight categories. Draw a card from one of three levels of difficulty. Act out the scene written on the card, while the others try to guess the scene. Then, take turns playing until you're ready to stop. While all the time you HAVE FUN!

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
This is our answer to... well, actually, there's no game quite like it! It couldn't be easier to learn and, with 1,000 scenes, is so much fun we couldn't get our test players to stop playing. PANTOMIME™ is contagiously entertaining. It is imaginative and clever - FUN for the whole family, the bigger the better. Wild and crazy, with 8 different categories and 3 different levels of play, it builds personal confidence and increases sensitivity to others.
Just a pile of FUN for everyone!

It's used in schools, hospitals and anywhere kids and families want to have FUN! The categories include: Science and Nature, Sports, Emotions, Life skills, Professions, Entertainment, Oops and Oh Goody cards. All but the last two have three levels of difficulty and are played by acting them out, without sign language (like Charades) or props, or sound effects. It's pure non-verbal communication from the actor, and nonstop guessing and laughter from the rest of the players.

name: Flip Strip Poker
description:
A unique wagering game based on three coin flips and some betting strips which are laid on top of each other.

Despite the name of the game, no one needs to take their clothes off.

name: WPTA 21 Fort Wayne
description: WPTA 21 Fort Wayne, Game of Free Enterprise, Money Maker Board Game". The game board is like Monopoly and there are many old time Fort Wayne,IN businesses represented on the board, some are still in existence and some are not. Great nostalgia!

name: Mosaik
description:
Abstract boardgame for 2 players. Board must be 11 x 7 squares, with several of the squares divided into 4 smaller squares. Each player has 4 counters which must be placed 1 counters in each of the 4 large squares on the short edge.

Counters most move to an adjacent square, of a different size and color. In large square there can be 4 counters, small squares can only hold one counter at a time.

The player to first move his counters into the opponents start squares wins the game.

This game is found in a Danish book with rhymes, stories and games, originally published in Prague.

name: Kaptajn Flints Skat
description:
Captain Flint's treasure. 16 cards are dealt with 4 to each player.

The player who dealt the cards begins the game by asking any other player for a card. If the player asked has the card he must surrender it. Then the next player takes a turn.

The object of the game is to collect 4 cards which are connected on a red line on the map, and which ends at the Hut or the Tall Tree.

Found in a Danish book, originally published in Prague.

name: Fodboldspil For To
description:
Soccer game for two.

Played with a special die, showing 1-1-2-2-3-4.

Each player has his own counter, which start in the middle of the board. Read team goes first, rolls the die, and moves as many spaces as shown in any direction. If landing on A or B, you must move one more space. If landing on C you must roll the die again. If landing on D you must move two more spaces.

To score you have to roll the exact amount to land in the goal.

Found in a Danish book, originally published in Prague.

name: Labyrintspil
description:
Labyrinth game. Each player has 4 counters, one in each of the 4 colors on the board.

All counters start in the middle of the labyrinth.

On a turn a player will roll the die, and move any one of his counters forwards or backwards as many spaces as shown. If the counter stands on a space of the same color as the counter itself, the player gets an extra turn.

First player to get all his counters out wins the game.

Found in a Danish book, originally published in Prague.

name: Havenspel
description:
From the box: "discover the port of Antwerp without effort."

The game is a variation on the "roll and move" game. You roll a die and moves that many spaces. The number of the square he lands on corresponds with the number of the question he must answer successfully. If he answers correctly he can continue, if he answers incorrectly he has to skip a turn or draw a VIP card.

On the VIP cards are extra questions, if he answers this one correctly he still can continue, if he fails, he skips an additional turn.

You can only use VIP cards three times during the game.

The first player to reach the last square wins the game.

name: Drive By
description:
From the publisher:

Gangs, Vigilantes and Drug Dealers!
It's a new easy-to-play board game of neighborhood survival as Gangs and Vigilantes try to save their homes from crazed drug dealers. Bullets fly in this exciting and all too real game from Tri Tac.

It's a world of drugs, money, and horror as street gangs use automatic weapons to settle differences. Drive-By is a fast Micro Game of combat on the move as two or more players and vigilantes try to eliminate each other. You can take the neighborhood if you have the guts and guns. Dice not included.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hexagon Grid, Movement Points, Player Elimination, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Simulation, Variable Player Powers, Variable Set-up
publishers: Tri Tac Games LLC (Tri Tac Talents)

name: Tivoli-spil
description:
Fun Fair game.

On a player's turn, the player will roll the die and move thr amount on the circular track. Rolling a 6 earns the player 3 notes, and an extra roll. Crossing the start space earns the player 2 notes. Landing on the Target allows the player to roll the die, and on a 1-3 the player earns that many notes, and a 4-6 nothing happens. On the Clover the player draws one of the 7 luck cards. Landing on the Labyrinth makes the player lose one turn.

Landing on one of the rides allows the player to take that ride by playing the corresponding amount of notes.

First player to take all 12 rides wins the game.

Found in a Danish book, originally published in Prague.

name: I teatret
description:
In the theater.

Each player has 6 rows of 6 chairs. The player rolls two dice, then decides which one is the row and which one is the chair. The player puts a counter on the chosen combination. If the player cannot put a counter on any chair, he looses his turn.

First player to fill a 36 positions wins the game.

Found in a Danish book, originally published in Prague.

name: Ballonfart
description:
Used playing a dice with 6 colors as shown on the board.

Each player has 3 counters, first player to get all counters to the finish have won the game.

A players turn consist of rolling the dice and moving one of his counters to an adjacent balloon with the same color as rolled. Counters can only move forwards. If the player is not able to use the color rolled, he looses his turn, and the next player takes over.

Found in a Danish book, originally published in Prague.

name: Twelve O'Clock High
description:
Poultron Press Test Series Game #16.

The game covers the bombing of German industrial production by the Americans. There are Basic, Tournament and Advanced rules. The Americans win by destroying aircraft factories or other industrial targets. The Germans win by preventing the Americans from attaining their victory conditions.

The board is in black and white on heavy paper. The rules booklet is 14 page mimeograph. Counters are good quality.

name: Fun House
description:
Fun House - From the Klix Pocket Travel Games from Tiger Electronics.

The board folds out, the magnetic pieces (player pieces and prize markers) are stored in a built-in compartment and the dice are self-contained in a see-through compartment. The dice are 'rolled' by pushing and releasing the 'dice snapper'.

Prizes worth varying points are distributed throughout a 4-room funhouse. You have a limited number of moves in each room. If you run out of moves before you exit the room, you lose the prizes you've collected in that room.

"To Win: Race through all four rooms of the Funhouse to win more prizes than your slow-footed opponent and without running out of moves! You have a limited number of moves to get through each room and the challenge gets tougher."

name: Office Politics
description:
From the publisher:

It's dog-eat-dog FUN in the workplace!

Relate and laugh as the game pokes FUN at the humorous side of workplace Gossip, Antics and Skulduggery. But, be careful not to get FIRED... from the game.

An exiting game loaded with Opportunity, Challenge and OFFICE POLITICS.

Hold meetings, becoming a SPY, Embezzling and Backstabing are all part of the FUN as players compete against each other, scaling the corporate ladder any way possible, to take the ownership of a company called "OFFICE POLITICS".

name: F Troop
description: 1965 board game based on the ABC network television sitcom of the same name which starred Ken Berry, Forrest Tucker and Larry Storch.
categories: American Indian Wars, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Kuk-Nuk
description:
This is a variant of Chinese Checkers, where the "holes" (that contain the marbles) are hex nuts, a colored set for each player. On your turn, you can either move a nut or a marble. Nuts move either one space (on a board that looks uncannily like a standard Chinese Checkers board) or can jump over intervening nuts.

It's pronounced "Canook," by the way (says so right on the box!).

name: Brain Food
description: Brain Food: Games that Make Kids Think is a 200-page book with over 100 games in it. Many game boards are included for traditional games like Wari and Fox and Hounds. There are chess and checkers variants, chase games, blocking games, alignment games, maze games, mathematical games, deductive logic games, and a large selection of word games. Nicely illustrated game boards accompany 70 games from Sri Lanka, England, Korea, Africa, Japan and other places (and times).

name: Aérogame
description: A game where you fly a delta plane in a race against the other players. Negotiate the wind, your speed and don't forget your altitude.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Open Drafting, Point to Point Movement

name: Stresz
description:
Stresz is a strategic game which consists simply of pushing the opponents 4 marbles into the center square.

Each turn players roll the dice. The number rolled represents the amount of squares that the player can use to move his marbles. Only 1 base color is permitted to move per dice roll. To his choice, the player can move as he pleases the 2 marbles (if possible) of the same base color.

A player can push more than 1 marble.
A player cannot push his own marbles directly. He has to do it by pushing the opponents marbles(s) on his own.
A marble moved cannot end up on the same square it started its turn on, unless it has pushed one of the opponent's marbles before ending on this square.
The center square is made up of 4 distinctive squares. A marble has to be pushed to make a move in the center square.

When a marble is pushed in the center square, this marble is considered taken and cannot be used or moved directly. To take out a marble from the center square, one of the opponent's marbles will have to be pushed against it in order to push it out of the center square.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Countryfied
description:
"The only Country/Western game that'll have y'all Frettin'!"

Advance around the guitar-shaped board by answering questions about both kinds of music: Country *and* Western. A reader reads a question and the first to grab and ring the little cowbell (included) gets 30 seconds to answer. If they fail, another player can grab the bell and get a chance. Players advance if they answer correctly. When you get to the guitar neck, you have to roll a die (included) the exact amount to get to the head and answer a last question.

name: Chelmsford Challenge
description:
Chelmsford Challenge is one of a series of Monopoly style board game developed by local YMCAs in the UK to generate funds for their activities. The games in the series are essentially the same, but as in the different versions of Monopoly, the board and the businesses are specifically themed to the town or city represented in the title - in this case the town of Chelmsford, 28.5 North-East of London.

Players progress around the board as a result of the roll of 2D6. When landing on a Company square a player may purchase a share in that company (there are two shares available in each company), if he wishes. If not he may put the share up for auction, with any excess over the sale price being retained by that player as his fee for being the auctioneer.

Players landing on companies that are already owned must pay to visit, with the payment due being based on how many shares are owned in that particular company and in the other two companies in the same colour series. Since shares can be owned by two different players both may demand payment from a visitor.

Certain squares on the board require the drawing of a Chance card which normally result in income being received from or paid to the bank.

The “New Share Quotations” square results in the changing of share prices for some of the blocks of companies. This will result in players losing or gaining money on the shares that they own. It also requires players to put up one of their shares for auction thereby permitting players to trade in shares.

The game can be ended in three ways, which should be decided before the game starts:
- After a set time.
- When the first player becomes bankrupt.
- When all but one player has gone bankrupt.

At the end of the game the money is counted and shares are valued at whatever is the then current rate. The player with the greatest assets is declared the winner.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading

name: Cornwall Challenge
description:
CORNWALL CHALLENGE is one of a series of Monopoly style board game developed by local YMCAs in the UK to generate funds for their activities. The games in the series are essentially the same, but as in the different versions of Monopoly, the board and the businesses are specifically themed to the town or city represented in the title - in this case the County of Cornwall in the West of England.

Players progress around the board as a result of the roll of 2D6. When landing on a Company square a player may purchase a share in that company (there are two shares available in each company), if he wishes. If not he may put the share up for auction, with any excess over the sale price being retained by that player as his fee for being the auctioneer.

Players landing on companies that are already owned must pay to visit, with the payment due being based on how many shares are owned in that particular company and in the other two companies in the same colour series. Since shares can be owned by two different players both may demand payment from a visitor.

Certain squares on the board require the drawing of a Chance card which normally result in income being received from or paid to the bank.

The “New Share Quotations” square results in the changing of share prices for some of the blocks of companies. This will result in players losing or gaining money on the shares that they own. It also requires players to put up one of their shares for auction thereby permitting players to trade in shares.

The game can be ended in three ways, which should be decided before the game starts:
- After a set time.
- When the first player becomes bankrupt.
- When all but one player has gone bankrupt.

At the end of the game the money is counted and shares are valued at whatever is the then current rate. The player with the greatest assets is declared the winner.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

description:
EXETER CHALLENGE is one of a series of Monopoly style board game developed by local YMCAs in the UK to generate funds for their activities. The games in the series are essentially the same, but as in the different versions of Monopoly, the board and the businesses are specifically themed to the town or city represented in the title - in this case the City of Exeter in the county of Devon in the West of England.

Players progress around the board as a result of the roll of 2D6. When landing on a Company square a player may purchase a share in that company (there are two shares available in each company), if he wishes. If not he may put the share up for auction, with any excess over the sale price being retained by that player as his fee for being the auctioneer.

mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Hooked On Hereford
description:
HOOKED ON HEREFORD is one of a series of Monopoly style board game developed by local YMCAs in the UK to generate funds for their activities. The games in the series are essentially the same, but as in the different versions of Monopoly, the board and the businesses are specifically themed to the town or city represented in the title - in this case the City of Hereford in the West of England on the border with Wales.

Players progress around the board as a result of the roll of 2D6. When landing on a Company square a player may purchase a share in that company (there are two shares available in each company), if he wishes. If not he may put the share up for auction, with any excess over the sale price being retained by that player as his fee for being the auctioneer.

Players landing on companies that are already owned must pay to visit, with the payment due being based on how many shares are owned in that particular company and in the other two companies in the same colour series. Since shares can be owned by two different players both may demand payment from a visitor.

Certain squares on the board require the drawing of a Chance card which normally result in income being received from or paid to the bank.

The “New Share Quotations” square results in the changing of share prices for some of the blocks of companies. This will result in players losing or gaining money on the shares that they own. It also requires players to put up one of their shares for auction thereby permitting players to trade in shares.

The game can be ended in three ways, which should be decided before the game starts:
- After a set time.
- When the first player becomes bankrupt.
- When all but one player has gone bankrupt.

At the end of the game the money is counted and shares are valued at whatever is the then current rate. The player with the greatest assets is declared the winner.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading

name: Girls in Love
description:
Based on Jacqueline Wilson's books and TV series, players vie to see who knows the most about each other.
From the publisher: Get your closest friends together to see if you know what they like, what they don’t like and discover their deepest secrets! A game for girls about friends, gossip, fun…and boys!

name: All About Racine Area Game
description:
All About Town: The Game of the Racine Area is a localized monopoly clone where the players move around a board trying to acquire 8 travel cards while stopping at popular locations in the Racine, Wisconsin area.

The player’s pawns, money, game territories, travel cards and surprise cards all contain advertisement from local area business. The box also contains 2 sheets of 12 coupons for free goods and services from local businesses.

The layout of the game board and other game components could easily be changed for any other city that wanted their own board game.

In fact, the family on the cover is playing the game on a board with a completely different design.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Dice Rolling, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading

name: 3D Game Board
description:
This is actually four games in one:

Four Straight - 3-D Tic-Toe variant for up to 4 people. Indicates no tie ever on record ;-)

Triple Check: a 3-D checkers variant. For 2 players.

Space Pirate: A 3-D chase game - evidently similar to farmer and the Pig. For 2 players.

Space Chess: This really is the rules only as it states in the rules that the chess pieces are not included.

The board consists of 4 clear plastic shelves of 4 levels. There are marbles that sit in holes of these shelves in 4 colors.

Quite hard to find.

Contents:
Rule sheet
4 plastic planar levels
12 columns to insert into planar levels
30 marbles in each of two colors
18 marbles in each of an additional two colors

name: Ad.dic'tion
description: A simple but somewhat clever word game. The players alternate turns placing cards with letters on them on the board, creating an ever-longer string of letters. Strangely enough, the object is to avoid spelling an actual word. However, the string of letters must always be such that it could conceivably be made into an actual word by adding more letters. The round is awarded to a player if either her opponent plays a card making the string of letters into a word, or if she catches her opponent making a play that eliminates all possible words that could be made from the string of letters.

name: Agoniz'n
description:
Game play is an almost identical clone to Aggravation, although only 4 players may play. However, the board is compressed plywood, making it a true "Board" Game. The sounds of marbles hitting the wood is unforgettable.

Players move their five marbles around the board from Home to Finish. Lucky die rollers can make use of the shortcut spaces to speed movement. Players can not pass their own marbles and landing on any one else's marbles sends the landed-on marble back to Home where it must start again. First player to get all five pieces to Finish wins.

Since a 1 or a 6 are required to start a marble on its path, an optional house rule is that no one can jump your only marble if they have another choice, unless it is your last marble. A shorter version can be played using three or four marbles.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Brain Quest Add and Subtract
description:
From the manufacturer:

"For Ages 3 - 6. Put together sum puzzles! This matching game for preschoolers is a great introduction to addition and subtraction. All Problem Pieces and Solution Pieces are placed face down. Turn over a Problem and then search for its matching solution. Patterns and colors are one way to make the match. Figuring out the math problem takes the game to a whole new level. This game is a great way to introduce tiny tots to the award-winning Brain Quest approach: It’s OK to Be Smart! Comes with 20 double-sided Problem Pieces and 20 double-sided Solution Pieces. For 2 or more players."
categories: Children's Game, Educational, Math, Memory, Number

name: Gambling Games of Malaya
description:
This book was written by an Assistant Commissioner of Police as an aid for Magistrates in Malayan Courts who had to hear cases involving all manner of gambling games common in the region at the time.

As the author, Dobree, says in his preface to the book, dated 1st February 1955, "The book contains detailed descriptions of the majority of gambling games, betting and lottery games and betting which usually form or which may form subjects of charges in this country under the Common Gaming Houses Ordinance No. 26/1953 and the Betting Ordinance No. 47/1953.

Also mentioned for the most part briefly, are other popular gambling games mostly in the card game category, which do not usually form subjects of criminal charges as they are invariably played under circumstances which do not constitute any offense under the Ordinance ..."

Although intended to be a functional legal document, this book has concurrently become a major reference work for gambling games in South-East Asia, containing descriptions and rules for games not described in English in print elsewhere. Dice and playing card collectors will find this volume to be an indispensable repository of information on rare and unusual Asian specimens. The work is liberally illustrated with colour plates of gambling implements.

A list of the contents follows:

Foreword
Preface
Notes on Legal Aspects of the Ordinances
Definitions
DOCUMENTARY BETTING AND LOTTERY GAMES:
An Introductory Note to the Games of Chee Fah or Hwah Hwey, Chee Tam and Chap Ji Kee
Chee Fah, Hwah Hwey or 36 Numbers
Whay - Kelantan version of Chee Fah
Chee Tam or 80 Characters
Chap Ji Kee
Sap Sam Tai Poh
Wee Sua Peow or Wei San Piew,or Tong Sua Peow or Quay Suay Peow
Pak Kap Piew or Pigeon Lottery
Tikam Ekor or 100, 1,000 and 10,000 Number Games
Lucky Numbers at "Fun" and Similar Fairs
GAMES WITH CARDS:
Games with English Cards
Games with Chinese Cards
- Soo Sik Pai
- Luk Foo Pai
- Seong Kum Pai or Pin Kum Pai
- Chi Kee Pai
- Sap Ng Hor Pai
- Tung Koon Pai
- Oh Peh Pai
Pair
Sap Sam Cheong or Lushun Poker
Three Cards, Sam Cheong, Pa Kau or Daun Tiga
Koo Kiew, Ten Kiew or Soo Kiew
Tau Ngau
Twenty One
Thirty One
Ten and a Half
Minta Daun
Three Card Trick, Mai Wong or Tikam Raja
GAMES WITH DOMINOES:
Pai Kow
Tau Ngau
Tien Kow
DICE GAMES:
Yew, Yee, Sam or One, Two, Three
Tai Sai or Big and Small (Simple Form)
Luk Kow or Dicing Six
Sepat
Ta Kai or Cockfighting
Chong Yuen Chow
Sek Poh
Sek Chai Tan or Kok Kok
Tai Sai or Big and Small - using Staking Board
Tai Sai combined with Sek Chai Tan
Hoo, Hey, How
MISCELLANEOUS GAMES:
Chap Ji Kee Pangjang
Daun Empat or See Kee Yah
Fan Tan or Tuahn
Four Numbers
Poh, Lien Poh or Ewok
Staking Methods in Fan Tan, Poh, Four Numbers and Sek Chai Tan
Pek Bin
Belankai
Dadu Katak Ular (a Javanese Game)
Dadu Muka Enam (a Javanese Game)
Dadu Belankas Mata (a Boyanese Game)
136 Numbers
Solhi (a Punjabi Game)
Games with Mah Jong Tiles
Games in Amusement Parks
Fruit Machines
Horse Race Betting and Bookmakers

N.B. Page numbers and Chinese characters have been omitted from the listing of the contents.

name: Hor Lor Boon
description:
The name of this traditional roll-and-move race game possibly derives from the hulu (Mandarin) or hor lor (Hokkien dialect), which means a gourd, that often appears as a symbol on the board. In the catalogue for the exhibition, Asian Games: The Art of Contest, the following names for this game are mentioned:
hulu pan (gourd board) - southern Fujian and eastern Guangdong area
hulu qi (gourd chess) in Hong Kong
hulu wen (gourd puzzle)in Suzhou
fenghuang qi (male and female phoenix chess)in places such as Tianjin, Weixian (Shandong Province), and Chengdu (Sichuan Province).

I know it, in Singapore, as Hor Lor Boon.

This game is played on a board showing a spiral track and the object is to move one's piece from the outside into the center of the track first(q.v. Game of Goose and Sheng Guan Tu). The track is made up of individual symbols which will be repeated once on the board. Players roll two dice and move the number of symbols along the track. Wherever they land, they will then jump to the corresponding symbol elsewhere on the board (which could be a help or a hindrance). It's not necessary to land exactly on the center square to win - passing it also wins.

The symbols may vary, but are usually traditional or mythological Chinese figures (e.g. the Eight Immortals, creatures from the Chinese zodiac) and would include a gourd (hor lor).

A contemporary set made in China called cai shen you xi qi (God of fortune game) has two pieces for each player - presumably the roll can only apply to one of the pieces in this version (the rules are not clear on this). The rules for this version state that if a piece is supposed to land on a space occupied by another piece, it remains where it is and the piece it would have landed on is sent back to the start. The board features the God of Fortune as the central space that all the players are trying to reach.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Care Bears Cloud Catcher Take and Play Game
description:
A simple children's game wherein players user a spinner to attempt to collect a set of five Care Bear character tiles and place them on their "Cloud Card".

The first player to collect all five Care Bears is the winner. Comes in a vinyl carrying case.

Ages 4 and up
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Roar! Roar! Dinosaur!
description: The game where extinction stinks! Choose your beasts one by one, then shake the rock and see where it lands. Will you get to capture one of your opponent's dinosaurs, or will one of yours become a fossil? Roar! Roar! Roar as your dinosaurs go extinct! Contains: 24 Dinosaurs, Earthquake Mat, 1 Meteor, 24 Fossils, Rules. Ages 5 and up.

name: SARS War
description:
SARS Wars – Sha Si Zhan Qi

Towards the end of the SARS (Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome) outbreak in Singapore in 2003, an enterprising media company published this simple roll-and-move board game, incorporating the public health education messages that were issued at the time. It was sold at branches of a book-cum-stationery shop chain, Popular Bookstore.

The game is for 2 to 6 players and players each have a coloured pawn that moves along a spiral track towards an End Point. Along the way, players follow instructions on spaces they land on, including taking two kinds of chance cards.

The ‘Personal Hygiene’ card is drawn when landing on a ‘Personal Hygiene’ square – players follow whatever instructions are written on these cards. The ‘See Doctor’ cards may be drawn when landing on a ‘Symptoms’ square, or also after landing on a ‘Check Your Temperature’ square and rolling a 4, 5, or 6 (on lower numbers your temperature is normal, so you naturally don’t need to see a doctor).

Players may also get sent to Hospital or be put under Home Quarantine. Being in the Hospital is worse as the player proceeds to Home Quarantine after discharge from hospital.

The game has lots of humorous touches that reflect the atmosphere at the time. One of the pre-game preparation rules is, “All players must wash their hands thoroughly before playing”. There’s also a rule concerning expulsion from the game, “You are not allowed to continue with the game when you are expelled because of reckless, irresponsible personal misconduct that jeopardizes the entire community”.

The first player to reach the End Point is the ‘overall winner’ of the game. The other players can continue to play the game. Ominously, “the last player left is the loser, who may be punished appropriately”.

name: Karlsson på taket
description:
Children´s game published in Sweden and themed on Karlsson på taket (Karlsson on the roof). The gameboard depicts Karlsson´s house and the apartment where the boy, Lillebror, lives.

Contents:
Gameboard
Die
7 figures
39 cards

Ages 5 and up
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Stones: Seven Challenges of the Pharaohs
description: This series of abstract games are played on a cloth banner with nicely polished stones. There are a total of seven different games. There is one solitaire game and the remaining six games are either for 2 players or 3 players. This game is packaged in a mailing tube. The contents include a cloth banner for the playing board, a rule book, a cloth bag with draw string, 15 finely polished stones and 1 six sided die.

name: Sporting Triangles
description:
SPORTING TRIANGLES - ITV's Question and Answer game for all the family.

Now everybody can be part of the quick-fire question and answer fun of the top rated TV show. With 3,000 sporting questions to help and harass you it's a race around the triangular board for up to four players or teams. Those who use their sporting knowledge to best advantage and are the first to complete the 'sporting triangle' win the game.

Contents:

Game board
3,000 questions and answers
Scoring base and pegs
Four playing pieces
Die
mechanics: Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: The Share Game
description:
The object of the game is to win as much as possible by buying and selling shares.

Brief description: Players are each given oil shares, industrial shares, mining shares and money - 1000 of each. The first player takes a telegram from the top of pile and reads it to himself and places it face down on the table in front of him. He then throws the two dice at the same time and moves the correct share marker to a higher or lower price and follows any printed instructions there. He may use his telegram at this point or hold to a later point in the game. To present it he turns it face upwards and the share marker to which it applies is then moved to a higher or lower price as indicated by telegram. Shares may then be bought or sold by any player at the value indicated. Then once players have bought or sold play continues by the next player picking up a telegram. When the last telegram is taken from the pack, the dice are thrown for the last time. Each player is then, in turn given one chance to present any telegrams still held.

Note: One die is chosen as the number 1 die. This die determines which share type rises or falls, according to the table printed on the board and box. The other die shows the amount of fluctuation. For example if number 1 die shows 3 and number 2 die shows 6 the price of mining shares will fall 6 points.

Table as below:
No 1 dice
1. Industrials fall
2. Oils fall
3. Mining falls
4 Industrial rise
5. Oils rise
6. Mining Rises
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Stock Holding

name: The Rooster Coop
description: The Rooster coop is a game where the players try to collect their family of chickens. It is done by moving the marker on the board and by sliding the tiles and by that changing their position. The rules are very simple that can be explained in a few minutes, but wining the game is a bit more tricky. The players try to collect their chickens, but at the same time, can try preventing other players from collecting their chickens by changing the positions of the tiles. Fun game for all the family.
mechanics: Action Points, Set Collection, Tile Placement

name: Alagar XVI
description: A checkers type game, using the standard chess type board. Pieces range with values 1 - 4, and the goal is to capture opponents pieces to total exactly 16 points. Pieces only move the value on the piece in straight lines, and capture by landing directly on the opponents piece.

name: Touristo
description:
Touristo
The Board Game of Singapore

From the rules:
"TOURISTO is a board game for two or more players. The play consists of getting to know some of the interesting places in Singapore, collecting as many token points as possible and escaping the multifarious pitfalls that are intricately simulated in the pot luck cards. Each player competes for the highest token value and he can strategize and take advantage by using his discretion wisely. The players can also have great fun and laughter with the creative catch-phrases that are used to portray the interesting places."

This game was obviously targeted at the tourist market. It is small, portable and features tourist destinations in Singapore, some of which are no longer around. References to the defunct Van Kleef Aquarium and Bukit Turf Club date the game to the 1980s or early 1990s.

It features a Monopoly style board with pictures of the tourist attractions on the spaces. There are 'Pot Luck' cards that act like chance cards, and token cards with point values that the players are trying to collect. Player's pieces feature a tiny Merlion's head.

name: Tengamo
description:
Tengamo offers four different games that can be played in this collectible magnet game. Game packs come with 6 random characters magnets (of 60 current) and a steel marble.

In "Roller Ball", each player tosses the same number of pieces onto the playing surface. Players then take turns rolling their steel balls to collect opponents until all pieces have been captured. Pieces have different point values, and the player with the most points wins.

In "Magnetic Pull", one game piece is placed in the center of the playing surface, and each player uses the magnetic properties of another Tengamo piece to try to drag the center piece to their side of the table. Pieces are placed in the game by both players until all have been used and collected. The one who has attracted the most pieces to their side wins.

"Stack and Build" allows players to create different shapes and images with pieces.

"Fridge Throw" can be played one of two ways. Players can throw Tengamo pieces on metal objects, such as the refrigerator, and try to connect without touching their opponents' pieces, or they can throw their pieces at the object and try to hit their opponents' pieces.

name: Paddington
description:
This children's card game contains 36 cards (9 different sets of 4 cards) depicting Paddington Bear from the BBC's 1970's children's TV series.

Cards are shuffled and dealt 5 to a player. The remaining cards form the draw pile, and the top card is turned over to start the discard pile.

On a player's turn, he may take the top card from either the draw pile or the discard pile. He then discards a card.

Each player aims to collect two sets - one of 3 cards and a pair. When a player completes a set during his turn, he places it face up on the table in front of him. The first player to lay both sets on the table is the winner.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Let's Play Golf
description: Let's Play Golf is a card game for 2-12 players. The golfers compete to see who can achieve the lowest score by matching cards. The game requires a good memory and who ever can manage their hand best will putt their way to the lowest score.

name: Ceexstem
description:
A very traditional Nimíipuu game, shared throughout the Plateau region is called Céexstem, a form of dice game. Formally played by women, today both men and women of all ages enjoy the excitement of Céexstem. The goal of the game is to see who can reach the agreed upon point total first. Any number of individuals can play at one time. The game is a wonderful way to learn the number system of the Nimíipuu, counting from náaqc (one) to le'dptit (twenty), and have a lot of fun doing so!

To play the game, you need two sets of game sticks, each set colored a different color, e.g., blue and red, and each set marked indicating a áayet (male) and hamma (female), a "couple." The male stick is often marked with an extra perpendicular line across it. The reverse side of a stick is called, caya, "nothing."

Before starting the players agree upon the number of points to win, the higher the number, the more challenging and the more fun. Typically, 5, 7 or 11 point totals are selected. Usually starting with the youngest player and proceeding to that person's right, each person throws the four game sticks onto the rug before them. Depending on how the sticks land, the following points are possible.

* one "couple," a áayet and a hamma of the same color = one point

* two "couples," both sets of áayet and a hamma sticks = three points

* one áayet and two hamma = two points. This combination refers to the Nimíipuu practice of looking after a male friend's wife should he fall in combat.

* if there are no pairs matched, e.g., áayet and a hamma of differing colors = no points

* but if all the sticks land caya, "nothing" = all points accumulated are lost and the player starts over.

After deciding on the win point total, be it 5, 7, or 11, the players need to agree on other rules. Will you need to win on the exact number, be it 5, 7 or 11, not going over that total? If a player gains points beyond the agreed upon win point total, will extra points over that total be subtracted from that player's earned points? As players gain points, they should always announce their totals in Nimíipuutimptneewit.

Nimíipuutimptneewit numbers:


náaqc - one
lepít - two
mitáat - three
píilept - four
páaxat - five
'oyláaqc - six
'uynéept - seven
'oymátat - eight
kuyc - nine
púutimt - ten
púutimt wax náaqc - eleven (ten and one)
púutimt wax lepít - twelve (ten and two)
le'eptit - twenty

name: CardMath
description:
From the company's Website:

The primary objective of CardMath is to use numbered cards (Math Cards) and Operator Cards (+ , -, x, ÷) to create an equation whose result is selected as the target. Players collect as many Math Cards as possible (each card has a point value printed in the center). The secondary objective is to use up all of your Math Cards before the other players can use up all of theirs. Once a player uses all of his or her cards, the game ends, and points are tallied. The player with the most points wins the game.

There are many ways to set this game up, to accommodate different levels of math skill of the players. The Spinner can be used in the center of the board to determine the target equation’s solution or it can be removed so that the target solution is always 21. Or, take away the multiplication and division operators, so that less skilled players only have to think about adding and subtracting. When math skills increase, CardMath will be along side to grow with your needs.

name: Trimendus
description:
From the company's Website:

Trimendus, illustrated with many famous art objects, makes an exciting atmosphere for a jigsaw memory game. Spell the magical word before your opponents and win the game. Be careful, your memory skills will be pushed to the limit. Trimendus turns a regular jigsaw puzzle into an exciting interactive board game.

name: Kobe Mini-Yard
description:
A table game with a circular board that has four pockets. The board is made of wood and has a circumference of 85 cm. It revolves like a lazy Susan so players need not stand up. The games have elements of Carrom and Billiards (The name is a contraction of 'mini-billiards').
Each player has a hand held spring-loaded cue with which they try to hit various colored wooden pucks into the pockets.
There are at least three different games that can be played. For example, Direct Pocket, where points are scored for knocking the pucks into the pockets (eg a red puck is worth 5 points, a green is worth one point). There is Battle Game, where you try to pocket your opponents' pucks by striking them with your own.
There is also a game set called Octo Mini-yard which has an octagonal board.

name: The Wizard of Oz
description:
Quiz Game made in England in 1962 by Bell Toys.

It is a family quiz game called the "The Wizard of Oz". This works along the same lines as the Magic Robot games that were also made in the 1960's.

There are sheets of questions and answers covering eight different categories. You stand the Wizard figure in the red magnetic base and move his pointer to a question. You then place him on the mirror in the middle of the answers section and he will magically move his pointer to answer your question.

He always gives the correct answer - he is a very clever little man!

Contents:

1 board
1 Wizard figurine
4 overlay mats with questions and answers

name: Alternative Games for the Family
description:
From the back of the book:
"The alternative games in this booklet are all designed to be played with standard equipment. They offer exciting new dimensions to games played on or with draught boards, cards, pool tables etc., helping to eliminate the constant financial burden of purchasing expensive and often short-lived new games."

This is one of at least three booklets with rules for games designed and published by New Zealander, Tony Crow. Two other titles are "Alternative Games for Those Who Like a Challenge" and "Alternative Games for the Studious".

The games are variations on existing games like draughts, ludo and Scrabble. The booklet is divided into four sections: Card Games, Draught Games, Other Games and Billiard Table Games.

name: The Road to Peace
description:
The United Nations Assistance Mission in Afghanistan (UNAMA)produced 10,000 of this game for disadvantaged children throughout Afghanistan.

The game aims to teach children about the key events in the peace process and reconstruction of Afghanistan. It also highlights key issues such as the environment, health, and education.

Players spin a spinner and move their piece (not included) along a path from "the past" to "the future." Along the way they land on squares indicating positive or negative events that either send the player forward or backward.

name: The Ten Thousand-2000
description:
From the website: " A new crisis is forming in Central Europe. A right-wing German government has seized several disputed nuclear weapons brought into their nation by American military actions in the Ukraine. The German chancellor has demanded the disarmament and the immediate removal of all US military personnel in Central Europe as well as Germany being recognized as "a nuclear power". The President of the United States appears to capitulate to the German demands; however, Lt. General Al Malin, commander of the US Tenth Corps, refuses to disarm without a fight and leads a bold, yet desperate plan to invade Germany, recover the nuclear weapons, and march his units to the North Sea to uphold American military honor. " Based on the novel by Harold Coyle.

For this, you'll be provided with the game's mapsheets, rules, charts, etc., while you will utilize the components from Axis & Allies or related games.
categories: Dice, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Novel-based, Wargame
mechanics: Area Movement, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Instant Math Games that Teach
description: This book contains 38 games recommended for grades two through five, but older kids or adults could enjoy them, too. Templates for dice or spinners are included, but usually all that is needed is a few markers or coins. Variants on Nim, Magic Squares and Tic-Tac-Toe, as well as games using tangrams, pentominoes and other manipulatives. Aimed at teachers, but has nicely presented abstract strategy games as well as those involving numbers.

name: Walker's Tour Through France
description: Full title: "Walker's Tour through France Being a New Geographical Game Containing Many Interesting Particulars of the Present State of the Principle Cities, Towns, Villages, Mountains, Rivers, &c., in that Kingdom.". Early 19th century board game comes in slip case box which measures approx. 5 1/2" x 7" and contains an 84 page booklet titled "A Key to Walker's Geographical Tour Through France with Directions for Making the Tour" and a folding, hand colored Game Board being a map of France with a trail of 199 game "spots" tracing a tour through the entire country beginning at spot #1 (Calais) and ending at spot #199 (Paris). The map is linen backed and folds out to approx. 21 1/2" x 20 1/2". The map is marked "London. Published June 6th, 1815 by Wm Darton Junr. 58 Holborn Hill ___ Of Whom may be had Walker's Instructive Geographical Tours of the World, Europe, England & Wales, Scotland & Ireland.". Among the very earliest commercially manufactured Board Games produced.

name: Spade Town Challenge
description:
SPADE TOWN CHALLENGE is one of a series of Monopoly style board game developed by local YMCAs in the UK to generate funds for their activities. The games in the series are essentially the same, but as in the different versions of Monopoly, the board and the businesses are specifically themed to the town or city represented in the title - in this case the town of LURGAN in Northern Ireland. It is situated on the south shores of the Lough Neargh, 20 miles south-west of Belfast.

Players progress around the board as a result of the roll of 2D6. When landing on a Company square a player may purchase a share in that company (there are two shares available in each company), if he wishes. If not he may put the share up for auction, with any excess over the sale price being retained by that player as his fee for being the auctioneer.

Players landing on companies that are already owned must pay to visit, with the payment due being based on how many shares are owned in that particular company and in the other two companies in the same colour series. Since shares can be owned by two different players both may demand payment from a visitor.
