The cards were developed by a biotech company and a team of Raffles Institution students who have decided that that there are others ways to learn life sciences aside from textbooks and stacks of notes.
First conceptualised by Genecet Biotechnologies, a leading biotech company that provides education in life sciences to schools, the prototype was then passed to the RI students —Melvyn Kee, Hoe Si En, Nicholas Leong and Tan Ee Kuan — to improve on.
.Said Genecet Senior Manager Mr Jeffrey Lee: "Being students, the RI boys had a different perspective on the game, because we as adults don't really know what they would enjoy."
.

name: Saved by the Bell: The New Class
description:
From the back of the box:

It's time for some hilarious new adventures at everyone's favorite school, Bayside High. And to make it even better, Zack and Kelly are stopping by to join in the fun. The object is to be the first player to collect 3 prank tokens and have three differen date-cards- one each of WHO, WHAT, and WHERE. You date may end up being a romantic who takes you to a scary movie and then out for a picnic. Or maybe your date is athletic and you go to a baseketball game and then eat pizza with everything. Your date can be different every time you play.

Includes gameboard, date cards, prank cards, prank tokens, movers, game die, and original instructions
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Ato-Blitz War Games
description:
This is a Stratego-like game that's actually two games, an army game and a navy game. Pieces are set up on a board in a manner similar to Stratego, but rather than being linear (numerical values), the units have a rock-paper-scissors relationship. i.e. the tank unit is superior to infantry and engineers but is inferior to aircraft, artillery, and mine units.

For those who want to recreate the (army) game, the pieces are as follows: Private, corporal, sergeant, staff sergeant = 3 each. Second lieutenant, first lieutenant, captain, major, lieutenant colonel, colonel, 1, 2, 3, and 4 star generals = 1 each. Tanks=2, plane=1, Anti-aircraft/anti-tank=5. Mines=6, Engineers=6. A-Bomb=1.

Infantry take each other according to rank; infantry also takes anti-aircraft/anti-tank and engineers. Tanks and planes take infantry and engineers. Plane takes tank, anti-aircraft/anti-tank takes planes and tanks, engineers take mines without damage. Mines are stationary pieces that explode and destroy anything that triggers it except an engineer. The A-Bomb is essentially a movable mine that destroys every piece in a surrounding square when it explodes.

The pieces are like mah jongg tiles arranged so that the opponent cannot see what kind they are -- he just sees blank pieces advancing toward him. When a piece is attacked or attacks, it is turned over so that the face is visible. It then becomes a known piece for the rest of the game.

We played the game in Hawaii in elementary school in the late 1950s. There were two blank pieces included, presumably in case a piece got lost. We sometimes used these to create two additional pieces, the brainwasher and the kamikaze. The kamikaze was simply a flying bomb. The brainwasher changed an opponent's piece into one of your own. It was not possible to brainwash the A-Bomb.

name: Domodots
description:
From the box:

"A new game to increase number skills."

There are tiles of three colors with variable number of black and white pips positioned at random on the two ends of each tile. Players match tiles based on color and one of: (1) the total number of black and white pips on the tile halves, (2) the number of black pips on the tile halves, or (3) the number of white pips on the tile halves.

name: Radical Racers TCG
description:
A new TCG with an automotive theme. Start the game with a set MPH (miles per hour). Each player Battles through the race playing four mutant racer cards attempting to decrease opponents' speed, while at the same time increasing their own. Some interesting mechanics is that a player can force a tie, instant win or lose all their mutant cards. The racer at the end with the highest mph wins. They have also added an Advance game where you play until one player has captured all their opponents' Racers.

Online Play

CCG Workshop (no longer available)

name: Hexplora
description:
All players arrive to the Hexplora Isle named such a way because it has a hexagonal shape and is divided into hexagons.
Each player starts exploration of the isle collecting resources to manufacture new things and help their community progress.
You can also attack other communities.

You have to create a "Municipium" to collect all founded gold.
The winner is the player who collect 36 pieces of gold.

The game was inspired playing Catan's Settlers, but the way the map is composed is completely different (even if it is based on hexagon too).

Some rules should be tuned but the game mechanic is already defined.

For more information contact the author (dexhm2@hotmail.com)
mechanics: Commodity Speculation, Hexagon Grid, Modular Board

name: Raa..Raa..!
description:
This is a tailor made game for the Dutch police.
This game requires some pens and paper, which are not included in the game.

Your pawn starts at start.. Throw the 12 sided die and move that many spaces.
You draw a card with 15 random words on it. You pick 1, 2 or 3 words off of the card according to the number of eyes on your field. Don't show the card to the other players

Another player draws a card with sentences on it and he/ she picks a sentence for you. You have to start your 1 minute story with that sentence and try to get all your words in the story. If you fail to get all your words in the story, you get zero points, if you succeed you get 50 points per word. (So the max is 150 points per story)

The other players can now guess which words the storyteller has used, for every correctly guessed word the player gets 25 points

For every 150 points you get an eye token and after that you start counting again, so if you have 175 points you get 1 eye token and have 25 points left.

There are special fields called Raa..Raa..! fields. If you have an eye and you end on a Raa..Raa..! field you are allowed to lay your eye on that field. If there is already an eye of somebody else there, you are allowed to remove that eye and give it back to the owner.
If you receive your 4th, 5th or 6th eye, you can use those to block an other player. Just lay your eye in front of his pawn and the other player, that player must now skip a turn.

The challenge:
If you end on a Raa..Raa..! field you can choose between either skip a turn or accept the challenge. The challenge is pick 4 words and use those in an 1 minute story. If nobody guesses the words, the storyteller gets 250 points. If one player guesses all 4 words he receives 100 points and the storyteller loses 150 points.

name: E! Pop-A-Razzi DVD Game
description: Put your tinsel-town knowledge to the test with this fun DVD game packed with celebrity clips and trivia questions from E! Entertainment's 101 Countdown series.

name: Techmate
description: Each player controls a team of robots. The player that can transport his robots into his opponents' starting spaces first wins.

name: PriceWaterhouseCoopers
description:
A promotional game developed by Identity Games for PriceWaterhouseCoopers.

Players try to gather as much 'right answer' tokens and as little 'wrong answer' tokens as possible by answering trivia questions. The winner is the person with the most 'right answer' tokens at the end of the game.

name: Bloomsday
description:
A racing game that simulates the 10k Bloomsday race in Spokane, Washington. Players simultaneously choose a number of Endurance Points to "burn". Players burn these points to move along the board, but if you don't burn more than your opponents, you only move one space! Be sure to keep something in the tank for the final stretch.

The board consists of a long track labeled with the different stages in Bloomsday. The board spaces can also make the player go forward or backwards or lose turns. Some spaces give you special cards, like "injury" or "special training" that you can play on yourself or your opponent.

name: Century 1900-2000
description: Here's a great game that focuses on American 20th Century social, political, and historical information in a "trivia" game format. Players answer questions covering important events of the century while moving across the gameboard and collecting playing tokens. It's a great game for school and home! 2-4 Players Ages 9 and up

name: States & Capitals Zip Around
description: Each player receives a double sided card which is keyed so that a question on one card requires an answer on the card of another player. This high-interest activity allows players to become familiar with the capitals and numerous geographic characteristics of all 50 states. Grades 6-12

name: California Chase
description: Players begin their game in San Diego and chase their way up the state of California while drilling language arts basic skills. This exciting game integrates geography and language arts skills in a fun format designed for 4th through 7th grade students. Skill areas include spelling, antonyms, synonyms, word usage, capitalization, and punctuation. 2-4 players Grades 4-7

name: States & Capitals Match Wits
description: Players use these 50, four-sided domino game to match the capitals, time zones, and geographic regions of the 50 United States. Each of the four different categories have different point values. Strategic placement achieves high scores! 1-4 players. Grades 4-8

name: Add & Subtract Chekker Math
description: Play checkers and enjoy improving addition and subtraction skills. This fun and fast paced game may be played by two individuals or two teams with similar or different learning ability. Grades 2-6

name: English Volley
description: Students reinforce their knowledge of prepositions in this vollyball simulation game. Players take turns and "serve" questions from one of the four sets of story cards and "return" the answers. This activity covers prepositional phrases; prepositional after verbs; and prepositional after nouns, adjectives, and participles. Each set of cards, when assembled numerically from 1-48, tells a story, original or adapted from multicultural folk tales. For 2-10+ players ESL Adult and Grades 5-12

name: Pursuit
description: Players learn how to build words using prefixes and base words. The base words are located within the game board squares, and the prefixes are listed on the spinner. Students spin and move to the first space where that prefix can be used with a base word to form a word. 245 words can be formed. 2-4 players. Grades 4-8

name: Decimal Olympics
description: Competition in popular Olympic activities is incorporated in this exciting game using decimals from 10ths to 1000ths. Over 40 problems using addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division of decimals are included. Olympic activities including the javelin, discus, shot-put, and pole vault allow students to earn points toward winning a gold, silver, or bronze medal. For 2-4 players plus a referee.

name: Fraction Olympics
description: Over 400 problems for each of the four basic math operations are included in this exciting fractions game. Competition in ten popular Olympics events are used to motivate players. For example, the javelin, discus, shot-put, pole vault, and many more activities allow students to earn points towards winning a gold, silver, or bronze medal. For 2-4 players and a referee.

name: Factor Football
description: Two players or teams can score touchdowns, field goals, and experience other activities found in football games as they practice multiplication skills. For example: 6X2 = 12 which represents a fumble with no points scored.

name: Bear Hunt
description: Students become masterminds as they use inductive and deductive reasoning with this exciting game. Using colorful bears, students build color pattern riddles that their opponent must solve on the transparent gameboard. This activity is great for whole class competition or for use in learning centers. 2- players or whole class participation. Grades 1-6

name: Baseball Card Grand Slam
description: Here's an action packed board game designed to meet a variety of educational needs while tapping into America's favorite pastime... Baseball! As players build their own teams, they use their own baseball cards or the baseball cards included in the game to answer problem solving questions. Included are integrated reading, math, and geography skills covering time zones, states and capitals, major league cities, rivers, lakes, and oceans. Lots of baseball trivia is included. There are five levels of difficulty, allowing players of different ability levels to play together. 2-4 players or teams. Grades 2-12

name: Equation Golf
description: Play golf while you learn to compute combinations of addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, cubes, square roots, and more. Using 60 cards in the deck along with golf terminology, players draw "stroke" cards to create equations which solve a target number. After nine rounds of play the game is over and the player with the lowest score wins the game.

name: Chase Whole Numbers
description: Here's a great, competitive, fun-filled game. Each player chooses a colored pawn and follows the track around the board by spinning and moving to a specific number in either the ones, tens, hundreds and thousands place. The winner is decided by the first player who makes it once around the board and follows their colored alley to the center of the board. Grades 1-4

name: Chase Large Numbers
description: Here's a great, competitive, fun-filled game. Each player chooses a colored pawn and follows the track around the board by spinning and moving to a specific number in the thousand, millions, up to the hundred millions place. The winner is decided by the first player who makes it once around the board and follows their colored alley to the center of the board.

name: Chase Decimals
description: Here's a great, competitive, fun-filled game. Each player chooses a colored pawn and follows the track around the board by spinning and moving to a specific number in either the tenths, hundredths, and thousandths place. The winner is decided by the first player who makes it once around the board and follows their colored alley to the center of the board. Grades 4-7
publishers: Creative Teaching Associates, Wiebe, Carlson & Associates

name: Discount
description: Over 400 real-life challenges are included in this great game. Players learn to purchase furniture, clothing, appliances and more. Extensive drill in computing percentages, fractional discounts, keeping financial records and reconciling accounts is covered. Great for home use, and learning centers. 2-4 Players Grades 5-12

name: Math Around The School
description: How long did John Glenn orbit the earth? This and many more curious questions are included in this fun-filled game. History, math, problem solving, and trivia are incorporated into three levels of difficulty so that students at different ability levels can be challenged as they play together. 2-4 Players Grade 3-8

name: Place Search Small Numbers
description: Place Search is a great activity in a four-sided domino format. Players match words with their corresponding numerals. Two levels of difficulty cover numbers through the thousands place. 1-4 players. Grades 3-12

name: Place Search Large Numbers
description: Place Search is a great activity in a four-sided domino format. Players match words with their corresponding numerals. Two levels of difficulty cover numbers through the hundred millions place. 1-4 players. Grades 3-12

name: Tic Tac Frac
description: Using the tic-tac-toe format and three levels of difficulty, students are immersed in competitive drill with equivalent fractions.

name: Equivalent Fraction Dominoes
description: This game contains 45 dominoes and five game ideas using halves, thirds, fourths, fifths, sixths, and eighths. It's great for home use or learning centers.

name: Foxhole 2: Poland
description:
"Jon Compton's tactical hex and counter game of WWII combat. This set focuses on Germany versus Poland at the start of the war."

Each hex on the map represents an area approximately 100 yards across. Each playing piece represents about 40-60 men (a platoon) or half a dozen vehicles or towed weapons . . . For ease of play, the game scales are approximated. Time is also abstracted, thus turns represent several minutes.

The FOXHOLE system is simple to learn and fast playing that focuses on the invasion of Poland. Its a good diversion from the more heavy fair of historical board-wargaming.

FOXHOLE SET 2 includes:
-Ten new scenarios, six exclusively with this set, and four incorporating elements from Set 1.
-Twenty-four unit cards
-Over one hundred playing pieces -Tactical Battles Map A - and One rule book

name: Batter Up! Math
description: Incorporate baseball with addition, subtraction, multiplication and division problems. With three levels of difficulty, students from first to sixth grade can have fun in pairs or small groups as the play baseball. Get the whole class involved by creating an overhead transparency from the black line master that is included. This game may also be adapted for weekly homework assignments and remedial math programs. 2-4 players or 2 teams.
categories: Children's Game, Educational, Math, Number, Sports

name: Play Ball Multiplication
description: Introduce children to the great American pastime...BASEBALL while they practice multiplication problems with factors of 3,4,6,7,8, and 9. Multiplication problems determine base hits, singles, triples, home runs, and more. Example: 3X7 = 21 which denotes a single. 4X9 = 36 or a "triple". 2 players or teams may play. Grades 4-8

name: Equivalent Fractions Match Wits
description: Two sets of 30 quadromino tiles provide drill in equivalent fraction recognition at two levels of difficulty. Level 1 includes fractions from 1/4 to 10/12; Level 2 covers 1/4 to 21/24. Each tile shows fractions in numerical form. It's a great activity for individuals, play at home, or in learning centers.

name: Synonym Line Up
description: Three levels of difficulty are included in this fast-paced tic-tac-toe styled game. Three game cards are included and players match antonyms from their playing card, to base words found on the spinner. The first person to form a line of antonyms on the board wins the game.

name: V-Attack
description: The year is 2340. Just as in all of history, conquest is at the heart of mankind. Enslave or become a slave is the future. You are in charge of breaking through the wall of your enemy’s city to allow the entry of your battalion to take over. Organic Titazium metal (O37T2y) has been used in the construction of all walls during this time period, which makes them virtually impenetrable. The wall cubes must be removed carefully or the wall structure will collapse and repair itself thus defeating your mission. While you are attacking the walls of your enemy, they in turn are attacking you. By using limited means, you must minimize the damage directed to your city. Victory belongs to he who enters the city first.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Card Game, Fighting, Print & Play

name: Escape
description: Players learn how to build words using suffixes and base words. The base words are located within the gameboard squares, and the suffixes are listed on the spinner. Students spin and move to the first space where that suffix can be used with a base word to form a word. 245 words can be formed.

name: Alternative Games for Those Who Like  a Challenge
description:
From the back cover:

"The alternative games in this booklet are all designed to be played with standard equipment. They offer exciting new dimensions to games played on or with draught boards, cards, dominoes etc., helping to eliminate the constant financial burden of purchasing expensive and often short-lived new games.

The games in Alternative Games for Those Who Like a Challenge are based on popular games that have been modified so they are even more competitive and exciting.
At the same time, they are easy to learn if you already know the standard edition, providing hours of inexpensive entertainment, making this booklet desirable for most game lovers.

Other books designed by Tony Crow are:
Alternative Games for the Family and
Alternative Games for the Studious"

This book contains rules for modified card games, draught board games, Scrabble games and billiard table games.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Action / Dexterity, Book, Card Game
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Point to Point Movement, Trick-taking

name: Black Abyss
description: Black Abyss is a space civilization game where players explore the galaxy for habitable planets and then scan the planets surface for beneficial terrain. Players will expand their empire by colonizing these planets and erecting buildings that best use the terrain and available space of each planet. A player will win by means of expansionary, militaristic, diplomatic, or scientific policies. The game features great details of empire building and fleet management.
categories: City Building, Civilization, Exploration, Science Fiction, Space Exploration, Territory Building
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers, Voting

name: Grammar Mania
description: This game reinforces the proper use of grammar as players identify and correct common grammatical errors. Over 700 sentences at three levels of difficulty are included. Throughout the game there are mistakes that are commonly made in the usage of adjectives, adverbs, questions, verbs, subject verb agreement, nouns, comparisons, superlatives, gerunds, infinitives, prepositions and more. A comprehensive answer key is included. Great for all English Language Learners (ESL) low intermediate to advanced and English grades 6-12.

name: The Good Steward Game
description: Good stewardship of time, ability, and money is an important part of life. This exciting game introduces children to the principles of good stewardship. As players move around the game board they earn money for a variety of tasks. They learn to put money in savings and in the church offering. There are opportunities to spend money, recycle and do community service projects. A scripture memory component is also included. For 2-4 players. Ages 6 - 12

name: Your Number's Up!
description: Your Number's Up is a fast-paced game for 2 to 6 players. The object of the game is to score as many points as possible, by completing simple sums. The first player lays a number card down and subsequent players have to complete the sum. The player completing the sum takes the three cards as their trick and starts the next round. Sounds easy? Well maybe! What happens if you cannot complete the sum? You have to pick up a spare card and wait for your next turn. This game can be played by people with all levels of ability and in our testing, we found some people with devious minds who tried to stop others winning tricks. I'm sure you wouldn't do this! It's fun, but make sure number isn't up by having a handful of cards at the end.

name: One Card Game
description: Here's a great card game for visual learners! Players match equivalent fractions or find sums of "ONE." Included are cards representing halves, thirds, fourths, sixths, and eighths. Each card pictures a fraction, gives the number word, and shows its corresponding numeral.

name: Percentage Dominoes
description: Here's a great way to learn about percentages using dominoes! It's a great game for individuals, or small groups in a learning center.

name: Subtraction Dominoes
description: Subtraction Dominoes provide a unique way to learn subtraction facts with differences from 1 to 18. It's a great learning tool for individual or small group us in a learning center environment.

name: Tic-Tac-Sum
description: Here's a basic addition activity using a competitive tic-tac-toe format. Three levels of difficulty cover addition problems from 1 to 20. Great for home use or in learning centers.

name: Tic-Tac-Times
description: Here's a basic multiplication activity using a competitive tic-tac-toe format. Three levels of difficulty cover basic multiplication problems. Great for home use or in learning centers.

name: Tic-Tac-Divide
description: Here's a basic division activity using a competitive tic-tac-toe format. Three levels of difficulty cover basic division problems. Great for home use or in learning centers.

name: Arithmattack
description: This exciting game sharpens player's addition and subtraction skills as they capture spaces on the board by adding together numerals printed on color-coded disks. Strategy is used to capture other players spaces by exchanging disks on their own space or on an opponent's space. The winner is the player who is the first to capture four squares in one row, one column or one diagonal. Great for two players or teams. Grades 2-8

name: Triad
description: Competition and strategy makes this game fun and exciting. Players learn to build words by connecting prefix, suffix, and base words. It's great for two players or two teams. Grades 4-8

name: Die Regenbogen-Karawane
description:
The board displays a rainbow with 6 colored tracks. The player pawns are animals. Each animal carries a jewel on its back.
At each turn the player throws a die and moves his/her pawn. A player may move forward or sideways. If the jewel on the back of the animal corresponds with the course of the rainbow, the animal moves faster. Otherwise the animal moves slower.
The first player with all of his/her animals at the other end of the rainbow wins the game.

name: Charge!
description:
"Become a general in the Napoleonic Period and challenge a friend on the battlefield. Charge! is a non-collectible card game for 2 players. With Charge! you can revive the emotion of leading an Army and win a battle. Dispatch your orders to your infantry regiments, fire at the enemy army with your cannons and force it to retreat with your cavalry charges."

A card war game involving advancing your units to break the line of your opponent. Debuted at Essen 05.

name: Department Store Math
description: Let's go shopping! Each player begins the game with $200. As purchases are made from the enclosed catalog, players make purchases and compute change using money up to $20. Coin chips from one cent to fifty cents, and currency from $1 to $20 is included. 2-4 players. Grades 4-8

name: Match Wits Addition Facts
description: This four-sided domino activity provides drill in addition facts with sums up to 20. It's a great activity for small groups of 2-4 players or for individual use. 120 problem answer combinations are possible with two levels of difficulty. For example, 2+4+3 matches 3+5+1 for a total of 9.

name: Skim Math: Subtraction
description: Skim Math - Subtraction is a fast-paced game that uses color-coded problem and answer cards while players race to match addition problems with their corresponding colored answers. For example: 3-1 is blue on the problem card and the blue answer card 2 wins that card. The player with the most cards at the end of the game wins.

name: Skim Math: Multiplication
description: Skim Math - Multiplication is a fast-paced game that uses color-coded problem and answer cards while players race to match addition problems with their corresponding colored answers. For example: 4X3 is blue on the problem card and the blue answer card 12 wins that card. The player with the most cards at the end of the game wins.

name: Skim Math: Division
description: Skim Math- Division is a fast-paced game that uses color-coded problem and answer cards while players race to match addition problems with their corresponding colored answers. For example: 12 divided by 4 is blue on the problem card and the blue answer card 3 wins that card. The player with the most cards at the end of the game wins.

name: Skim Math: Addition
description: Skim Math - Addition is a fast-paced game that uses color-coded problem and answer cards while players race to match addition problems with their corresponding colored answers. For example: 3+4 is blue on the problem card and the blue answer card 7 wins that card. that card. The player with the most cards at the end of the game wins.

name: Money Dominoes
description: Players have fun with these unique dominoes by matching coin values in written, numerical, and pictorial form. 45 dominoes and game suggestions are included. This activity may be used for individual or small group play.

name: Face Value, Place Value
description: 40 creative cards show children's faces featuring numbers that represent the "face value" for each card. A place value spinner focuses attention on the value of the digits on each card. Set A contains numbers that emphasize ones, tens, and hundreds places. For example: If a player's Face Value card number is 945 and the spinner lands on "tens", the player gets 4 point since the 4 is in the tens place. This is a great activity for small group or full class participation. Grades 1-3

name: Tic Tac Fraction Slices
description: Using this unique tic-tac-toe format, students enjoy competitive drill at three levels of difficulty while they learn to recognize fractional parts.

name: Purchase
description: Financial accountability! With this exciting game, players learn to make purchases and keep financial records of their purchases on their personal financial record sheet. They also have the opportunity to earn money and make strategy decisions while keeping track of their income and cash balance. 2-4 players. Grades 4-8

name: Spelling Bee II
description: 600 high utility words are contained within the bonus word list and on the gameboard. Words have been carefully selected from current spelling word lists for 4th through 7th grade. Players travel around the gameboard and find words that are misspelled on a list in the square where they land. The game is self-correcting and fun to play. 2-4 Players - Grades 4-7

name: Spell Checkers
description: This self-correcting game reinforces spelling skills from primary to intermediate grades. Players with different learning abilities may play at the same time using an extensive list of spelling words that are included. Weekly spelling lists may be substituted in order to adapt the game to your classroom needs. Grades K-8 Great for two players or two teams.

name: Recognizing Fractions Match Wits
description: This game comes with two sets of four-sided tiles. There are 30 tiles in each set. Level 1 includes fractions from 1/4 to 5/6: Level 2 includes fractions from 1/4 to 10/12. Fractions are depicted using slices, bars, and numerals. It's a great activity for home use or learning centers.

name: Match Wits Simple Column Addition
description: This four-sided domino activity provides drill in simple column addition facts using 3-digits. It's a great activity for small groups of 2-4 players or for individual use. 120 problem answer combinations are possible with two levels of difficulty.

name: Name That Word
description: As players move around the gameboard they identify parts of speech in 125 sentences within the spaces on the board. Nouns, pronouns, verbs, adverbs, prepositions, and articles are addressed.

name: Super Clerk
description: This real-life game is fun to play and introduces players to the reality of saving money through store sale. Learn to use percentage calculations while figuring the differences between regular and sale prices of household goods while shopping. Each player selects 24 product cards and during the game may sell them to other players. 2-4 players. Grades 3-8

name: Swipeout Ski Challenge
description:
Swipeout Ski Challenge is three games in one, a card game, a board game and combined card and boardgame.

When you play the full Swipeout Challenge game (The combined card & boardgame), you build up your resources for your mountain adventure through a competitive card game. You also acquire carious action cards, known as Game Cards, which will help you or hinder other during the boardgame that follows.

The winner is the player with the most money left at the end of the game.

name: Speller Senior
description:
From Publisher's website at http://www.creativeeduaids.com/whats.htm:

"Senior version of our very popular game in which the players spell the words correctly to move around the board and score maximum marks. A highly challenging and educative game to learn spelling, pronunciation and improve vocabulary. Contains and beautiful multi-color play board and 300 spelling cards with 900 spelling of varying difficulty levels."

Components:
1 Board
4 Playing pieces
300 Spelling Cards
1 Special dice

Publisher's contacts:
Creative Educational Aids Pvt. Ltd.
6, Toy City, Udyog Kendra, Greater Noida,
Dist. G. B. Nagar, U.P. 201306. India
Tel.# +91-120-2350875, 2350292, 9891082313

New Delhi Office Tel# +91-11-25381813, 25381759,
Fax: +91-11-25381790
Email: pradeep@creativeeduaids.com

name: Sale
description: "To buy...or not to buy?" Shopping is a part of every-day life. Finding the best bargain is always a challenge. In this game, players experience the challenges of comparative shopping and determining savings on sale items. Players also make payments, and record financial transactions. Currency from $1 to $55 is included. 2-4 players. Grades 4-9

name: Menu Math
description: Going out to eat can be an expensive venture, but with Menu Math, players learn how to keep within their budget and interpret menus. Each player receives $60 and six menus. Choices range from short order restaurants like Grandma's Kitchen, to Chinese, Mexican, and Italian restaurants and dinner houses. There are two levels of difficulty in the game, and it 's great for use at home, or in learning centers. 2-4 players Grades 4-9

name: Antonym Line Up
description: Three levels of difficulty are included in this fast-paced tic-tac-toe styled game. Three game cards are included and players match synonyms from their playing card, to base words found on the spinner. The first person to form a line of synonyms on the board wins the game.

name: Language Detective
description: This excellent proofreading game helps players look for mistakes in spelling, word usage, capitalization, and punctuation. With an easy-to-follow scoring system, this self-correcting game is great for any language arts program.

name: Fun At The Fair
description: Let's go to the fair! This fun and exciting game helps players learn to manage their money when they go to the fair. After paying the entrance fee, players race around the board to be the first to ride all five rides. The winner must finish first and be able to reconcile any remaining cash. Two levels of difficulty are included. 2-4 players. Grades 2-6

name: Match Three
description: Here's a great way to deal with problem spelling. Two students or two teams play this self-correcting game as they properly spell 200 words from cards, using combinations of ei and ie...ir and us...ee and ea, and oa and ou. Grades 4-8

name: Build A Sentence
description: Players learn to put sentences together correctly as they choose simples words that represent "Who", "What", "Where", and "When". Players take turns spinning the spinner. They select a word that is color-coded to the spinner. Once they have collected a "Who", "What", "Where", and "When" card, and can make a sentence, they win! The game includes two levels of difficulty. Level 1 includes words representing "Who", "What", "Where", while level 2 includes words representing "Who", "What", "Where", and "When".

name: Match Wits Subtraction Facts
description: This four-sided domino activity provides drill in subtraction facts. It's a great activity for small groups of 2-4 players or for individual use. 120 problem answer combinations are possible with two levels of difficulty.

name: Match Wits Multiplication Facts
description: This four-sided domino activity provides drill in multiplication facts covering numbers from 0 to 9 . It's a great activity for small groups of 2-4 players or for individual use. 120 problem answer combinations are possible with two levels of difficulty. For example, 3X4 matches 2X6 or 12.

name: Match Wits: Division Facts
description: This four-sided domino activity provides drill in division facts with divisors of 1 to 9. It's a great activity for small groups of 2-4 players or for individual use. 120 problem answer combinations are possible with two levels of difficulty.

name: Batter Up! Spelling
description: Here's a great game that incorporates a baseball theme using first through sixth grade level spelling words. At three levels of difficulty, students with different learning abilities may play in pairs or small groups in a learning center. Get the whole class involved by creating an overhead transparency from the black-line master included. The game may also be adapted for weekly spelling and vocabulary drill, as well as remedial classes. Grades 1-6

name: Mark Twain's Memory-Builder
description:
In 1885 American humorist and author Samuel L. Clemens (Mark Twain) received a patent for Mark Twain's Memory Builder, a game designed to help players retain important dates and facts from throughout history.
Points are awarded by what type of fact is given: 10 for an Accession of kings, presidents, and other rulers; 5 for Battles; and 1 for minor events such as births, deaths, and inventions. Additionally, one point is awarded for facts not related to dates, such as the number of bones in a human foot.
The board consists of a table with areas marked 1-100 representing the years of any century with 3 rows of dots for the three kinds of facts previously mentioned and a separate section for un-dateable facts. As a player names a fact he places a pin in the related pinhole. Anything worth remembering is admissible.
Play continues in turns for a previously agreed upon amount of time.
publishers: Charles L. Webster & Co., Geo. S. Parker

name: Busy Day Race Game
description:
From the back of the game box:

Winnie the Pooh and his adorable friends are having a fun filled busy day. Join them in their adventures around the Hundred-Acre Wood. Play as Winnie the Pooh, Piglet, Eeyore or Tigger in this "Busy Day Race Game". The aim of the game is to be the first player to arrive HOME. As you race around the board you will come across some obstacles which will help and hinder you on your journey home.

name: Walt Disney's Wonderful World of Color Game
description: A game based on the TV program. The object of the game is "to be the first player to travel all the space orbits, collecting the six different colored pieces to complete a TV screen."
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Racing
publishers: (Unknown), Alga, Damm / Egmont, Parker Brothers, Whitman

name: Opiumkrieg 1839-42
description:
From Spielbox . . .

In Opiumkrieg 1839-42 (The Opium War 1839-42), the goal is to be at the right place at the right time and then do the right thing. On the eve of the first Opium War, the players sail their junks through the China Sea and buy silk, spices, porcelain or tea from the various harbors. These wares are sold for a heavy profit in the canton where the English freighters are. But the freighters also bring a trading good with them, one out of India that is worth much gold in the harbors along the sea: Opium! The only catch – dealing in Opium is punishable by death. Each player can choose in this game: a long life, or get rich quick. After war breaks out, the needs of the dealers change on a daily basis, forcing flexibility: A harbor that might have been shut yesterday is now open again, where Opium trafficking might be punished heavily today, tomorrow the English might allow it again. The historic events of the time are also included and have an affect on the way the game goes. And yet, there’s still enough variety in the game to make it play out differently each time and allow the players to influence the game in many ways!

name: Sticks & Straws
description: Take as much part of the board, by placing straws in different sizes. The straws are randomized by a dice. Straws can also be taken away if they are not part of an enclosed area.

name: Turncoats
description:
From the publisher's website:

Turncoats is a game of espionage where allegiances can shift at any time during conflict. Players must outsmart their opponent and manipulate the neutral force (which both players have control over) to win.

This fast-paced game combines strategy, luck and ingenuity to create a game that is fun and intriguing for people of all ages. The games concept is roughly based on the idea of a military conflict where two warring factions must manage the effect of a third force which can be influenced by either side. The French and Indian war is an example of a conflict similar to what players will encounter in Turncoats.

name: Dive-Opoly
description:
Dive-Opoly is a monopoly clone, replacing Jail with the Hyperbaric Chamber and other properties with dive related businesses. It was published by Scuba Tool with part of the proceeds going to Divers Alert Network (DAN), a non-profit agency dedicated to assisting in education, research, and medical aid to divers throughout the world. The following descriptions come from the game's enclosed instructions.

Object: To become the richest diver from the buying, selling, renting, and trading of scuba related businesses.

Equipment: A game board, 2 dice, tokens, huts and villages, title-deeded cards, Treasure Chest and Explorer cards, and Dive-Opoly money.

For 2-5 divers, Ages 8 and up.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Octobuzzy
description:
How to play
Pick one of the tools either oar tweezer or spoon
Spin the ship's wheel
Steal the treasure shown on the wheel. the treasure must be picked up with the chosen tool. If Octobuzzy eye's light up or the buzzer sounds the treasure must be returned and play passes to the next player.
A turn ends when a treasure is stolen without Octobuzzy's eyes lighting up or buzzer sounding.
Spin again if treasure shown has already been stolen by another player.
Lose a turn if treasure shown has already been stolen by yourself.
The winner is the first player to steal 4 different treasures

Same style as Operation

name: The Mayor of Hooverville
description:
It’s October 1931 in Seattle Washington, and you’ve had a tough couple of years. The Stock Market crash of ’29 brought on hard times. You lost your job last year when the lumber mill shut down. Nobody’s hiring. The local bank where you kept your money saved made loans to those businesses that were shutting down. Depositors panicked and there was a run. The bank went into receivership, and your savings were wiped out. With no job and no savings you couldn’t make your house payment, and your mortgage was foreclosed on. Like millions of Americans you find yourself jobless, penniless, homeless.

Down by the Port, on the site of the old shipyard, some men are gathering supplies for winter: cardboard boxes, tar paper, firewood. You have decided to join their shantytown and to try to start again.

Who will eat the most food? Who will wear the least tattered clothes? Who will live in the finest hovel? Who will become The Mayor of Hooverville?
mechanics: Trading, Variable Phase Order, Worker Placement

name: Booktastic! Family Edition
description:
Booktastic!
Family Edition
for ages 10 and up
Features Children's Literature!

Booktastic is a fun-for-the-whole-family game that combines traditional strategic and competitive play with the sharing of literary trivia! Booktastic appeals to rudimentary readers, bookish braniacs, and everyone in between. Because the casual reader questions are opinion-based and have no wrong answers, anyone can play including children and non-readers. During the game players move around a quaint town square of bookstores to buy, sell, and trade books according to a collection card they receive at the beginning of the game. Before each turn, players earn money by choosing question cards. The player with the most valuable collection of books and cash at the end of the game wins!

name: Word Fun
description:
The rules for two different games are included in the box.

One, Two, Three - Go! (for 3-4 players)

Object of the Game
Each player competes with others to collect as many 3 card sets as quickly as possible.

Rules:
1. Place all cards scattered face up in the center of the group.
2. On a count of three, each player begins to collect his cards. First a lead card must be picked; then its idea related partners. a 3 card set must be completed before a player may start again, picking a lead card first.
3. After all cards have been collected and assembled in 3 card sets, the player with the most card sets wins!

Letter Recognition (for 2-5 players)

Object of the Game
To group by the first letter of the first word on each card, while trying to lay down all cards. The first player out of cards wins.

Rules:
1. Shuffle cards, one player deals all cards equally to each player.
2. Each player should organize their cards, grouping like letters. Example: Post Office, Park, Picnic Table, etc.
3. The dealer starts play by laying down the first card. Play continues clockwise with each child laying down a card that begins with the same letter as led by the dealer.
4. If a player cannot play a card he "passes," and play continues to the next player.
5. If all players have laid down all cards beginning with that same letter, the last player to lay down starts the next group.
6. Play continues and the first player to lay down all his carsd wins!

Recommended for Ages 4 - 8.
categories: Children's Game, Educational, Puzzle, Word Game

name: Dumb Luck the Ultimate Gambling Party Game
description:
Dumb Luck is the Ultimate Gambling Party game, which combines poker, blackjack, hi-lo, and 19 other exciting games of chance with a race to the finish line where the winner cleans out what is left in the bank.

The Dumb Luck game is even set up as a "$20 buy in" if playing for some friendly cash is desired (and allowed). Among the many pieces included are 300 11.5 gram poker chips, 3 decks of cards, 8 dice, custom spinner, full color hinged board, and a beautiful locking carrying case. Take a look at www.dumbluckgame.com
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Dice, Party Game
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Musical Bingo
description:
Each player gets a musical bingo card. The cards consist of a diamond of whole, half, quarter, eighth, and sixteenth notes distributed across the two musical clefs (treble and bass). Each card either has notes on the lines or notes on the spaces between the lines. The placement of the high/low notes are staggered and each card has a different placement of the various note lengths.

The caller selects one of the musical note chits, which have a particular pitch and duration. Players check their boards to see if they can match that pitch and duration. If they can, they place a marker on the appropriate note. Play continues until someone can make a run of 5 notes.

name: Metropolitan Washington Trivia
description:
This Trivial Pursuit clone has cards with six categories: People, Politics, Places, Culture/Entertainment, Fine Points, and Sports. The questions relate to the Washington D.C. area.

The included instructions have players take turns rolling a die (not included) and answering a question in the corresponding category. Answering two questions correctly in a row gives the player one "letter" marker (a piece of cut-out paper). Once you have gotten 10 letter markers (spelling WASHINGTON) you win.

The rules also state that the cards "can be used with other trivia game boards - just use our colors instead of theirs."
publishers: Washington D.C. Trivia Playing Cards Inc.

name: Would You Believe?
description:
Contents: Six pawns, score card, answer cards, question cards, and the instructions.

Object: Move up and back down the score card by the use of the move values on the question cards. Be the first to arrive back at start.

name: Geo-Graphy
description:
Object: To peg-in as many places beginning with the letter indicated by the alphabet dial as the timer allows.

Components: Peg map board of the world, sand timer, alphabet dial, pegs, and instructions (printed inside box top).
mechanics: Line Drawing, Set Collection, Tile Placement

name: Howdy Doody's TV Game
description:
A visit to Howdy's own TV studio! Players spin the "Howdy Doody Time" spinner then move their pieces through the studio visiting the show's characters and scenes.

Components: Game board, spinner, 6 character pawns (color cardboard stand-ups of show characters), 6 wooden pawn stands, 4 wooden movers.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Silly Sidney
description:
The absent-minded elephant game. Based on the Silly Sidney character from the Hector Heathcote Show. Players travel through the jungle to find their animal friends.

Contents: 14 cards, 4 pawns, game board, spinner, instructions.
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Off To See The Wizard
description:
Children scaled board game where children stand in as pawns.

Each player takes his place ate the beginning of his path, He must always move forward the number of steps indicated by the spinner, following the Yellow Brick Road. Obey the signs on each brick. If a a player is in another player's way, you cannot pass him. If a player has been instructed, though, to go to a space already occupied, the more than one player can occupy the space together. The first player to land on the Gate to Oz must spin a number one to enter and win.
categories: Fantasy, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game

name: Funny Finger
description:
Funny Fingers everywhere, sticking out here and there! Match each finger one by one, Funny Finger is funny fun!

Players match up other players' fingers (sticking through holes in the finger fence).

Contents: Four finger fences, scoreboard, scoring pegs, instructions (inside lid).

name: The Wonderful Wizard Of Oz Spinner Game
description:
The Wonderful Wizard Of Oz Spinner Game, 1975 from The Toy Factory.

Simple spinner game for Ages 5 - 12. The spinner is integrated to the middle of the gameboard.

Spin and move the indicated number of spaces. Follow directions there, if any. The first player to reach the Emerald City wins.

Includes 4 character cardboard pawns on stands.

name: Spin 'n Win
description:
To be the first player to fill the five slots on his color section of the playing board.

Contents: Game board with attached spinner, letter cards, instructions (inside box lid).
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Limbo Legs
description: Be nimble, be quick, jump over the limbo stick! The game is an elimination contest. Players jump over the revolving limbo stick while performing a task (determined by spinning the large Twister-esque spinner). If any player fails to clear the limbo stick, they are eliminated from the game.

name: Termitenspiel
description: 64 (4 sets of 16) small cardboard cubes with termite trails, all in a canvas bag. Rules for 6 games are included.

name: Captain Gallant of the Foreign Legion
description:
This antique game is based on the TV show Captain Gallant of the Foreign Legion. The TV show featured the well-known LARRY "BUSTER" CRABBE, who played Captain Michael Gallant. He is better known for his roles as TARZAN, FLASH GORDON and BUCK RODGERS

Players are legionnaires (starting in the center of the board) or North Africans (starting from the outer ring of the board). Each race to make it to the other side. The first player to move all his tokens to the other side, wins.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanics: Race, Roll / Spin and Move, Take That

name: lamafia
description:
Sicily, 1943. Main Mafia families in Western Sicily, supported by the Allies who have overthrown Fascism, took back the control of rural areas inside the country.

Up to 6 powerful Mafia families struggle to achieve the economical and political power in Sicily and Italy, managing their deals with the Italian-American gangsters and with the South American and Far East drug traffickers.
They accumulate their fortunes through the typical ways of organized crime, then re-invest their revenues in money laundering, in order to get some affiliates among the entrepreneurs and politicians.
The aim is to increase their prestige inside the organized crime structure, killing their opponents and dealing with the reaction of the State, always adapting their income sources to the evolution of the political context, through the enitre 50 years of Italian history depicted by the game.

This game design project has been abandoned in 2007.

name: Twisted Tales
description:
Created by a 7 year-old girl (now she would be 16!; is this the start to a game designer's resume?), this is a story telling game where you take familiar characters and twist the stories, so Handel and Gretel blew the pigs straw house down. The game consists of character and story cards.

Suitable for Ages 4 and up.

name: Falling into a Black Hole: A Space VLBI Intergalactic Adventure
description:
From NASA's site for kids:

you can take an imaginary trip to a black hole right now!

You will also visit such interesting places as a giant array of radio telescopes in the New Mexico desert and NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, California. Then you will blast into space and visit the Earth-orbiting Japanese VSOP Radio Telescope (launched in 1997) and Russia's RadioAstron telescope (not yet launched).

Then you will leave Earth orbit and go on to explore other galaxies, an interstellar gas cloud, a neutron star, and finally, a black hole! You will earn "Antigravity Tokens" along the way, so that you will be able to escape from the black hole's tremendous gravitational force.

Object of the game:

Be the first to reach the Black Hole armed with at least 25 Antigravity Tokens so that you will be able to get yourself out and go home after you are through exploring.

Game available at - http://spaceplace.nasa.gov/en/kids/svlbi_do1.shtml

name: Slim River
description:
On January 7, the British 12th Brigade, which had been hammered back for weeks, now faced a new bold foe: Japanese tanks (type 95 and 97) composed of two companies supported by the 42nd Regiment. With only a few antitank weapons, the British defenders were hard pressed when the Japanese bold use of armor in the jungles began at 0330. What followed was simply a mini-blitzkrieg as the Japanese tanks found numerous previously undiscovered roads through which to bypass British defenses. The British really did not know what hit them and by 0830, the Japanese had secured the Slim River bridge and the road to Singapore was open. In the game, chance cards create the uncertainty of battle from the sudden approach of Japanese aircraft, discovering a bypass road, stumbling onto a minefield, or the sudden activation of British units. Formation cards determine which formations activate and in which order, depending on the player that plays them. This will vary with every game turn. All this creates a totally unpredictable game.

The game comes with a 11x17 in. map, 280 counters, formation and chance cards, which are used to activate the counters on the map, a rulebook. The scale is 350 yards per hex, platoons, individual tanks\weapons, 30 min. turns for a total of 11 turns.

name: Sail Back L'approdo
description:
Both players have to reach other side of board (enemy's island) and have to choose the way to reach it faster than opposite player.
During the journey the ships can try to sink enemy’s ship shooting them.

name: Memoradar
description:
Players have to make a pool of cards copying exactly the pool locked in twisting plastic structure.
The fastest one gain victory point and the twisting were replaced by other cards.

name: Mixies
description:
The 1965 version has three scenarios. The deck consists of 36 cards. The first card displays an advertisement for this product, the next two cards show a list of instructions, and the other 33 cards are divided equally between circus character pictures of heads, bodies, and legs.

Game #1: This version is essentially the only game. It is for 3 or 4 players. The head cards are divided equally among the players. The rest of the cards are mixed up and spread face down on the table. Player take turns revealing cards in a memory game type fashion. A player with a "head" card must uncover a "body" card while a player with "head" and "body" cards must uncover a "legs" card, otherwise the turn passes to the next player. The first player to complete all of his funny characters wins the game.

Game #2: A player can divide the three types of cards into three piles for a solitaire version players where the sole player reveals a "head" card followed by a "body" card followed by a "legs" card, creating various funny-looking circus figures.

Game #3: A player can place the cards in numerical order to create a "flip-movie" by riffling the top of the deck with his or her thumb. (It might be noted that these different numbers and pictures on the backs of the cards could be used essentially as "marked cards" for the 3 to 4 player game.)

name: Coopetition: On the Go!
description: An offshoot of the original Coopetition game, the On the Go! edition has players competing and cooperating in the categories Act, Talk, and Draw. The game consists of dice, game cards, and a 30 second sand timer. Players role dice to determine what word and category will be in play and with whom they will be cooperating or competing. Designed to be played in teams of two or more. The game box is small enough to fit in a pocket or purse and is meant to be taken with to family gatherings or parties.

name: Le città del cielo
description:
This game consists of a deck of 36 square cards representing star systems and constellations. It is not only a game, but it may constitute an help for the realization of theatrical or narrative structures.

The players take three cards each an try to form a particular configuration before the other players. When such a configuration is done, the player says "TRIS" and puts the cards in his score stack. Another hand is dealt and so on, until the cards are over.

The scoring differs in the three version of the game (Base, Medium and Difficult). In the base games it is simply the number of cards captured, while in the other versions also the numbers on the cards are taken into account.
mechanics: Pattern Building, Simultaneous Action Selection, Tile Placement

name: Das Rasante Kunstflugspiel
description:
Or: "Hexagames - Sonderanfertigung für die 1. Spielertage, Essen 1983 - Das Rasante Kunstflugspiel - Mit do-it-yourself Spielregeln" (*) to give it it's full title. ("Hexagames - Specially made for the first Essen Game Fair 1983 - The Speedy Stunt Plane Game - With Do-it-Yourself Rules")

This must be the most unremarkable game to have ever been presented on any of the Essen game fairs if it wasn't for a very small detail: it was the first promotional give-away game on the Essen fair ever. It was possibly also an entry in a whole new genre: make-it-up-yourself-gaming. Jürgen Hagedorn from Hexagames was simply handing out 20x35cm sheet of paper, with a hand-drawn game board on it. Stuck to a corner was a small bag with 4 wooden cylinders and a dice. The drawing was very suggestive, but had no rules.

Whilst freebies continued to be used by various companies in an effort to get noticed, they often took the shape of fashionable and pointless pins that people could stick on their clothes, or, after a more inspired moment by Jumbo, were god's gift to gamers on Essen: jumbo-sized carrier bags - with appropriate logo of course.

It took until 1995 before the next noteworthy Essen promo-expansion appeared: Goldsieber's 13th constellation for "Sternenhimmel" (although this was not free). Kosmos followed in 1998 with a "robber-gang-figure" for "Die Siedler von Catan", probably embarrassed by the success of the game and in a genuine effort to thank the fans. But it wasn't until Hans im Glück released a player's expansion for its "El Grande" that the promo floodgates truly opened.
The game itself, off course, hardly got noticed and was easily forgotten. What do you expect from a sheet with a large plane and a game-of-goose type track of fluffy clouds that have different shapes but lack any explanation?

Nevertheless, now the "Essen Freebie Game (Expansion)" has became a bit of an institution, it might be time to pay tribute to the very first one: Hexagames, we salute you with a BGG entry for what must have been a great laugh.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Mickey Mouse Card Game
description:
The side of the card packet displays the name as the "Mickey Mouse Card Game" while the front cover displays the name as the "Mickey Mouse: Educational Card Game" and inside card instruction displays the name as the "Mickey Mouse Number Game".

Most of the cards have either green circles that represent Mickey Mouse, red circles that represent Donald Duck, blue circles that represent Pluto, or yellow circles that represent Goofy.

The game can be played with two to four players. The four-player game can be played with a set of two partners. The game begins with each player being dealt 4 cards. Three cards are placed face up in the middle of a table, although the 3-player game requires five cards to be placed face up in the middle of the table instead of three.

Players can claim cards in three ways.

1. By matching: A player can claim a card that matches on in his or her hand.
2. By combining: If there is a Mickey Mouse "Lucky One" on the table, a player can form a +1 addition equation to place this card on another card already on the table and pick it up with a next highest number card in the player's hand.
3. By building: A player can attempt to form an addition equation to pick up a set of cards. For example: If there is a "3" on the table, a player can place a "4" on a "3" to build a "7". If player can use a "7" card next round to pick up the "4" and "3". However, this player could lose this "4 + 3" in two ways. Another player could take this "4 + 3" before next turn by playing a "7", or another player could attempt to build a higher number equation by placing another card on the "4 + 3" stack. However, a player cannot build unless he or she has a card to pick up the stack.

A player that cannot match, combine, or build must place one card on the table. The player making the last play takes any cards left on the table. A player gets 3 points for having the most cards, 2 points for a Lucky 2, 2 points for a Lucky 10, and 1 point for a Lucky 1. The player or team that is the first to get 25 points wins the game.
categories: Card Game, Comic Book / Strip, Math, Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanics: Hand Management, Set Collection, Team-Based Game

name: Whistler Challenge
description:
Be the first player to complete a day trip to Whistler (in B.C. Canada).

-Drive the awesome route from Horseshoe Bay to Whistler Village

-Ski three challenging runs on the mountains

-Then return to Horseshoe Bay

Box Contains:
1 Gameboard
1 Die
6 Pawns
20 "miss turn" tokens
18 Ski run medals
11 Chance cards
11 Apres ski cards
6 First aid cards

name: Batman: The Robin Climbing Game
description:
All players start on the street. The youngest player spins first and moves his/her playing piece the number shown on the spinner. Play continues with the next player on the left.

Players can move from side to side along ledges, and they can move up using fire escape ladders, windows, or Batropes.

The first player to climb from the street to the top of the building and saves Robin wins.
categories: Comic Book / Strip, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Lako's School Days Game
description:
Lako's School Days Game is an education board game for children ages 4 and up. During game play, players draw cards with pictures such as red pizza, blue mittens or yellow giraffes and then attempt to classify the pictures into color, number and object categories. In a turn, a player may count grapes or socks, match blues or reds, and group donuts with food or squirrels with animals. Success moves Lako along the game board’s sidewalk path and the winner is the first to get Lako to the red schoolhouse.

Along the way, children land on Lako spaces which award school activity cards such as Lako doing homework at his desk, or Lako showing his name tag in show & tell. These cards educate kids about school activities and create a positive attitude toward them by rewarding children with advances on the board.
publishers: Ninety Longview Inc., Start Space Games

name: Submission
description:
From the publisher's website:
Submission was developed for the true wrestling fan, by true wrestling fans. Whether you watch wrestling on television, or attend local wrestling events, this game will test your wrestling knowledge to the fullest in a fun and creative way. With 7 intense modes of gameplay, over 100 unique categories, the INSANITY of the Tap Out Deck, and Mini-Games that really mix things up, you and your friends can battle it out for hours, until one person is crowned the Submission Champion!

name: Calculink
description:
From the publisher's website:
Calculink is an adventurous math game that enhances your mental arithmetic as you link numbers to reach certain totals. Points are scored on each play and extra for bravery, while strategy is used to avoid traps and to block your opponents. You learn to master several math skills through the popular Calcutest cards, which offer fun-filled exercises on a range of school-based topics. And if you are a lucky, you just might pull the right Cue Card to give you that edge on your opponents.

name: Balancing Act Challenge
description: Balancing Act Challenge is based on the Canadian government's Canada's Food Guide To Healthy Eating, which organizes nutritional needs into four food groups: grain products, milk products, vegetables & fruit, and meat & meat alternatives. The object of the game is to be the first player to collect the required number of each food group's Serving Cards. There are challenge squares that would allow players to challenge each other for food-serving cards. If a player lands on the Canadian flag, they may move anywhere on the board.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Raising Cattle
description: Raising Cattle is a family game which shows you the obstacles that Ranchers and Farm families have to deal with on a daily basis. Roll the dice and move your way around the board. Watch out for the Cow Pies - they can be both good and bad. The first player to collect 12 Calf's wins the game, if you don't run out of Hay first.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Syncrohearts
description: Syncrohearts is a game designed to bring a couple closer together. Some spaces require the players to hug, kiss or massage each other. Players will go around the board once. There are also four categories of cards including “Couple”, “4-Fun”, “Hot Stuff” and “Insights”. When a player lands on one of these categories, they select the top card and answer the questions or follow the directions. If they are not comfortable with the questions or directions then they can select another card or pass their turn. Players will typically both answer any card that asks a question.

name: Persona: O Jogo das Mutações
description: Bizarre party game from the 70's: Players turn the lights off, take some candle and, then, look each other through the double sided mirrored glass, hence fusing the reflections shown on each side of the glass. The game develops around a kind of flux of consciousness emanated from interaction between players and images. The author developed the first version of this game as a conceptual art installation first exhibited at the XII Art Biennal of São Paulo (1973).
publishers: Steps Produtos Didáticos e Recreativos Ltda.

name: The Amazing Chan and the Chan Clan Game
description:
1973 Hanna-Barbera Productions, Inc.

OBJECT:
To be the first player to bring Charlie the missing clue that correctly matches the clue space on which Charlie is standing.
categories: Children's Game, Deduction, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Locarno: Europe 1926
description:
Locarno - Europe 1926 seeks to portray the restored "Concert of European Powers" following the Treaty of Locarno, Oct. 1925. Players assume the role of European statesmen seeking to outclass their geopolitical rivals and attain a position of predominance.

The game is based upon Allan B. Calhamer's classic Diplomacy. However, its treatment of minor powers is strikingly different as these have their own military units. Players secretly bid influence points in order to obtain the support of these lesser powers.

Re-implemented by:

The Road to War: Europe 1936
mechanics: Area Movement, Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Il Ribaltone
description:
"Il Ribaltone" is a game on Italian politics. It focuses players' attention to the intrigues and machinations that made the Italian governments so weak during the First Republic.
Each player takes the role of a political party. His goal is to achieve the most political influence by cumulating the head chief offices inside the Government during the 5 years covered by the game.
Laws "ad personam", scandals, bankruptcies, breakdowns of institutions, strange affairs, volatile alliances, backstabbing, riots inside the Parliaments... everything can happen during a match.

This game design project has been abandoned in 2007.

name: Giants and Castles
description: Players move their Giants around the board, ripping castles apart looking for treasure rooms. First player to acquire 4 treasure rooms (as the giants are trying to build their own golden castles) wins the game. Each player gets 5 actions points a turn. Action points can be spent to move to an adjacent space, pick up an adjacent room from the top of a castle or giant’s stack, place the top room of your stack on an adjacent square, or cast a spell, provided you have enough rooms to give to the local sorceresses.

name: Hearts Playing Board Game
description:
The version has two different games.

The first game involves players moving playing pieces from start to finish. Players attempt to take tricks of balloons, stars, and flowers while avoiding the hearts. The player taking the highest numbered card in the leading suit takes the trick. After all cards are played, players move their markers ahead 1 space for each non-heart and back 1 space for each heart.

The second game determines movement by using cards and a spinner.
mechanics: Hand Management, Roll / Spin and Move, Trick-taking
publishers: Tee Pee Toys, Jessup Paper Box Co.

name: Mental Blocks "The Block Party"
description:
This game is published by Perigee Books, a member of The Putnam Publishing Group, in The United States and by General Publishing Company in Canada under the exclusive license from The Stonesong Press, Inc. "The Block Party" is a trademark of The Putnam Publishing Group.

This game is made up of 16 cubes that allow players to find up to 96 pictures and almost 2000 pictorial variations by arranging the cubes into four-by-four squares or other patterns.

The game has three levels of difficulty, or you can create your own game.

"Block Party" is the first version to be published in a material other than wood.
mechanics: Memory, Pattern Building, Pattern Recognition, Team-Based Game

name: Billion Dollar Player
description:
From the publisher:

The top sports stars receive many income opportunities. Players sign deals, receive awards, and lead their sports in categories that help and hurt their earning potential. Poor performance in their sport reduces the next contract offer sheet. The wrong endorsement deal can ruin an image and cause a player to miss out on millions of dollars. Now, the average fan has the opportunity to make money like the best athletes around today. Play Billion Dollar Player to win!


From the games website, doesn't look like this game is in print anymore. (March 2007)

name: Tenpin To Go
description: Tenpin To Go is a tabletop bowling game, which includes ten plastic pins and a metal ball as well as a cardboard lane. Players take turns setting up and knocking down pins and scoring their frames.

name: Mad Manic Move
description:
Mad Manic Move is a family game of moving home.
Players must travel around the board, visiting places as indicated by their 'on the move' card, chosen at the start of the game.
With a variety of cards and pitfalls throughout the game, mad manic move is a fast paced, fun game taking a dig at difficulties of moving home.
The objective of the game is to collect all 9 house cards, answering trivia questions all the way, before moving into you new home.
categories: Humor, Maze, Party Game, Puzzle, Trivia
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Antburger Hill
description:
“The spiders are on the march, they have their sights set on Antburger Hill, Grid Ref. 86N 27.4E.
The bugle sounds and Ants scurry to man hurried fortifications. With stout hearts the defenders stand in wait for the spiders to rush their hill.”

The ants must defend their anthill against the rush of the spider hordes.

“Hold that hill at all costs.”

Using cunning and tactics, deploy your troops carefully against the rampant spider horde.
Win or lose the ants must defend their homes against the spider attack.
Its up to you to stop the spider advance before they destroy the whole ant colony.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Fighting, Humor, Modern Warfare, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Modular Board, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Fish'n Derby
description: Compete at the Fish'n Derby on this lake on a board. Travel around the lake to find the best fish'n spot and go fishing. If you're in the right spot, you automatically catch a fish. If you're not in the best fish'n spot, then you must roll high enough to catch a fish. The fish you catch will range in weight from 1 to 10 lbs at various lengths. Each round only lasts so long as you must decide what fish to keep or throw away. At the end of each round, compete for one of the three trophies. Win all three and win the game.

name: Hog Auction
description: Each player owns a farm. The goal of each player is to expand their farms after making money at the hog auction. To do this, farmers must buy pigs one round and sell them when they get back to the auction. On the way back to the auction the market could fall and a farmer could lose money or a natural disaster could hit a player's farm an he could lose a barn. There are all kinds of questions that each farmer must ask him/herself during game play. How much should I bid on pigs? Should I buy insurance risk it? Can I afford to expand my farm right now?

name: Grow2Learn
description:
From the publisher's website:
GROW2LEARN is an educational series of six card games that use the same board. Focused on memory retention and cognitive learning development, the six activities progress for various levels of comprehension. This game was developed for children in pre-K to grade two.
1) Build early memory and picture-matching skills.
2) Develop phonics skills in beginning sounds.
3) Enhance shape, color, and visual-perceptual skills.
4) Learn addition with number exercises.
5) Improve math skills, focusing on subtraction.
6) Match the pictures to the cards and build picture-word skills.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Educational, Math, Memory, Word Game

name: Citibank Worldwide Banking Game
description: This game was designed for the First National City Bank of New York, which has since become Citibank. The objective of the game is to collect the cards representing the 7 banking services offered by the bank in 1964, Savings Account, Checking Account, Trust Service, Overseas Service, Personal Banking, Travelers Checks, and Loan Service. Once a player has collected he or she can declare CITIBANK at which point all of the players total up the dollar amounts on the cards that they have collected and the player with the highest total wins. Cards are collected by landing on spaces around the board after rolling. Once cards are collected they are placed face down on the table in front of the player.
mechanics: Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Spotta
description: The board has a large picture of a leopard without spots. Before the game, players place black spots with a particular word (all of which make a phrase with the word "spot") face down. Players then draw cards with a word and must find the appropriate spot on the leopard.

name: Reflex
description: First player selects a desired pattern or combination on the three dice. The three dice are rolled, and if the combination matches, the first player to drive his "scorer" up the wire loop to the center gets the point.

name: The New Kid's Choices Board Game
description:
Applying Biblical Principles to Everyday Situations

You wanted a stereo CD player for your birthday, and made sure that your grandparents knew it. They've given you an encyclopedia program for the family computer instead. What will you say to them?

A student in charge of lunch tickets has given you too many tickets for the money you gave him. What will you do with the extra tickets?

You don't like the clothes your mom buys for you. You prefer denim and T-shirts. What will you tell her?

Making the right choice can be tough. But with the help of Kid's Choices, learning to make the best decisions becomes exciting entertainment!

Grab your family or your friends (or both!) and get ready to come face to face with some of life's toughest decisions, including those involving friendship, forgiveness and obedience. Learn how to base all your decision making on biblical principles (twenty in all, supported by several verses from the popular NIV® translation of the Bible).

Designed for Ages 6 - 12, The New Kid's Choices is great game play for three to six players, and can also be played in teams. Includes colorful game board, six player markers, 150 dilemma cards, 10 principle cards and an instruction/reference booklet.

name: The Senior Prom Game
description:
"All the thrills of a social season and a chance to be a .... Prom Queen"

A very cheaply made game by 'Built Rite'. The Senior Prom Game is a simple roll and move game for children. The game board is made out of thin cardboard and features 2 different tracks to move around depending on an initial spin with the spinner. Even the playing tokens are made out of cheap cardboard.

Some out of date and stereo-typical items are found on the game board including....

"Meet new boy at game. Wow! Run ahead 3 spaces."

"Dance with T.V. idol at sock hop. Move ahead 6 spaces."

"Study for finals with boy friend. Move ahead 2 spaces."

name: Rune Blade's Gulf War 1991
description:
From the website:
In 1990, Saddam Hussein engineered the invasion and occupation of Kuwait, giving Iraq control of 24% of the world's oil supplies. January 1991, The United States and her allies launch Desert Shield and Desert Storm in an effort to remove the brutal dictator's forces from Kuwait. The First Gulf War was underway.
