With the pieces from your "Axis & Allies" games and some others, then YOU can embark upon this 'Global' encounter. No longer is it restricted BY just the actual "Area of Operations", as the entire WORLD with 'this' has their 'say' for things. Declare a "Jihad!", tout your "Scientolo-dogma", "Kill for OIL!", it could ALL be there, so YOU 'be' there or be-hind!
mechanics: Area Movement, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling

name: Midway
description:
The game includes a 5 3/4", 4 1/2", by 1 1/2" box that includes a 11" x 17" game map, 3 pages of rules, 55 cut-out U.S. counters, 63 cut-out Japanese counters, 18 flag markers, and a D10. The game is a type of expansion for Axis and Allies, but it might be possible to use this with other games too. An alternative scenario simulates the battle as if the U.S. had not broken the Japanese code.

This expansion doesn't seem to be an official expansion.

Expands:

Axis & Allies

name: Get Rich
description:
The chess-like board is mostly water, with "islands" in the middle. Each player has a homeland in a corner of the board with 3 ports.

Units are naval vessels, aircraft, air/naval bases and construction units.

Players purchase units with money and fight it out their military units to become the richest player by the end of the game.

A full set includes:

4 fact sheets (purchase prices, move/fire/range info)
Money (play money)
Equipment pieces for 4 countries
4 Flag markers
Generic air & naval base markers and damage markers
2 air-range measures
4 dice

I'm not sure how many of these were produced; mine is an original, mimeographed in a printed folder.

name: Massive Star Corps
description:
Based on the earlier 'Star Corps: Call to Battle'

Updated that game with new movement and combat rules and adds an alternating action system.

Includes:

Pink (black print) cover for the package
12-page rulebook
(5) counter & play aid cards
(10) cards with 4-6 unit status cards on each
(2) blank of the above (for personal mods)


http://www.teamfrog.com/fig-sc.htm
categories: Miniatures, Science Fiction, Space Exploration, Wargame

name: Card Games For Two
description:
Book (150 pages) describes and analyzes nine two-player card games:
Piquet
Klaberjass
Demon Patience
Ecarte
Six-pack Bezique
Gin Rummy
Cribbage
Two-handed Bridge
Canasta

name: Crow Hunt
description:
This 1931 game from Parker Brothers was advertised as a splendid shooting game. Crows were inserted on a slide at the rear of a target and automatically appear one at a time. Using a repeating rifle which shot 6 elastic bands, the object was to hit the birds who slid down the ramp and into an opening in the background target. When you hit one the next one slid down into place. Each bird that you hit was worth 1 point. The last bird hit was a duck named "Elmer" He was worth 5 points if you successfully hit him. First person to get 25 points won the game.

the ad for the game stated that additional ammunition (60 elastic bands) were available for 30 cents from Parker Brothers.

name: Teddy Bear Panda and His Friends
description:
This game is for young people. It was designed to teach them their A, B, C's. The object of the game was simple. The first person to move his piece from a to y and z wins the game.
Color determines the move. Each player selects a piece to move (Panda, Kitty, etc. The a player spins the arrow and depending on which color shows up he/she moves to the corresponding colored letter. Other players spin and then place their piece on the first unoccupied letter with the color that they spun. First person to get to y or z (both winning letters) wins the game.
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Racing, Word Game
mechanics: Pattern Recognition, Roll / Spin and Move

name: How a Bill Becomes a Law in Pennsylvania
description:
How a Bill Becomes a Law in Pennsylvania, a Game About the Legislative Process

A game booklet printed and distributed by the Pennsylvania House of Representatives. Subtitled, "A game about the legislative process". Players draw cards that give them the opportunity to try to get a bill made into a law. Drawing cards and moving around the board. One player wins when he manages to get the following three cards. 1. Bill Passes House 2. Bill Passes Senate and 3. Governor Signs Bill.

name: Groovy Girls Pet Show Game
description:
From the publisher:

The Pet Show Game brings the Groovy Girls and their pets together for a fun competition.The pets perform some amazing tricks, with the help of the groovy owners, of course. Game contains Game board, spinner, 4 tokens with bases,2 flying disk dice, 25 game cards, 12 award ribbon cards,3 hurdles and 6 power jump cards.

Includes game board, spinner, 4 tokens with bases, 2 flying disk dice, 25 game cards, 12 award ribbons, 3 hurdles, 6 jumps power cards.

Challenges memory, spelling and sequencing skills
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Educational, Memory, Word Game
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Memory, Roll / Spin and Move

name: DiceHoldem
description:
Who needs cards? DiceHoldem™ is the Ideal Portable Poker Game! Played just like Texas Holdem!

Players use a combination of guile and luck, bluff and planning, to compete for the pot.

Using unique dice with the letters H, O, L, D, E, and M on them, players compete to make "hands" of the best combination of their 2 player dice and the 5 community dice. The betting rounds are the same as Texas Holdem and each one rolls another community die.

Variants are included for faster play, advanced play, and "Can't Holdem" (a two-player variant that has players bid for a guess at one of five dice that are thrown).

Set includes a zippered carrying pouch.

name: Het Grote Piramidespel
description:
Get me the magical heart scarab of pharaoh Cheops. It lays in the royal tomb chamber of the great pyramid. The god Seth wants it, and you will obey him. Therefore you must go find the magical scarab. Throw the dice and try to be the first to find it.

"Het grote piramidespel" was included with comic N°21 of the series of Papyrus.
You roll the dice and answer to the trivia questions if you answer is right, you have luck, if it's not, you don't.

note: the game was also included with comic N°22 of the series
of papyrus, with new characters and questions. This way it's possible to play the game with 12.
categories: Adventure, Ancient, Comic Book / Strip, Trivia
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: King Solomon's Lost Mine
description:
Players race into the depths of a lost mine to recover a rainbow colored gem that will prove that this indeed is
- King Solomon's Lost Mine.

name: Zapt
description: In Zapt, players roll three dice and can choose a numbered space to place a chip. Lining up four chips will score. Players can choose on there turn to try to get closer to four in a row or to try and block an opponent (which is when you "Zapt" them.). The modular board means that each game can be different than the previous one.

name: ABO Game
description: Romance and Dating game based on the Japanese fascination with Blood Types and how they determine personality. Move around the board and find a suitable match from the available partners but make sure you use the "Blood Tester" to see if your "ketsu-eki-gata" match!!

name: Pikachu no Tankentai Ki Nobori Gemu
description: "Pikachu's Tree-climbing Explorer Game". Another in the enormous line of Pokemon merchandise. A game for children Ages 7 and up played on a double-sided board and using building blocks to simulate tree climbing.

name: Kinchan no Shukan Kinyoubi
description: Kinchan no Shukan Kinyoubi or "Kinchan's Weekly Friday Game". Based on the 1980's Japanese TV Variety show. Players move around the board answering questions and competing in several mini-games.

name: Homestay Snoopy
description: Join Snoopy and his pals as they travel around the world and make new friends in this Japan-only game. Collect a variety of travel cards and use them to move from country to country.

name: Ai-Jo Monogatari
description: Prepare for the perfect wedding day in this Japanese children's game. Race around the board collecting all the things necessary for your big event and the winner will receive the "golden" bracelet and the entitlement to lord it over her envious rivals until the next session.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Ultraquiz 91
description: Japanese trivia game based on popular TV show from the early 90's where students competed to earn a trip to the USA. Contains over 2500 questions on American culture. Players take turns playing the role of quizmaster, the others must be the first to press their "buzzer" to be able to answer.
categories: Memory, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Travel, Trivia

name: Ai-Nori
description: Romance and travel game based on the popular Japanese TV show. Travel around the world and collect objects that make you a better romantic match with other players. At the same time other players will be trying to sabotage your chances. The winners will be the boy and girl who successfully make a matching couple.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Team-Based Game

name: Gaiking
description: Based on the 1976 cartoon (also known as "Giant Sky Demon Dragon Gaiking"). Players use the built in roulette wheel to move around the various sections of the board and battle the alien enemies.

name: The Great Cake Chase
description:
An exciting game of colors, counting, and sharing. Teaches Biblical values!
Kids: Help Christopher Churchmouse's friends find what they need to bake a cake for Christopher's birthday! But watch out for Tuffy the Cat! Based on the popular Christopher Churchmouse Classics written by Barbara Davoll and illustrated by Dennis Hockerman.

name: Ben Hur
description:
A colorful antique boardgame based on the epic chariot race from the novel Ben Hur.

Components include large game board, four wooden pawns, and two spinners. The rules are printed on the bottom of the box.

name: The Never Ending Feelings Game
description:
A game intended to assist in teaching positive reactions to processing feelings, to assist in learning social skills, and to get adults and/or children talking.

A totally noncompetitive with no winners or losers.

CONTENTS: 144 cards, 8 playing pieces, laminated game board, 1 die, instruction booklet.

name: The Christmas Stocking Game
description:
An antique children's card game of toys and presents brought by Santa Claus. "The game may be played by any number of persons."

32 gift cards, 11 Christmas stocking cards, and a Santa Claus card (unknown if complete, rules do not specify the number of cards).

name: Major League Baseball Game
description:
The wooden frame game box folds open to display the baseball field on one half and a large spinner on the other half. The spinner lists various results in two concentric rings - "hit", "ball", "strike" and "out" appear all around the outermost ring, while various other results appear sporadically in the inner ring ("foul", "fly to center", "hit to right", "out at first", etc.)

Lineup cards for various teams are included. The selected teams are inserted into the playing field and list the players for various teams of the era. The playing field has holes in it for wooden playing pieces to track scores, runners on base, the positions of players in the field, etc. Strikes, balls, and outs are tracked with rotating wheels.

name: The Jury Box
description:
This Parker Brothers game series from the thirties is somewhat similar to the modern murder mystery party game genre. Each game in the series included six cases and twelve crime scene photos.

The game is currently being reprinted by On-Line-Products. The following information is from their website:

"Unlike modern murder mystery party games, which are elaborate affairs that sometimes require extravagant character portrayals, The Jury Box is a more informal, easy to play party game. The players are members of a jury who get to examine evidence against an accused person. They each then try to unravel the case and decide if the defendant is guilty or innocent."

"Each series of The Jury Box comes complete with six different court cases that you get to solve. The cases have an outline with state's evidence against the defendant, along with two pictures of the crime scene and ballots for the jurors to cast their verdicts. You even get the actual solutions to these realistic cases."

name: Strawberry Shortcake Card Game
description: Play along with Strawberry Shortcake and all her Strawberryland friends in this berry fun card game. Match pairs of cards to get rid of the ones in your hand. The player who has the special "Berry Card" when all the pairs of cards have been matched is the winner.

name: Read and Rhyme Memory Match
description:
This game is published by Judy/Instructo, a division of Frank Schaffer Publications, Inc. It appears to be recommended for children Ages 5 - 8

It consists of 10 nursery rhyme cards and 30 word cards. The word cards are shuffled and spread face down. Each player chooses a nursery rhyme card and places it in front of him or her. Players take turns picking up a word card and reading it aloud. If the word rhymes with the boldfaced word on his or her nursery rhyme card, the player keeps it and takes another turn. The game continues until one player has collected all three words for his or her nursery rhyme. That player must then read the proper completed nursery rhyme to win the game.
mechanics: Memory, Open Drafting, Pattern Building, Pattern Recognition, Set Collection, Storytelling

name: Trick Tock
description:
Children's game from the Nickelodeon TV channel. Players have 30 seconds to name as many items as possible from a given topic. However they must do so while performing a "Nick Trick" (spinning around, flapping their arms, etc.) and also have to obey the "Nick no-no" (Don't move your feet, do blink, etc.). If they make a mistake they'll be "squeaked".

Contents: game board, scoring sheets, 3 decks of cards, player counters, squeaker and timer.

name: Psychedelic Cipher Caper
description:
Welcome to the late 60's. A spy is selling government secrets by encoding them into the artwork of psychedelic posters. The transfer point is Sy's Psychedelic Disco.

Suspects include:

Sy Silver - owner of Sy's Psychedelic Disco.

Thunder Showers - TV weatherman who is remarkably vain.

April Showers – Ex-wife of Thunder Showers, April is a Go-Go dancer at Sy's Psychedelic Disco.

May Flowers - A genuine child of the 60's, May is a hippy flower child.

Lenny "Thinker" Spencer - a philosophical draft-dodger.

Jean Boaz - a dreamy poet.

Ralph Rubble - a light-hearted jokester, who seldom takes anything seriously.

Teresa Wainwright - a stuck-up rich kid who acts as though she shuns the money upon which she so richly lives.

Unlike a lot of other murder mystery games where you ad-lib, this one provides a script for each player. This is a great way to introduce people into these types of parties. Next time they will feel more comfortable if you choose one where they have to hold a conversation on their own.

Attire and prop suggestions are included.

name: Rock 'N' Jockey
description: A game of skill and accuracy. You're the jockey! You control the horses speed! The excitement of real horse racing! Endless hours of racing fun! Automatic pop-up finish line! From 2 to 4 players.

name: Fractals!
description: Fractals!(tm) provides an exceptional challenge as all players simultaneously work to find a home for their tiles on the game board. The first person to place all their tiles wins. The name of the game is derived from the property that the game board itself is an enlarged image of the tiles being placed. Each placed tile will be a member of four interlocking numerical series that appear on the tile diagonals. There is a built-in tutorial game for learning how to play Fractals!. But really it's not hard: Anyone who can count to nine can play. Even though there are 320 game pieces!

name: Global Conflict: Vietnam 1970
description:
From the website: "Vietnam - 1970
After the defeat of the Japanese in the Pacific, America had to formulate a policy for Asia and the rest of the world. As allies of Ho Chi Minh's fighters against the Japanese, it is clear that the U.S. had several choices in Indochina. The decision to back the French, attempting to regain control of the region, led to America's eventual involvement, and all the consequences thereof. The war that ended in 1973 had led to all of the following: 57,661 U.S. servicemen dead, 2 million Vietnamese dead, the first military defeat for the U.S., internal turmoil in the U.S., distrust of the government and military, the devastation of much of Vietnam, and many other things. Is it possible the war could have turned out differently? It is up to you to decide..."

Now YOU can take over where "Nixon" failed! Send them 'Tin Soldiers' far away FROM the grounds of "Kent State" et al, and unto the "killing fields" where they belong. Using your 'A&A' pieces along with some others, then you too can attempt to "rectify" the situation in Southeast ASIA, where the "domino effect" concerning 'Communism' was at its height! SEE if the "Bombing Cambodia" Campaign would have truly been 'effective', OR perhaps an EXTRA couple 100-thousand 'Troops' might have "done the deal" instead. Here's your chance to "re-write" some gaming 'History', and either rise UP to the 'occasion', or 'go down' through "Defeat in detail" with THIS!
mechanics: Area Movement, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Team-Based Game

name: Färg & Form
description:
This game is for children Ages 4 and up and is used to learn different types of shapes, and also to recognize color and to be able to see a relation between shape and color.

You divide all the tiles by color and shape.

Then you take turns drawing bits from the pouch, trying to find a specific shape and color. You can see from your tiles which bits you are missing and so you try to find those in the pouch.

You can also see the other players tiles and so you know if there is only one of a specific bit left in the pouch, and try to get that one and in doing so you stop an opponent from completing his tiles. This gets you a point at the end of the game.

The winner is the one who first get all bits on the tiles or who has the highest point total.

name: Tonobeb
description:
A dice game described in the premier issue of Gameplay Magazine (February 1983) played on a 7 square by 14 square board. The dice are not rolled, but instead moved around the board as pieces. Each player starts with six dice. one of each pip-strength from 1 to 6 in opposite corners of the board.
Pieces move horizontally or vertically the number of spaces shown on the top face of each die, or one space more or one less. If moved more or less the value, of the die is changed to show the actual number of spaces moved.
Units can be eliminated from play in one of three ways called "eliminating," "capturing," and "fourwalling."
"Eliminating" is landing on an opposing piece by exact count, removing it from play.
Pieces are captured by placing opposing pieces on either side, adjacent, and replacing it with a die of the opposing player's color.
"Fourwalling" is blocking a piece from moving its required number of spaces in every direction. Fourwalled pieces are removed from play.
The object of the game is to eliminate all opposing pieces.

name: Trollerispelet
description:
Each player gets a magician as his game piece.
It is up to each of the magicians to mesmerize their opponents with their tricks. The magician needs to collect five magical accessories during the game. A wand, a hat, a deck of cards, a bow tie and a cape.
There is five real magic tricks included in the game which you shall try your opponents to not guess the correct answer. Because if the do, they get one of the magical accessories needed to win the game.

The player who manage to collect the five accessories first is the winner.

name: I Got It!
description:
This game is similar to BINGO with the following differences:

- each board is made up of combinations of 5 shapes (circle, rectangle, triangle, square & hexagon) and the numbers 1-10.
- there are 2 spinners which each player in turn spins both to obtain a shape/number combination to match to their board.
- each player has their own turn and do not share the combos obtained on their spins with the other players.
- if the shape/number combo isn't present or has already been filled on their board, that player may choose to re-spin one of the 2 spinners for a chance to get a combo that they do need.
- like in BINGO, the first player to complete a horizontal, vertical or diagonal row of 5 wins!

This game is great for Ages 4 - 10 for teaching number and shape recognition.

name: Tickityboo
description:
Tickityboo(tm) is a game similar to Stubborn(tm), but with hexagonal tiles, and more of them. The hexagonal tiles mean that each tile has six large triangles, each of a different color...Stubborn has only four large triangles and hence only four colors. Each Tickityboo tile is therefore a member of 6 different numerical series.
Despite its increased intricacy, Tickityboo is begun just like Stubborn, by placing the specially marked Starting Tile face up on the table. Each player then takes 9 tiles blindly from the remaining total of 143 tiles still face down on the table. When there is more than one player they take turns, but unlike in Stubborn, in Tickityboo each player becomes "vulnerable" if they cannot place a tile, and the another player can move an overlooked tile, and discard one of their own tiles to the vulnerable player's pile.
Like the other games in the "Mining Order From Chaos"(tm) series, Tickityboo is a great solitaire game. It supports up to nine players, however, to make an engaging pastime for a small party or a third of a normal classroom.

name: Zoo ver-rückt
description: Players Ages 5 and up try to find the animal that the starting player has selected and hidden.

name: Dinorennen
description:
This is the prototype of a so far unreleased game and a birthday gift by the designers. My guess is that even Friedemann forgot about this small little game and I am the only one left with a copy.
Each player gets a Dino and tries to be the first one reaching the red winning zone with 13 victory points earned through winning fights. Moving and fighting is done with the same cards. The better movement cards are also the ones with the higher combat value so card management is vital. One of the nicest aspects of the game: I always start (says the rules). The publisher is actually "Spiel-Bau-Stelle" with is was the forerunner of 2-F Spiele.

name: Wiretap
description:
In Wiretap each player constructs a 5x5 grid containing "wires," which are single, double, triple, and quadruple lines, exactly three spaces long. The grid must contain ten wires, one in each row and one in each column. A specific number of each type must be used.

A turn consists of each player simultaneously choosing a space to ask about; the opponent just reveals the number of wires in the selected space.

When a player thinks they can reoonstruct their opponent's grid they announce this. They win if they are correct or produce a grid with the same number of wires in every space as the correct grid. If they are incorrect their opponent gets a double victory if playing a series of games.

Variants are given for a 6x6 board and for using some longer wires.

name: Crystalmancer
description:
Crystalmancer is a strategy card game of magic, power, luck and politics. A game where players struggle to be the first to hold enough of the mystic crystals to rule over the world, for he that holds enough of the mystic crystals is the only true Crystalmancer. Players will take on the role of a might wizard, one that seeks to collect the many mystic crystals that lay about the fantasy landscape. These crystals hold magic power, power that will allow you to summon great magic, and to control mighty beasts. These crystals are thus used to wage mystical war on your foes, all in the hope of defeating them and their own goal of possessing the needed crystals to become your master instead of you becoming theirs.

Within the game you get well over 40 monstrous creature to summon and battle, spell cards and magical items, as well as over 60 crystal cards and more.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Card Game, Dice, Fantasy, Fighting, Print & Play, Wargame
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Fill the Ark
description:
Tiddlywinks variant wherein players attempt to flip animals into 'the Ark'.

Game comes with 4 plastic disks (flippers) and 24 animal disks (2 each of 12 animals). Each player takes 2 each of three different animals (6 total) and attempts to flip them onto the numbered spaces of the game board. When all six animals have been flipped, scores are recorded. High score wins.

The board also has each animal type printed around the edge of the board in a space of its own. A game variant involves flipping animals onto the board in an attempt to get each animal onto its matching board space. The player who gets the most animals into the Ark wins.

name: The Fun Game of Switch
description:
The Fun Game of Switch was published by Built Rite and is for Boys & Girls Ages 5-10. It is a simple spin-and-move game with 'Switches' that can alter your direction of movement.

It is a larger sized flat box game that is very colorful. It comes with an insert in the box which serves as the game board, a spinner and 4 wooden pawns.

name: Web of Tears
description:
Yiyia watched as the undead shambled through the broken gates of her soon to be defeated enemies. Long had she plotted and planed for this day, her dark heart pounding with the pent up joy she was having at hearing the screams of the dying on the other side of the high wall. Her house had finally crushed their greatest rivals, and now nothing, no one, stood in their way of taking complete control of the city. A dark elf warrior casually walked up to her and bowed, as was custom among her people. A lower caste member of the dark race must always pay nominal respect to those of higher rank and birth. High born over lowborn, nobles over all others, females over males. That was the law of the Dark Elves, that was the way of the people of the Spider Queen.

This is the game of Web of Tears, a game of politics, intrigue, struggle and conquest. Web of Tears allows players to take control of a Dark Elf noble house, where they then must compete with other Dark Elf houses as each tries to achieve multiple victory conditions and goals. Can you train your nobles to their ultimate in skill, or will you need to amass a great army of slaves and skilled warriors. Maybe you will need to work the political side of the social order and have yourself proclaimed the queen of the city.

Web of Tears uses a unique system of influence peddling, intrigue, political plotting and all out war to allow players to interact in the nastiest of ways.

Can you out smart, out fight and out survive your foes?

The game comes with everything you need to have a great couple of hours of fun.
Over 30 Noble Cards, showing each of their skills and levels of ability.
40 spell cards covering both Arcane and Faith based magic.
80 Special Ability cards covering Warfare, Arcane, Faith and Stealth based skills.
Over 30 Market Cards
6 Noble Houses to play, each having its own special powers and victory conditions.
A massive playing area, which shows the Dark Elf city and its may locations.
And a massive amount of counters
categories: Card Game, Dice, Economic, Fantasy, Fighting, Negotiation, Political, Print & Play
mechanics: Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Secret Unit Deployment, Simultaneous Action Selection, Team-Based Game, Trading, Voting

name: Word Wise
description: Ages 8 and up. This interesting and educational game combines all the standard word games such as Anagrams and Crosswords plus the fun of using picture puns. 100 letters, 40 picture puns, hardwood letter rack for 2, 3, or 4 players.

name: Andromeda Foundation Official Battle Manual
description:
This is a slightly altered version of the rulebook for Battle for Andromeda: Conflict for a Trillion Suns!. It was included as the series rulebook for Galaxy-Foundation Games' other strategic games (Deliverance From Beyond the Stars, The Xenon Empire's Star Wars: Crusade Against the War-Lords, and The Collodian Conspiracy: Science Against Chaos Unleashed), and also appears to have been sold separately. It may have come with some Combat Operations Plots when sold separately (these were used in all of GFG's strategic games).

The cover of the Battle Manual is done in the style of a military field manual. Under the obligatory number (OBM-76A-171) it states "For Fleet Commanders and Officers of Flag Rank." The manual is also marked CLASSIFIED DATA, noting "under official regulations, any attempt to reproduce, pass on, reveal, or place in possession of unauthorized personnel constitutes a violation of military law under the military code, espionage and sabotage acts and is punishable under the penalties regarding treason."

The Combat Operations Plot is a large chart designed to assist in setting the current configuration of your starship. There are 23 separate Operations Plots displayed, each specifying the various ship settings for the forthcoming turn.

The values specified in an Operations Plot include Offensive Power Level, Defensive Power Level, Shield Potential, Counter-Attack Factor, Defense Factor, Sensor Screen Penetration, and Rate of Warp (acceleration and deceleration). Each Operations Plot is given a descriptive name, ranging from the straightforward "Full Shields" and "Total Offensive Weapons Deployment", to more convoluted selections such as "Special High Speed Evasive Action Plan for 'A' Type Beta Battle Cruisers or 'CR' Type 'Gammas'."
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Freddy the Fireman
description: It's a children's race game. Race to be the first to get to your fireman to the fire.

name: Dimitri Donskoi
description: Battle of Kulikovo 1380 between the Russians of Dimitri Donskoi and the Mongols which ended in a victory for Russia. In Russian language only.

name: U.S.I.Q.
description:
U.S.I.Q. By the National Center for Constitutional Studies NCCS 1986

An Exciting Quiz Game to Celebrate the 200th Birthday of the U.S. Constitution

Includes rules for 2 to a classroom full of players. A great teaching aid for US History.

Contents complete.5 Copy's of the Constitution,5 constitution at a glance pamphlets,instructions for two types of play small group and classroom, HUNDREDS OF QUESTION CARDS WITH POINT VALUES.

name: Carlette
description:
From the box: "Monte Carlo in the Home"

Carlette is essentially roulette played with a deck of standard playing cards.

Players bet on whether "Court Cards" (face cards), cards of a specific suit, "evens" of a specific color, or specific cards will appear from the deck. A die is used to determine the cards that will be dealt from the deck and winners are paid.

Components include the betting board, a deck of standard playing cards, a die, red poker chips, a wooden table rake, and the book "Rules of Carlette".

name: Coast to Coast
description:
From the box: "An Educational Action Game for 2 to 4 players. Learn to Know America While Traveling!"

Game board features a map of the U.S. with a built-in spinner. Players travel a circular track around around the map visiting landmarks as they go. A fun way to learn geography!

Players start on NYC, and move the number of spaces indicated by the spinner. Land on a red space, lose a turn. Land on a blue space, go again. First to return to NYC wins.

name: Starluk
description:
From the box: "The Fortune Telling Game"

Players keep score telling each others' fortunes. Rules describe group play as well as more traditional tarot use.

The game was shipped in a book-shaped box (one side was shaped like a curved book spine and the others were printed with a design to make them look like book pages) and included a poker-sized tarot deck, a pad of score sheets, and a rules sheet.

name: The Prep Game
description:
Are you wearing an alligator shirt? A Polo tie? What are you driving? A "woody" station wagon? Did you have a Teddy Bear as a toddler? What clubs do you belong to? THE Country Club?

In The Prep Game, players move their calling cards, with names like Muffy, Sissy, or Corky, around a board, collecting scoring cards and visiting places like "Mummy's and Daddy's," the "Chariot Races," "Miss Comer's Dance Classes," and the "Debut at the Plaza." The players also collect doubling or tripling cards as well while traveling around the board. The first player to 25,000 points wins.

name: Square It
description:
A 2 player game. Players take turns placing tiles into the grid trying to form squares. Completed squares are marked, and the player gets another turn. When the board is filled, the person with the most squares wins.

This game is the same as the paper and pencil game "Dots and Boxes" played on a 7x7 box grid.

The title of the German edition is just "Square". The German word for the traditional paper and pencil game is "Käsekästchen".

name: Le Wine Game
description:
Le Wine Game is a wine tasting party game for 1 to 4 couples.

The host selects four wines, places them on numbered locations on the "game board," and lets each person sample the four wines. A notepad/scoresheet is provided for each couple to take notes on the wines. Then the wines are removed, and the host again distributes samples of each wine to the guests. The guests now attempt to identify the wines using their notes. The first taster or team to call out the correct identification is declared "Wine Judge of the Evening."

The game is designed to help players learn about wine. Wine tasters are encouraged to file away their notes in a note box (provided) so that they may have "a permanent record of all your wine tasting impressions."

name: Carlo Derby
description:
Carlo Derby is a depression era horse racing game. It comes in an orange and white tube with all the components rolled up in an oil cloth track. The game contains a layout cloth, race tickets, ticket punch, five horse and a mixer called the "carlo box". The carlo box contains 6 white marbles, 5 red, 4 blue, 3 green and 1 black.
As the marbles are dispensed, the horses advance. There are three raised felt circles below the track that receive marbles when you push the carlo box down. The track has a fast and a muddy (slow) lane for each horse. For example, the black horse fast track has only one space, which means he finishes the race the first time his marble comes up (1/19). The black horse muddy track has two spaces. You can bet on horses to win, place or show, and the payoff odds are shown on the track. For example, black pays 8.5 to 1 for a win on the fast track or 24 to one for a win on the slow track.
The best part of this game is the quality of the molded glass horses. The tickets are also very realistic looking.
The designer and publication date are unknown. However, the game is described as patent pending, and the company address is 268 First Street in San Francisco.

The "carlo box" could also be found (with the same marbles) in the game Lido

name: One Hundred & One Romantic Nights
description:
One Hundred & One Romantic Nights: A Romantic Game for Lovers

This comes with two custom six-sided dice and an brief instruction brochure in a card-backed plastic bubble package. The two dice have sides that read:

1) Home Escape, Hugs & Kisses, Star Gazing, Talk, Show Time and Love Notes

2) Go for a Drive, Dinner, Picnic, Breakfast, Naughty but Nice and Go for a Walk.

One Hundred & One Romantic Nights is for every couple who believes that there can never be too much romance in their lives. With a simple roll of the dice it's easy to spice up nights & weekends. And with over one hundred combinations, this game guarantees a lifetime of unforgettable romantic nights.

Instructions:
Roll the dice secretly if you plan to surprise your lover, or roll the dice together and start play immediately! Use either one or both dice together and refer to the mini guide for pointers if necessary. Play everyday or once a week, but remember to play regularly. Time & place is always up to you.

Keep in Mind...
Have fun with each roll that you take. Give & take encouragement. Dare to go out on a limb and try something new. Do what you can afford & improvise when necessary. And above all else, enjoy yourself and your loved one at all times.

While the expression of romance has changed over the course of time, the underlying purpose has always remained the same. Romance is about escaping from the grind of everyday life to share a magical moment with the one you love.

Lover's Choice: The Essence of Romance, Carson City, NV
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Simultaneous Action Selection, Team-Based Game

name: Sound Bingo
description:
Be the first to match all your pictures to the sounds!

An electric toy gives away a sound every time you press it. If you have the corresponding animal or thing on your playing board you close the door to it, and the first one to close all the doors wins.

name: Galactic Space Games
description: 6 games in a big book (15.5" x 22.5" - closed). The games are rather simple. The book came with various bingo chips and dice in one corner.

name: Merrycourt
description: An acting and improv game in a Medieval court setting. Present and try up to 40 cases included in the box.

name: Space Pilot
description:
The object of the game is to win the most money by getting to the planets Mercury through Saturn from Earth and claiming their mineral resources. Each player gets a space-o-meter to record the number of millions of miles they have traveled on each leg of the journey. Movement is governed by a spaceship spinner that advances from 10 to 90 million miles per turn. To claim a planet, you have to be the first to have your mileage hit the orbit range of a planet. For example, to claim Mercury, you have to hit the 100 to 130 million mile range. If you go over, you have to reverse your direction and start subtracting mileage for each spin.

Once all planets are claimed, you add up the value of your planets. These range from 10 billion dollars for Mercury's gold to 50 billion dollars for Saturn's plutonium. These are very generous sums for 1951!

This game has rich retro decco graphics. The artwork is very similar to the 2005 Zathura: Adventure is Waiting. In fact, the spaceships are nearly identical.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Racing, Science Fiction, Space Exploration

name: Barnyard Boogie Woogie
description: Hilarious game of pantomime will keep players dancing and singing for hours! Roll the colored die, travel around the barnyard game board collecting farm animals along the way. In order to claim an animal card you must imitate the animal. Oink like a pig, Moo like a cow, waddle like a duck, lots of action for young kids and parents too.
mechanics: Acting, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Zizanie beach
description:
This game comes with Jeux & Stratégie magazine n.17 (January/February 2006)

In what is ultimately an abstract game, two players, each representing a male, compete on an evolving archipelago (which they build in the beginning of the game) and aim to end up isolated with the only girl on the set of islands.

On his turn, the player must first move his own pawn or move the girlfriend, and then move an island to another place in the archipelago.

name: Scrambled Heads!
description:
SCRAMBLED HEADS! - The Crazy Clues Game! is a similar game to HEADBANZ and others of that ilk.

Players take it in turns to be the 'Head Case' by placing a headpiece on their head. A card is placed in the headpiece by another player such that it can be seen by all the players except the one actually wearing the headpiece.

The game card shows three subjects in three different categories - Food and Drink, Entertainment and Miscellaneous. The subject is something that should be familiar to all the players and could be anything from a famous film star to a wild animal.

The 'Head Case' selects whether he wishes clues on the category on the top, middle or bottom row of his card, and is then informed of which particular category the subject belongs to.

The other players then take it in turns to offer clues as to what the subject is. Clues should be relevant to the subject but somewhat distant and slightly cryptic. Clues should not be derived from part of the subject title. The 'Head Case' has 10 seconds to try and guess the text on the card at which point the next player gives another clue.

Tokens are added into a central pile to indicate how many clues have been given - these tokens having been evenly distributed amongst the players at the start of the game. If the 'Head Case' guesses the subject then the player that gave the last clue must collect all the tokens. A player also gains them if he is unable to provide a suitable clue. In the event of the 'Head Case' not guessing the answer within 12 clues he fails and collects all the tokens from the pile,

Another player is then selected as the 'Head Case' and the while process is repeated. Play continues until one of the players runs out of tokens or when all players agree to stop.

name: Suffolk Downs
description: A horse racing game from The Corey Game Company about Boston's own race track, Suffolk Downs.

name: Gridrunner
description: (from the manual) Gridrunner is a strategy game from two to four players. The object of the game is to move your pieces over the board and capture the pieces of the other players. The player with the most pieces at the end of the game wins. Playing time is two to three hours.

name: Yak
description:
From the rule sheet:
Yak is a board game for 2 players, which involves a combination of luck and skill. Typical duration of the game is about 15 minutes.

Objectives:
The object of the game is to move your counters across the board whilst your opponent moves their counters across the board in the opposite direction. The winner is the first player to remove off all of their counters.

Equipment:
A long narrow board marked with 16 squares in a single line. There are 16 counters and 4 dice, 8 white counters plus 2 white dice and 8 black counters plus 2 black dice.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: ConverStation
description:
This game was created by a speech pathologist to ensure that conversation doesn't become a lost art. The designer found that children that are not used to adult conversation will often reply to questions with one-word answers or an answer not related to what the question that they were asked. The game is also helpful for adults that have had strokes, brain injuries, or are attempting to relearn or expand their language skills.

As a player lands on certain colored game board squares in a train track format, a player chooses one of 240 question cards, divided into the four corresponding color categories of "Wh- Questions, "If I...", "Tell about...", and "How do you...". The game cards have three levels: kids, adults, and both.

The companion workbook called ConverStation Graphic Expression teaches people when to express themselves in writing versus conversation.

The board game hit the market in June 2005, winning the 2005 Preferred Choice Award from Creative Child magazine as a Toy of the Year Finalist.

The game is published by Say It Right, a small press educational publisher based in Tybee Island, Georgia. Their website is www.sayitright.org.
categories: Deduction, Dice, Educational, Memory, Trains, Word Game
mechanics: Memory, Roll / Spin and Move, Storytelling

name: Who Do You See?
description:
The Hidden Picture Game That Teaches Biblical Principles!

Another "No Reading Required" game in the "My First Game" series. It plays like "Where's Waldo?" or the "I Spy" games. Find the pictures on your token cards on the action panels.

6 hidden picture cards and 200 hidden picture squares.

Suitable for Ages 4 and up.

name: Beginning Math Roll & Learn Pocket Cubes
description:
Here's an innovative new way to learn Beginning Math skills, plus, as an added bonus, your students will have so much fun they won't realize how much they're learning!

Rather than the same old boring drills, numerous worksheets, or endless practice exercises, introduce your students to an exciting new way of learning with the Roll & Learn Pocket Cubes. The set includes: two pocket cubes made of the same durable material as our pocket charts, 24 learning cards, and a resource guide. The learning cards are designed to slide easily into plastic sleeves that are located on each side of the cube. Each card has either a photograph or colorful text printed on it.

The game instructions vary depending on the skill being taught that day. Some games require both cubes being tossed, while others have students toss one cube and find the correct answer on the remaining cube. The games include: numerals and number sets, shapes, numbers comparisons, as well as simple addition. These games can be played with either the whole class or placed in a learning center for small group or individual play.

This set is a terrific tool for teaching with a kinesthetic approach.

name: Beginning Language Roll & Learn Pocket Cubes
description:
Here's an innovative new way to learn Beginning Language skills, plus, as an added bonus, your students will have so much fun they won't realize how much they're learning! Rather than the same old boring drills, numerous worksheets, or endless practice exercises, introduce your students to an exciting new way of learning with the Roll & Learn Pocket Cubes.

The set includes: two pocket cubes made of the same durable material as our pocket charts, 24 learning cards, and a resource guide. The learning cards are designed to slide easily into plastic sleeves that are located on each side of the cube. Each card has either a photograph or colorful text printed on it.

The game instructions vary depending on the skill being taught that day. Some games require both cubes being tossed, while others have students toss one cube and find the correct answer on the remaining cube. The games include: picture and word matching, alphabetical order, initial sounds, compound words, and long and short vowels. These games can be played with either the whole class or placed in a learning center for small group or individual play.

This set is a terrific tool for teaching with a kinesthetic approach.

name: Deep Space Division Fission
description: Put a mathematical twist on the classic card game "War!" In place of ordinary flashcard drills, players solve basic addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division facts as they try to win all the cards in the deck. (108) 3 inch x 4-1/2 inch cards. 2 or more players.

name: Extreme Action Subtraction
description: Put a mathematical twist on the classic card game "War!" In place of ordinary flashcard drills, players solve basic addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division facts as they try to win all the cards in the deck. (108) 3 inch x 4-1/2 inch cards. 2 or more players.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Educational, Math

name: Underwater Addition Mission
description: Put a mathematical twist on the classic card game "War!" In place of ordinary flashcard drills, players solve basic addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division facts as they try to win all the cards in the deck. (108) 3 inch x 4-1/2 inch cards. 2 or more players.

name: World Vacation Multiplication
description: Put a mathematical twist on the classic card game "War!" In place of ordinary flashcard drills, players solve basic addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division facts as they try to win all the cards in the deck. (108) 3 inch x 4-1/2 inch cards. 2 or more players.

name: Trackin' Animals: Mammals in the African Savanna, Pine Forest, and Ocean
description: Grab your binoculars and join the Wild Goose team on a Trackin’ Animals photo safari! Three different games in each box have players chasing animals across the continents, through the oceans, and even back in time. Collect and assemble animal photos, draw and trade cards to make matching pairs, and correctly answer trivia questions to win these games, but watch out for all kinds of crazy twists when special Wild Cards appear! Each set contains 56 cards and directions for three different games to play. Ages 5 and up.

name: Trackin' Animals: Dinosaurs
description: Grab your binoculars and join the Wild Goose team on a Trackin’ Animals - Dinosaurs photo safari! Three different games in each box have players chasing animals across the continents, through the oceans, and even back in time. Collect and assemble animal photos, draw and trade cards to make matching pairs, and correctly answer trivia questions to win these games, but watch out for all kinds of crazy twists when special Wild Cards appear! Each set contains 56 cards and directions for three different games to play. Ages 5 and up.

name: Short Vowel Lotto
description: Players learn to identify short vowels through rhyming and/or matching activities.

name: Trackin' Animals: Mammals in the Rain Forest, Grassland, and Arctic
description: Grab your binoculars and join the Wild Goose team on a Trackin’ Animals photo safari! Three different games in each box have players chasing animals across the continents, through the oceans, and even back in time. Collect and assemble animal photos, draw and trade cards to make matching pairs, and correctly answer trivia questions to win these games, but watch out for all kinds of crazy twists when special Wild Cards appear! Each set contains 56 cards and directions for three different games to play. Ages 5 and up.

name: Trackin' Animals: Wild & Extreme
description: Grab your binoculars and join the Wild Goose team on a Trackin’ Animals photo safari! Three different games in each box have players chasing animals across the continents, through the oceans, and even back in time. Collect and assemble animal photos, draw and trade cards to make matching pairs, and correctly answer trivia questions to win these games, but watch out for all kinds of crazy twists when special Wild Cards appear! Each set contains 56 cards and directions for three different games to play. Ages 5 and up.

name: Buster Brown and the Goat
description:
A card game featuring Buster Brown, Tige, and friends similar to Old Maid. The Goat is the odd card or the "Old Maid" that you don't want to be caught with or you lose the game!

Rules from the game box:
Deal 3 cards to each player and 3 to the table face up. If the Goat is dealt to the table, he must be put back in the pack shuffled, and a new card dealt to the table in its place.

The first player must make a pair by matching a card on the table with one in his hand if he can, at the same time reading aloud the title of the card, for instance, "I am Buster's Father". He then takes the trick to himself. If he cannot make a pair in that way, then he must play a card on the table, any one he likes, except for the Goat.

After his play, he must then take the top card from the pack, so that he will always hold 3 cards, until the pack runs out, when there are no more cards to draw from. Then, if a player cannot make a pair by matching one on the table, he may make one from his hand. If he can do neither, he must draw a card from his left-hand neighbor and try to make a pair from the table or from his hand, and so on, until the last card remains unplayed which must be the Goat. The player with that card must hold it up and say "I am the Goat."
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Children's Game, Comic Book / Strip, Memory
mechanics: Hand Management, Hot Potato, Memory, Set Collection

name: The New and Fashionable Game of the Jew
description:
Cloth-backed, hand-colored folding engraving with slip cover. Shows a publication date of May 27th, 1807. Board is 18.5 x 16", cover is 7 x 5".

Game is played with two six-sided dice, but while I have pictures of the case and board, I can find no explantion of game play other than this quote from "Deconstructing Sondheim", a March 8, 1993 New Yorker article by Stephen Schiff:

When you enter his five-story town house in midtown Manhattan, the first thing you notice, besides an enormous black poodle named Max, is his antique-game collection: on the walls, in glass museum cases, on various low tables. Most of the items look faintly sinister: here is something called Schimmel, or Ball and Hammer and here an inscrutable British concoction, Squails, and, behind the sofa, his earliest acquisition—the ghastly New and Fashionable Game of the Jew, a dice game devised in 1811 that, according to Sondheim, "taught kids to be anti-Semitic. But all the games you see here are very nice to look at and real boring," he adds. "This thing about games—I'm not really fascinated with games."

--
Looks to be a variation of Gluckshaus. Roll both dice and pay the amount rolled onto the space of the same value. If there is something already on the space, collect it instead. Rolling a 7 always pays to the Jew space. Rolling a 12 collects all the counters on the board.
From: http://www.gamesetal.net/Stock_Pages/GLB/glb3930.htm
publishers: Dunnet and Wallis, E. Wallis, John Wallis

name: I Can Do Anything! Game
description:
The I Can Do Anything! Game is a fun way to learn about what people do for a living. Spin the wheel, move your piece, and tell a wonderful story all about different professions. Then make a wish about what you would like to be when you grow up! The enclosed booklet describes 24 different professions.

Objective: To be the first player to get to the Wish Star and make a wish.
publishers: Geebee Marketing, Inc., Pressman Toy Corp.

name: Trip Trap
description:
Players attempt to negotiate a plastic obstacle course using ball bearings fired from whale shooters. The five obstacles may be arranged in the specific order and layout as suggested in the instructions, or the course can be made harder by increasing the distance between obstacles. Each obstacle has a unique gimmick and name, such as 'Big Dumper' and 'Man With Falling Pants'.

The first player to successfully negotiate all five obstacles is the winner.
mechanics: Modular Board, Point to Point Movement

name: Play the Beats
description:
From the Rules:

"THIS IS A MUSIC FUN GAME."

The object of the game is to take your marker along the music staff starting with the introduction going all the way to FINE.

A game apparently designed to teach musical terminology and note counting.

name: Journey to the Motherland
description:
A cross between Trivial Pursuit, Charades and Pictionary, with an African-American twist.

Take a Journey and discover the history, past and present of great African-Americans who made substantial contributions to building the foundation of America. Journey to the Motherland is an exciting and educational game that highlights black achievement and many areas of historical importance.

Contents: Game Board, Timer, 4 Pawns, 2 Dice, 1 Pencil, 1 Drawing Pad, and the "Guide to the Motherland" Game Booklet

Recommend Ages - "From Little Brother to Grandmother"

name: Cooperation
description:
The goal of this little roll-and-move game is for players to work together to make it to the finish line. Along the way, they have some choices to make as to whether to which path to take and whether to remain together or to go their separate ways. Depending upon where they land, they can draw Gold, Disaster, or Frustration cards that affect them depending on whether they are still with their partner. The goal of the game is to be the player holding the least chips when the finish line is reached.

Per manufacturer advertisement:

"Cooperation? is a hilarious experience. It lets you scheme, practice being crafty, have fun with disaster. Once you've betrayed your partner - and you probably will - watch out! If you choose to cooperate . . . beware!

Cooperation? stands unique among games. It's aim is to beat you, and, since all players are facing this same obstacle, someone has to be the winner.

Score Cooperation? high in entertainment. It's the kind of a game you will want to bring out at a party . . . and all ages can play. Four to six players, in teams of two. You will experience hours of fun and relaxation. "
publishers: KMS Industries Inc. Scientific Games Div.

name: Cityism  -- The Austin Trivia Board Game
description:
What is cityism?

Webster's says nationalism is loyalty to a nation, especially its culture. So cityism is loyalty to a city, especially its culture.
All cities have cool things. But you have to live there to appreciate some of them. Who but Austinites would delight in Spamorama or Eyeore's Birthday Party?

All questions are about Austin.

name: Toggle Logic
description:
Toggle Logic is the umbrella game for two variants, Batel and BaoWei. Played on a standard chessboard, each piece has two distinct sides. Batel is a race to be the first to occupy your opponent's home row. BaoWei has a capture mechanic, with randomness increased through the use of dice.

The Toggle Logic set comes in a 6" closed tube with enough two-colored pieces for either variant. The tube includes a cloth screen-print playing board, two-colored pieces, dice, and instructions. It is self-published by the designer in Lawrence, Kansas.
mechanics: Pattern Building, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Heraldic
description:
A game of matching and capturing; a Bezique-based game - with original elements and developments.

HERALDIC is uniquely designed to create all the problems of Bezique with a pack of only 48 cards. The card designs are based on traditional animals of the hunt and mythical creatures.

Players capture the high-scoring cards in whist-style tricks, then score various combinations of cards on the table and across the table. First player to 1000 points is the winner. Unlike bezique it works well with 2, 3 or 4 players.

name: The Game of Peter Rabbit
description:
First made available to the public in 1995, the design for the game was originally submitted by Beatrix Potter to her publisher, Frederick Warne, in 1904.

The game board - a reproduction of Potter's watercolor original - represents Mr. McGregor's garden, with 12 key points of interest from the book marked on the map. Peter must enter at the gate, visit each of the twelve points (leaving a brass button behind to mark his visit), and then exit through the gate. He is pursued in this endeavor by Mr. McGregor who is restricted to moving on the garden pathways, unlike Peter. Mr. McGregor wins by catching Peter. Should Mr. McGregor choose to guard the gate rather than pursue Peter, an alternative escape route becomes available.

The game includes copies of Potter's handwritten rules for the game (both original and revised) and her original letter to the publisher introducing and endorsing the game - all from 1904 - as well as a recreation of her 1893 letter to 5-year-old Noel Moore, in which she first told and drew "The Tale of Peter Rabbit."

name: Suck My Marbles
description:
Players must select witty ways to describe the crazy stuff people love and hate. It's easy to learn and easy to play. Just deal the cards for guaranteed fun and laughter.

For 3 to 8 adult players.

name: Star Games
description:
This vintage constellation card set game by the Naturegraph Company of San Marin, California, comes with four different games.

1. Guess the Constellation: Teams attempt to guess the names of the constellation cards held by a game leader.

2. Deal Constellations: Two or more players attempt to guess the names of the constellations on other players cards.

3. Map the Sky: Players attempt to place cards in relation to the north star. (A star map is typically needed.)

4. Star Relay: Two teams with flashlights attempt to locate the most constellations.

(Perhaps holes could be poked through copies of the cards in order to project the constellation onto an inside wall?)

The game comes with cards representing 30 constellations that are visible in the Northern Hemisphere. A 1956 planet guide was also included.

The game was adapted from the book, The Stars, by H. A. Rey (Houghton-Mifflin Co., 1952) with permission from the author and publishers.
categories: Card Game, Educational, Memory, Party Game, Space Exploration

name: Knock The Clock
description:
The game comes with a deck of 25 cards (4 colors numbered 1-6 & a joker) plus a large comical plastic clock which serves as a timer and scoring device. The full deck is only required for a full complement of players.

All players are dealt 4 cards, except the player to the dealer's left who receives 5 (the 'captain'). The clock is wound and held until the deal is completed; the timer is then released. Cards are passed to the left on the direction of the captain until one player has four-of-a-kind; this player places their cards on the table.

As soon as this happens, opponents do the same, regardless of cards held at the time. This procedure mimics 'snap' and the player whose hand is on top also stops the clock timer and scores the amount indicated on the dial.

When any one player reaches 25 points, the game is over. The winner is the player with the lowest score at that time.
mechanics: Hand Management, Set Collection, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Who Ate All the Pies?!
description:
From the Publisher:

"It’s the big game. You’re there. You’re in your seat. You’re ready. But then, Oh-oh! Suddenly you feel the need – the need for greed!

That’s right, it’s PIE TIME!! Quick, out of your seat! Out of the stadium!! Go get those pies and get back with them before the clock runs out!!!

But, hold on! You’re not alone. Look around you! There are other players – and they’re after YOUR PIES!! They’re just as needy, just as greedy, but are they just as speedy as you?!"

And from a publisher's press release:
"The setting of the game is a sports stadium surrounded by concession stands selling Pies. Your playing piece is one of 8 comically greedy cartoon characters with a single-minded desire for Pies. With the clock ticking, the object of the game is to move your character out of the stadium, rush from Pie-stand to Pie-stand collecting as many Pies as possible and return with them to your seat before the time runs out. But, along the way, there are a myriad of dirty tricks and hazards. Elbow your opponents as you pass and make them drop their Pies! Trip them up and make them miss a turn! Make them slip on Banana Peels and make them drop a Pie AND miss a turn!! Lock them out of turnstiles! Lock them out of bathrooms! And, of course, your opponents are going to try to do the same to you. Plus, you’ve got to be careful of those turnstiles – you and your Pies might not fit through them! And, all the time, you’ve got to watch out for those Pies – some of them are Dodgy Pies! They might not like you as much as you like them!!"

In this game the players' decide how many rounds they will play and set the timer for the game.

name: Pendoka
description:
Pendoka is a set of small wooden spheres and plastic connectors. The spheres have four holes each, so you can build dodecahedrons and different three-dimensional structures with penta- and hexagons, varying the possible forms, twisted and shrinked ... the fact you can turn the connectors even if it is already sticking in a hole, offers many ways for construction.

There are different kinds of games you can play with Pendoka, from easy to difficult:
At "Master of Pentagon" the players get a certain number of colored spheres and connectors, each player his own color. The goal is to build after a couple of rules and hinder the others from building. Winner is the first player who built all his parts.

At "Fünferkette" (five-in-a-row) the winner is, who built the first five of his parts in a row, at "Your Turn" you have to enclose a sphere of the contrary player ...

There are even more Games in it, so Pendoka is not a single game of its own, but more a system, like Spiel (with hundreds of dice) - you can create your own rules, build as you want or have a look on the website for new ideas.

Home Page: http://www.pendoka.de
categories: Abstract Strategy, Game System, Math, Puzzle

name: Rolaire
description:
Rolaire is a played with colored balls, 5 red, 4 yellow, and 3 blue. You 'back' your fancy as to which colored combination will end up at the bottom of the customized ramp. There are ten winning combinations with the odds of favorite at 5/2 to the outsider at 72/1 !

The Rolaire box itself is made of plastic with a wooden surround. It tilts in the middle to create a gentle slope that the balls roll down. The surface of the board is made up of several channels and sloping hazards scientifically designed to impede and divert the balls on their way down to the winning slot at the bottom of the board.

A roulette type of mat is in play to place your hunches and there are several modes of play. A very rare game indeed!

name: Mozog
description:
A Nine Men's Morris Variant

Alignment type game with alignment inhibiting means , United States Patent 4579347

Abstract: A game board apparatus (10) comprising a plurality of playing pieces (12), and a game board (11); wherein the game board has a number x of diminishing diameter geometrical configurations (14) in the form of squares (15) formed from and attached to one another by solid (17) and broken (16) lines that delineate the movement of the playing pieces (12) on the game board (11).

name: Who Framed Roger Rabbit: Dip Flip
description: Play as Judge Doom tossing the toons in the dip or Eddie Valiant trying to save their very celluloid skins.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Ring My Nose
description:
Ages 4 and up can enjoy this great little party game. Try to get all three rings on my nose!

Comes with 1 game board and 3 rings for tossing.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game, Party Game

name: Fooly
description:
From BGN:

Ergomia is a small French publisher of games that uses ergonomic comma-shaped cards. Their newest game, designed by Marcel Rigaut, is a kid’s symbol matching game revolving around the animal food chain. Each card depicts an animal and the 1-3 things it likes to eat. Players can start a new food chain circle by playing a green card or they can add to an existing food chain circle by playing an orange or blue card with at least 1 matching food element to the adjacent card(s). The shape of the cards allows 8 cards to be played in a circle or “rose”. Whoever places the 8th card in a food chain circle gets to claim the set. Whoever claims the most sets is the winner.

name: Oil Spill
description:
From the box:

"You are the captain of an oil supertanker. Your objective is to outmaneuver the other captains and be the first to collect and deliver your cargo of crude oil to the refinery. Chart your course to navigate the environmentally sensitive waters and the hazards of the savage seas. Be prepared to face the consequences of human error. Each roll of the dice presents new obstacles and calls for different strategies. You will be rewarded for your environmental foresight. Reefs, Ice Floes and Oil Pirates make this an exciting adventure, challenging all captains.

Bon Voyage!"

"On March 24, 1989 the tanker Exxon Valdez crashed into Bligh Reef and spilled nearly eleven million gallons of crude oil into Prince William Sound. The environmental effects were catastrophic.

It was not the first Oil Spill.
It was not the last Oil Spill.

Perhaps there is a lesson to be learned.
This game will help people become more aware of oil transportation and methods of preparation for and prevention of oil spills."

Incredibly over-produced, and apparently incredibly random roll-and-move game, with tons of chance cards, most of which punish the player for lack of environmental foresight...
mechanics: Pick-up and Deliver, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Lolli Plop
description:
The game comes with two colored plastic 'lolli plops', about 8" high. The see-through lolli plops each contain 5 fully enclosed marbles, four black & one white. The aim is to shake the lolli plops until the marbles fall down the shaft.

The instructions come with a number of game variations.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game, Racing, Real-time
mechanics: Pick-up and Deliver, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Leave It To Beaver Ambush Game
description: This is the 1959, Leave It To Beaver Ambush Game designed by the Beaver, Jerry Mathers himself.

name: The Berenstain Bears Too Much Junk Food Game
description:
Join the race where good food sends you charging ahead, and junk food leaves you lagging behind.. Shows kids basic matching skills, and the benefits of a healthy diet..

Comes with: Game board, 1 spinner, 4 good food cards, 4 bear pawns, 20 star cards

name: Flip 'Em
description: Players take turns flipping large chips manufactured from foam onto a 4x4 grid. Players are allowed to layer their own chips on top of opponents' chips. The object is to get three in a row. The game includes the 4x4 board and 64 chips in 4 colors.

name: The Muldoon Game
description:
From the rules:
The MULDOON Game is for those who want to get away from the ordinary party chit chat; who want to let themselves go; and who want to gain a greater insight into the true personalities of those around them. So when you play the MULDOON game, sit down, relax, be honest to yourself...you'll have more fun.

"MULDOON: A person who is playing the MULDOON game. He remains a MULDOON until he reveals his identity to those playing the game with him."
"NOODLUM: A group of MULDOONS playing the MULDOON game. An ideal NOODLUM connsists of 6 to 12 MULDOONS."

A leader is chosen, each other player is given a sheet from the MULDOON pad. The leader then draws 10 question cards and reads them to the group. Players answer anonymously the questions. The leader will, then, read the answers. Players try to identify of the author of the answers, each correct guess is given 1 point. The winner is the player with the most points.

name: Listening to Nature
description:
Cock-a-doodle do, ring, ring, ...

What does this sound correspond to? Listen carefully to the tape and find out. A nice day is waiting for you. Are you coming for this excursion?

The players have to identify on the board the sound they hear on a cassette tape. The winner is the player who has identified the most sounds at the end of the game.

name: Gothic Line: The Battle of Monte Altuzzo
description:
This is a new game in the Advanced Tobruk: Tank Battles in North Africa 1940-43 System (ATS) that allows gamers to recreate squad-level action in World War II. The Gothic Line was a German defensive front in Italy.

From the publisher's website:

A highly detailed rendition of this titanic struggle pitting combined-arms US Army forces against determined German resistance along the infamous Gothic Line in 1944.

IN EACH GAME YOU GET:
- A complete collection of color die-cut counters in 1/2”, 5/8” and 3/4” sizes,
providing the tanks, guns, and men that fought in the battle depicted;
- Detailed game maps on heavyweight stock;
- The latest edition of the ATS rules of play;
- Scenarios and Play Aids printed on separate heavyweight cards;
- Two ten-sided dice.
publishers: (Looking for a publisher), Critical Hit, Inc.

name: Nishi Ridge: The Battle of Iwo Jima 1945
description:
This is an Advanced Tobruk: Tank Battles in North Africa 1940-43 System (ATS) game allowing players to recreate squad-level action from World War II.

From the publisher's website:

-- The US Marine Corps is at it again as they struggle for Nishi Ridge. Complete game.
IN EACH GAME YOU GET:
- A complete collection of color die-cut counters in 1/2”, 5/8” and 3/4” sizes,
providing the tanks, guns, and men that fought in the battle depicted;
- Detailed game maps on heavyweight stock;
- The latest edition of the ATS rules of play;
- Scenarios and Play Aids printed on separate heavyweight cards;
- Two ten-sided dice.
publishers: (Looking for a publisher), Critical Hit, Inc.

name: Double Cross
description:
This is a game in the Waddingtons House of Games Family Favorites series.

This rather simple game features a square board with a track around the edge and with a cross track through the center. Squares on the track have a number from 30 to 100. Players are given 700 dollars to start and have a counter that starts in one of the corners. Game play consists of rolling a die, moving along the track and collecting money according to the color and number of the square a player lands on.

The game ends when one player wins all the money, but with some foresight, the game makers included an option to play the game to a time limit.

name: Shockoe: The Trivia Game of Metropolitan Richmond
description:
This is a trivia game that has questions from around the Richmond, VA area. The introduction to the rules states:

Welcome to Shockoe! Enclosed you'll find 150 questions in each of five categories - Geography, History, Media, People and Variety - all related to Richmond. We hope that this game will serve several purposes. First, it is a game... a competition to see who knows Richmond best. Second, it is a hometown keepsake... a collection of Richmond where's, when's, and what's.

The questions in the game are a little outdated, having been made in 1985.

name: Great American History Games
description: This book for teachers and home schoolers includes a variety of American history games, featuring a double-sided color poster for the board game Courageous Colony: A Colonial Survival Game (about colonial Jamestown). Other games include Muckracker: A Progressive Era board game, Hear Ye! Hear Ye A Revolutionary War News Game, Famous Quotation Bingo, State Capital Map game, Passport to American immigration game (based on Who Am I?), North or South? Civil War Fact Game, West Quest Timeline Game, Spy Versus Spy Civil War game, and more. The authors also have another book of 15 Primary Source Activities in American History, which makes creative use of primary source documents for mock trials, TV broadcasts, living tableaux, movie story boards, and other fun activities.
categories: American Civil War, American Indian Wars, American Revolutionary War, American West, Book, Card Game, Educational, Exploration, Memory, Pirates, Spies/Secret Agents
mechanics: Acting, Cooperative Game, Memory, Paper-and-Pencil, Roll / Spin and Move, Simulation, Storytelling

name: Noun Hounds and Other Grammar Games
description: A book of 20 games for elementary to middle school teachers or home schoolers to use with children. Noun Hounds (the title game) is an alphabetical board game about naming nouns. Other games: Command Performance (imperative verbs, acting), Subject-Verb Relay Race, Time Travel Word Maze (verb tenses), Black Hole Pronouns, Hinky Pinky Adjectives, Where's Herman preposition game, Pearls of Wisdom Auction, Compound Your Luck Game, Riddle Relay Race, Crack Me Up capitalization challenge, Word Jam concentration, Sound Sister Board Game (homophones), and more. The grande finale is the Drop Deadline Grammar Slammer Game.
categories: Book, Card Game, Educational, Memory, Word Game
mechanics: Acting, Cooperative Game, Memory, Paper-and-Pencil, Roll / Spin and Move, Storytelling

name: Spot Opposites
description:
Spot was asleep. Now he's awake and he wants to play this game!

Spot is always doing something. He is inside, outside, over and under. Whatever; wherever; however you look at it, Spot is fun! While playing the game, children match puzzle pieces to learn about opposites.

name: Race to the Gold Diggings of Australia
description:
Race to the Gold Diggings of Australia, produced at the height of the gold rush in the min-1850s, is the earliest known board game devoted to Australia.

"In the game, children raced each other from Plymouth, in England, to Port Phillip, a stepping-off point in Victoria for those bound for the gold fields[...]" (National Library of Australia 2005, National Treasures of Australia's Great Libraries)

name: Official Scorer's Basketball Game
description:
From the back of the box:

Easy to Play - Ages: 8 through Adult - 1 or 2 Players

Realistic and exciting College Version Basketball Game which enables players to record each Field Goal, Free Throw, Rebound, Turnover and Foul just like in a real-life game. It's possible to be blown out or have a double overtime game. Unlike programmed electronic games, no two games will ever be alike.

Take your favorite team to the FINAL FOUR!!!!

It's great fun!!!

Game includes: Team Rosters, Scoresheet Pads, Game Instructions, Scoresheet Instructions, Game Scoring Pads, Dice, Dice Cup

- - - - - -

Now, after reading the instructions, here's how the game works.

Coaches choose their starting lineup and allocate the players to a position (two forwards, two guards, and a center). Then, they roll dice and confer with a standard results table (same table used for any team that plays--ie, there are no considerations for team or individual player talent level). Repeat this until game is over.

Hence, the game is not realistic in the sense that Clemson can beat UNC just as easily as UNC can beat Georgia Tech.

The box cover shows the logos of the then-eight teams in the ACC. Inside the box are all-star rosters for each of those teams (that is, players from different years play together), plus eight other teams (Georgetown, Indiana, Louisville, Marquette, UNLV, Notre Dame, St. Johns, and UCLA). For whatever reason, Abdul-Jabbar/Alcindor is not included on the all-time UCLA team.

That's about it. A basketball simulation with specified rosters, but you can list your own buddies names and get the same results when you take on the all-time all-star UNC Tarheels.

name: Think-n-link
description:
Although the Milton Bradley logo appears prominently on the box, this is apparently a self-published or prototype game. No copyright or authorship information is included with the game.

The materials are hand-made. The box looks like a standard gift box with artwork pasted on. The box insert and game base are constructed of foam board; the building pieces are thin, hand-painted wood or fiberboard. There are three kinds of slats, all parallelograms. Large red slats are notched at the end, large green slats at the ends and sides, and smaller yellow slats are notched at the corners.

Per the instructions, three slats are inserted in slots in the foam base and then the players take turns building a structure, adding slats by mating the notches. If the structure falls or bends enough to touch the table anywhere but the base, the last player loses.

The notches are inconsistently cut, so it's nearly impossible to play - sometimes you can't get the pieces together, and sometimes they fit too loose.

name: Hunt the Higgs
description:
Hunt the Higgs is an educational card game intended to introduce schoolchildren to a few of the basics of particle physics. Cards represent "bosons", "final states" and experimental events.

Players take turns in trying to pair a boson with a final state from their hand to make as a high a score as possible. These scores are hidden from other players and the player with the highest card combinations at the end of the game wins.
